quoteText:
The darling! She doesn't even guess what
it's all about.
subQuotationList: ['The darling!', "She doesn't even guess what\nit's all about."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
We'll
read Faust together ... by the Italian lakes ...
subQuotationList: ["We'll\nread Faust together ... by the Italian lakes ..."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well--upon my soul!
subQuotationList: ['Well--upon my soul!']
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText: My God!
subQuotationList: ['My God!']
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText:
I didn't think the Mingotts would have tried
it on.
subQuotationList: ["I didn't think the Mingotts would have tried\nit on."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
referringExpression: he gave his moustache a thoughtful twist and said

quoteText:
What's the use of
two good cooks in one family, now that I've married the girls and can't
eat sauces?
subQuotationList: ["What's the use of\ntwo good cooks in one family, now that I've married the girls and can't\neat sauces?"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
After all, after
all, just WHAT happened?
subQuotationList: ['After all,', 'after\nall, just WHAT happened?']
speaker: Young Thorley
referringExpression: he heard one of the younger men begin

quoteText: He's an awful brute, isn't he?
subQuotationList: ["He's an awful brute, isn't he?"]
speaker: Young Thorley
referringExpression: continued the young enquirer a candid Thorley

quoteText:
The very worst; I knew him at Nice, A half-paralysed white sneering fellow--rather handsome
head, but eyes with a lot of lashes.  Well, I'll tell you the sort:
when he wasn't with women he was collecting china.  Paying any price
for both, I understand.
subQuotationList:
['The very worst; I knew him at Nice,', "A half-paralysed white sneering fellow--rather handsome
head, but eyes with a lot of lashes.  Well, I'll tell you the sort:
when he wasn't with women he was collecting china.  Paying any price
for both, I understand."]
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText:
Well,
then----?
subQuotationList: ['Well,\nthen----?']
speaker: Young Thorley

quoteText: Well, then; she bolted with his secretary.
subQuotationList: ['Well, then; she bolted with his secretary.']
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText: Oh, I see.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I see.']
speaker: Young Thorley

quoteText:
It didn't last long, though: I heard of her a few months later living
alone in Venice.  I believe Lovell Mingott went out to get her.  He
said she was desperately unhappy.  That's all right--but this parading
her at the Opera's another thing.
subQuotationList:
["It didn't last long, though: I heard of her a few months later living
alone in Venice.  I believe Lovell Mingott went out to get her.  He
said she was desperately unhappy.  That's all right--but this parading
her at the Opera's another thing."]
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
Perhaps, she's too unhappy to be left at
home.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps,', "she's too unhappy to be left at\nhome."]
speaker: Young Thorley

quoteText: Oh, that's part of the campaign: Granny's orders, no doubt, When the old lady does a thing she does it thoroughly.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, that's part of the campaign: Granny's orders, no doubt,", 'When the old lady does a thing she does it thoroughly.']
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott']], [['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Old Mrs. Mingott']]]

quoteText:
I hope you've told Madame Olenska
that we're engaged?  I want everybody to know--I want you to let me
announce it this evening at the ball.
subQuotationList: ["I hope you've told Madame Olenska\nthat we're engaged?  I want everybody to know--I want you to let me\nannounce it this evening at the ball."]
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: he sat down beside his betrothed and said

quoteText:
If you can persuade Mamma, but why should
we change what is already settled?
subQuotationList: ['If you can persuade Mamma,', 'but why should\nwe change what is already settled?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Tell my cousin yourself: I give you leave.  She says she used to play
with you when you were children.
subQuotationList: ['Tell my cousin yourself: I give you leave.  She says she used to play\nwith you when you were children.']
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

subQuotationList: ["We DID use to play together, didn't we?", 'You were a horrid boy, and kissed me once behind a door;\nbut it was your cousin Vandie Newland, who never looked at me, that I\nwas in love with.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Ah, how this brings it all back to me--I see everybody here in
knickerbockers and pantalettes,
subQuotationList: ['Ah, how this brings it all back to me--I see everybody here in\nknickerbockers and pantalettes,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Yes, you have been away a very long time.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, you have been away a very long time.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, centuries and centuries; so long, that I'm sure I'm
dead and buried, and this dear old place is heaven;
subQuotationList: ['Oh, centuries and centuries; so long,', "that I'm sure I'm\ndead and buried, and this dear old place is heaven;"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: We all have our pet common people--
subQuotationList: ['We all have our pet common people--']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: Mrs Archer who was fond of coining her social philosophy into axioms had once said

quoteText: Now we shan't have to talk,
subQuotationList: ["Now we shan't have to talk,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Dear,
subQuotationList: ['Dear,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You see I did as you asked me to,
subQuotationList: ['You see I did as you asked me to,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Yes: I couldn't wait,
subQuotationList: ["Yes: I couldn't wait,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Only I wish it hadn't had to be at a ball.
subQuotationList: ["Only I wish it hadn't had to be at a ball."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes, I know.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I know.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
But after
all--even here we're alone together, aren't we?
subQuotationList: ["But after\nall--even here we're alone together, aren't we?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Oh, dearest--always!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, dearest--always!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
The worst of it is that I want to kiss you and
I can't.
subQuotationList: ["The worst of it is that I want to kiss you and\nI can't."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Did you tell my cousin Ellen?
subQuotationList: ['Did you tell my cousin Ellen?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: No--I hadn't the chance after all,
subQuotationList: ["No--I hadn't the chance after all,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah.
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
You must, then, for I didn't either; and I shouldn't like her
to think--
subQuotationList: ["You must, then, for I didn't either; and I shouldn't like her\nto think--"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Of course not.  But aren't you, after all, the person to do it?
subQuotationList: ["Of course not.  But aren't you, after all, the person to do it?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
If I'd done it at the right time, yes: but now
that there's been a delay I think you must explain that I'd asked you
to tell her at the Opera, before our speaking about it to everybody
here.  Otherwise she might think I had forgotten her.  You see, she's
one of the family, and she's been away so long that she's
rather--sensitive.
subQuotationList:
["If I'd done it at the right time, yes: but now
that there's been a delay I think you must explain that I'd asked you
to tell her at the Opera, before our speaking about it to everybody
here.  Otherwise she might think I had forgotten her.  You see, she's
one of the family, and she's been away so long that she's
rather--sensitive."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
Dear and great angel!  Of course I'll
tell her.
subQuotationList: ["Dear and great angel!  Of course I'll\ntell her."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: But I haven't seen her yet.  Has she come?
subQuotationList: ["But I haven't seen her yet.  Has she come?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No; at the last minute she decided not to.
subQuotationList: ['No; at the last minute she decided not to.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: At the last minute?
subQuotationList: ['At the last minute?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes.  She's awfully fond of dancing, But suddenly she made up her mind that her dress wasn't smart enough
for a ball, though we thought it so lovely; and so my aunt had to take
her home.
subQuotationList: ["Yes.  She's awfully fond of dancing,", "But suddenly she made up her mind that her dress wasn't smart enough\nfor a ball, though we thought it so lovely; and so my aunt had to take\nher home."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska']], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['May Wellend', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Oh, well--
subQuotationList: ['Oh, well--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
She knows as well as I do, the real reason of her
cousin's staying away; but I shall never let her see by the least sign
that I am conscious of there being a shadow of a shade on poor Ellen
Olenska's reputation.
subQuotationList:
['She knows as well as I do,', "the real reason of her
cousin's staying away; but I shall never let her see by the least sign
that I am conscious of there being a shadow of a shade on poor Ellen
Olenska's reputation."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Old-fashioned eyes?  I hope you don't mean mine, my dear?  I like all
the novelties,
subQuotationList: ["Old-fashioned eyes?  I hope you don't mean mine, my dear?  I like all\nthe novelties,"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Very handsome, very liberal.  In my time a cameo set
in pearls was thought sufficient.  But it's the hand that sets off the
ring, isn't it, my dear Mr. Archer?
subQuotationList: ['Very handsome,', "very liberal.  In my time a cameo set\nin pearls was thought sufficient.  But it's the hand that sets off the\nring, isn't it, my dear Mr. Archer?"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Mine was modelled in Rome by the great
Ferrigiani.  You should have May's done: no doubt he'll have it done,
my child.  Her hand is large--it's these modern sports that spread the
joints--but the skin is white.--And when's the wedding to be?
subQuotationList:
["Mine was modelled in Rome by the great
Ferrigiani.  You should have May's done: no doubt he'll have it done,
my child.  Her hand is large--it's these modern sports that spread the
joints--but the skin is white.--And when's the wedding to be?"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
As soon as ever it can, if only you'll back me
up, Mrs. Mingott.
subQuotationList: ["As soon as ever it can, if only you'll back me\nup, Mrs. Mingott."]
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: the young man smiling at his betrothed replied

quoteText:
Know each other?
Fiddlesticks!  Everybody in New York has always known everybody.  Let
the young man have his way, my dear; don't wait till the bubble's off
the wine.  Marry them before Lent; I may catch pneumonia any winter
now, and I want to give the wedding-breakfast.
subQuotationList:
["Know each other?
Fiddlesticks!  Everybody in New York has always known everybody.  Let
the young man have his way, my dear; don't wait till the bubble's off
the wine.  Marry them before Lent; I may catch pneumonia any winter
now, and I want to give the wedding-breakfast."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Ha!  Beaufort,
this is a rare favour!
subQuotationList: ['Ha!  Beaufort,\nthis is a rare favour!']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Thanks.  I wish it might happen oftener, I'm generally so tied down; but I met the Countess
Ellen in Madison Square, and she was good enough to let me walk home
with her.
subQuotationList: ['Thanks.  I wish it might happen oftener,', "I'm generally so tied down; but I met the Countess\nEllen in Madison Square, and she was good enough to let me walk home\nwith her."]
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
Ah--I hope the house will be gayer, now that Ellen's here! Sit down--sit down, Beaufort:
push up the yellow armchair; now I've got you I want a good gossip.  I
hear your ball was magnificent; and I understand you invited Mrs.
Lemuel Struthers?  Well--I've a curiosity to see the woman myself.
subQuotationList:
["Ah--I hope the house will be gayer, now that Ellen's here!", "Sit down--sit down, Beaufort:
push up the yellow armchair; now I've got you I want a good gossip.  I
hear your ball was magnificent; and I understand you invited Mrs.
Lemuel Struthers?  Well--I've a curiosity to see the woman myself."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Of course if you and Regina invite her
the thing is settled.  Well, we need new blood and new money--and I
hear she's still very good-looking,
subQuotationList: ["Of course if you and Regina invite her\nthe thing is settled.  Well, we need new blood and new money--and I\nhear she's still very good-looking,"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Regina'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Old Mrs. Mingott'], ['Mrs. Struthers']]]

quoteText:
Of course you know already--about May and me, She scolded me for not giving you the news
last night at the Opera: I had her orders to tell you that we were
engaged--but I couldn't, in that crowd.
subQuotationList: ['Of course you know already--about May and me,', "She scolded me for not giving you the news\nlast night at the Opera: I had her orders to tell you that we were\nengaged--but I couldn't, in that crowd."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Of
course I know; yes.  And I'm so glad.  But one doesn't tell such things
first in a crowd.
subQuotationList: ["Of\ncourse I know; yes.  And I'm so glad.  But one doesn't tell such things\nfirst in a crowd."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Good-bye; come and see me some day,
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye; come and see me some day,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
And she ought
to know that a man who's just engaged doesn't spend his time calling on
married women.  But I daresay in the set she's lived in they do--they
never do anything else.
subQuotationList:
["And she ought
to know that a man who's just engaged doesn't spend his time calling on
married women.  But I daresay in the set she's lived in they do--they
never do anything else."]
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: the young man himself mentally added

quoteText:
It's a pity the Beauforts asked her, But
then Regina always does what he tells her; and BEAUFORT--
subQuotationList: ["It's a pity the Beauforts asked her,", 'But\nthen Regina always does what he tells her; and BEAUFORT--']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: Certain nuances escape Beaufort,
subQuotationList: ['Certain nuances escape Beaufort,']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
Oh, necessarily; Beaufort is a vulgar man, My
grandfather Newland always used to say to my mother: But at
least he's had the advantage of associating with gentlemen; in England
too, they say.  It's all very mysterious--
subQuotationList:
['Oh, necessarily; Beaufort is a vulgar man,', 'My
grandfather Newland always used to say to my mother:', "But at
least he's had the advantage of associating with gentlemen; in England
too, they say.  It's all very mysterious--"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
But this Mrs. Struthers, what did you say SHE
was, Sillerton?
subQuotationList: ['But this Mrs. Struthers,', 'what did you say SHE\nwas, Sillerton?']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
Out of a mine: or rather out of the saloon at the head of the pit.
Then with Living Wax-Works, touring New England.  After the police
broke THAT up, they say she lived--
subQuotationList: ['Out of a mine: or rather out of the saloon at the head of the pit.\nThen with Living Wax-Works, touring New England.  After the police\nbroke THAT up, they say she lived--']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
Then, then Lemuel Struthers came along.  They say his advertiser used the
girl's head for the shoe-polish posters; her hair's intensely black,
you know--the Egyptian style.  Anyhow, he--eventually--married her.
subQuotationList: ['Then,', "then Lemuel Struthers came along.  They say his advertiser used the\ngirl's head for the shoe-polish posters; her hair's intensely black,\nyou know--the Egyptian style.  Anyhow, he--eventually--married her."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Lemuel Struthers'], ['Mrs. Lemuel Struthers'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['Mrs. Lemuel Struthers'], ['Mrs. Struthers']]]

quoteText: Oh, well--at the pass we've come to nowadays, it doesn't matter,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, well--at the pass we've come to nowadays, it doesn't matter,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson', 'Janey Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer']]]

quoteText: And Newland's new cousin--Countess Olenska?  Was SHE at the ball too?
subQuotationList: ["And Newland's new cousin--Countess Olenska?  Was SHE at the ball too?"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: she might presently be able to say

quoteText:
Especially after that silly business with Mrs.
Rushworth,
subQuotationList: ['Especially after that silly business with Mrs.\nRushworth,']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
It's not that I don't approve of the Mingotts'
esprit de corps; but why Newland's engagement should be mixed up with
that Olenska woman's comings and goings I don't see,
subQuotationList: ["It's not that I don't approve of the Mingotts'\nesprit de corps; but why Newland's engagement should be mixed up with\nthat Olenska woman's comings and goings I don't see,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott', 'Mrs. Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: I'm thankful that Augusta Welland received us alone.
subQuotationList: ["I'm thankful that Augusta Welland received us alone."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: she had permitted herself to say to her son

quoteText:
Oh,
well, there's always a phase of family parties to be gone through when
one gets engaged, and the sooner it's over the better.
subQuotationList: ["Oh,\nwell, there's always a phase of family parties to be gone through when\none gets engaged, and the sooner it's over the better."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, how your grandfather Archer loved a good dinner, my dear Newland! Well--well--well ... I wonder what he would have said to
all these foreign marriages!
subQuotationList: ['Ah, how your grandfather Archer loved a good dinner, my dear Newland!', 'Well--well--well ... I wonder what he would have said to\nall these foreign marriages!']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: No, she was NOT at the ball.
subQuotationList: ['No, she was NOT at the ball.']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: Ah--
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: Perhaps the Beauforts don't know her,
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps the Beauforts don't know her,"]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText:
Mrs. Beaufort may not--but Beaufort certainly does, for she
was seen walking up Fifth Avenue this afternoon with him by the whole
of New York.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Beaufort may not--but Beaufort certainly does, for she\nwas seen walking up Fifth Avenue this afternoon with him by the whole\nof New York.']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: Mercy--
subQuotationList: ['Mercy--']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
I wonder if she wears a round hat or a bonnet in the afternoon, At the Opera I know she had on dark blue velvet,
perfectly plain and flat--like a night-gown.
subQuotationList: ['I wonder if she wears a round hat or a bonnet in the afternoon,', 'At the Opera I know she had on dark blue velvet,\nperfectly plain and flat--like a night-gown.']
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Janey!
subQuotationList: ['Janey!']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: It was, at any rate, in better taste not to go to the ball,
subQuotationList: ['It was, at any rate, in better taste not to go to the ball,']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
I don't think it was
a question of taste with her.  May said she meant to go, and then
decided that the dress in question wasn't smart enough.
subQuotationList: ["I don't think it was\na question of taste with her.  May said she meant to go, and then\ndecided that the dress in question wasn't smart enough."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Poor
Ellen, We must always
bear in mind what an eccentric bringing-up Medora Manson gave her.
What can you expect of a girl who was allowed to wear black satin at
her coming-out ball?
subQuotationList:
['Poor
Ellen,', 'We must always
bear in mind what an eccentric bringing-up Medora Manson gave her.
What can you expect of a girl who was allowed to wear black satin at
her coming-out ball?']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
Ah--don't I remember her in it! Poor
girl!
subQuotationList: ["Ah--don't I remember her in it!", 'Poor\ngirl!']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
It's odd, that she should have kept such an ugly
name as Ellen.  I should have changed it to Elaine.
subQuotationList: ["It's odd,", 'that she should have kept such an ugly\nname as Ellen.  I should have changed it to Elaine.']
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Why Elaine?
subQuotationList: ['Why Elaine?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I don't know; it sounds more--more Polish,
subQuotationList: ["I don't know; it sounds more--more Polish,"]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: It sounds more conspicuous; and that can hardly be what she wishes,
subQuotationList: ['It sounds more conspicuous; and that can hardly be what she wishes,']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
Why not? Why
shouldn't she be conspicuous if she chooses?  Why should she slink
about as if it were she who had disgraced herself?  She's 'poor Ellen'
certainly, because she had the bad luck to make a wretched marriage;
but I don't see that that's a reason for hiding her head as if she were
the culprit.
subQuotationList:
['Why not?', "Why
shouldn't she be conspicuous if she chooses?  Why should she slink
about as if it were she who had disgraced herself?  She's 'poor Ellen'
certainly, because she had the bad luck to make a wretched marriage;
but I don't see that that's a reason for hiding her head as if she were
the culprit."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
That, I suppose, is the line the
Mingotts mean to take.
subQuotationList: ['That, I suppose,', 'is the line the\nMingotts mean to take.']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
I didn't have to wait for their cue, if
that's what you mean, sir.  Madame Olenska has had an unhappy life:
that doesn't make her an outcast.
subQuotationList: ["I didn't have to wait for their cue, if\nthat's what you mean, sir.  Madame Olenska has had an unhappy life:\nthat doesn't make her an outcast."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott', 'Mrs. Welland', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: There are rumours,
subQuotationList: ['There are rumours,']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: Oh, I know: the secretary,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I know: the secretary,']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: the young man took him up

quoteText:
Nonsense,
mother; Janey's grown-up.  They say, don't they, that the
secretary helped her to get away from her brute of a husband, who kept
her practically a prisoner?  Well, what if he did?  I hope there isn't
a man among us who wouldn't have done the same in such a case.
subQuotationList:
["Nonsense,
mother; Janey's grown-up.  They say, don't they,", "that the
secretary helped her to get away from her brute of a husband, who kept
her practically a prisoner?  Well, what if he did?  I hope there isn't
a man among us who wouldn't have done the same in such a case."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Janey Archer']], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Janey Archer']]]

quoteText: Perhaps ... that sauce ... just a little, after all--
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps ... that sauce ... just a little, after all--']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
referringExpression: Mr Jackson glanced over his shoulder to say to the sad butler

quoteText:
I'm told she's looking for a house.  She
means to live here.
subQuotationList: ["I'm told she's looking for a house.  She\nmeans to live here."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: I hear she means to get a divorce,
subQuotationList: ['I hear she means to get a divorce,']
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: I hope she will!
subQuotationList: ['I hope she will!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You say the
secretary merely helped her to get away, my dear fellow?  Well, he was
still helping her a year later, then; for somebody met 'em living at
Lausanne together.
subQuotationList:
["You say the
secretary merely helped her to get away, my dear fellow?  Well, he was
still helping her a year later, then; for somebody met 'em living at
Lausanne together."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
referringExpression: Mr Jackson sank into the armchair with satisfaction lit his cigar with perfect confidence it was Newland who bought them and stretching his thin old ankles to the coals said

quoteText:
Living together?  Well, why not?  Who had the right
to make her life over if she hadn't?  I'm sick of the hypocrisy that
would bury alive a woman of her age if her husband prefers to live with
harlots.
subQuotationList:
["Living together?  Well, why not?  Who had the right
to make her life over if she hadn't?  I'm sick of the hypocrisy that
would bury alive a woman of her age if her husband prefers to live with
harlots."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Women ought to
be free--as free as we are,
subQuotationList: ['Women ought to\nbe free--as free as we are,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well, apparently Count Olenski takes your
view; for I never heard of his having lifted a finger to get his wife
back.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'apparently Count Olenski takes your\nview; for I never heard of his having lifted a finger to get his wife\nback.']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
Hang
Ellen Olenska!
subQuotationList: ['Hang\nEllen Olenska!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I'll go and see Louisa van der Luyden.
subQuotationList: ["I'll go and see Louisa van der Luyden."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: his mother who after a painful period of inward resistance and outward temporising succumbed to his instances as she always did and immediately embracing his cause with an energy redoubled by her previous hesitations put on her grey velvet bonnet and said

quoteText:
Don't tell me, all this
modern newspaper rubbish about a New York aristocracy.  If there is
one, neither the Mingotts nor the Mansons belong to it; no, nor the
Newlands or the Chiverses either.  Our grandfathers and
great-grandfathers were just respectable English or Dutch merchants,
who came to the colonies to make their fortune, and stayed here because
they did so well.  One of your great-grandfathers signed the
Declaration, and another was a general on Washington's staff, and
received General Burgoyne's sword after the battle of Saratoga.  These
are things to be proud of, but they have nothing to do with rank or
class.  New York has always been a commercial community, and there are
not more than three families in it who can claim an aristocratic origin
in the real sense of the word.
subQuotationList:
["Don't tell me,", "all this
modern newspaper rubbish about a New York aristocracy.  If there is
one, neither the Mingotts nor the Mansons belong to it; no, nor the
Newlands or the Chiverses either.  Our grandfathers and
great-grandfathers were just respectable English or Dutch merchants,
who came to the colonies to make their fortune, and stayed here because
they did so well.  One of your great-grandfathers signed the
Declaration, and another was a general on Washington's staff, and
received General Burgoyne's sword after the battle of Saratoga.  These
are things to be proud of, but they have nothing to do with rank or
class.  New York has always been a commercial community, and there are
not more than three families in it who can claim an aristocratic origin
in the real sense of the word."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: Mrs Archer would say to her children

quoteText:
I wish you would go with me, Newland, Louisa is fond of you; and of
course it's on account of dear May that I'm taking this step--and also
because, if we don't all stand together, there'll be no such thing as
Society left.
subQuotationList:
['I wish you would go with me, Newland,', "Louisa is fond of you; and of
course it's on account of dear May that I'm taking this step--and also
because, if we don't all stand together, there'll be no such thing as
Society left."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']], [['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer']]]

quoteText:
I shall first
have to talk this over with my husband.
subQuotationList: ['I shall first\nhave to talk this over with my husband.']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
referringExpression: Mrs van der Luydens attitude said neither yes nor no but always appeared to incline to clemency till her thin lips wavering into the shadow of a smile made the almost invariable reply

quoteText:
I think, I should like Henry to hear what you have told
me.
subQuotationList: ['I think,', 'I should like Henry to hear what you have told\nme.']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden

quoteText:
If Mr. van der Luyden
has finished reading the newspaper, please ask him to be kind enough to
come.
subQuotationList: ['If Mr. van der Luyden\nhas finished reading the newspaper, please ask him to be kind enough to\ncome.']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
Henry always enjoys seeing you, dear Adeline; and he will wish to
congratulate Newland.
subQuotationList: ['Henry always enjoys seeing you, dear Adeline; and he will wish to\ncongratulate Newland.']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
I had just finished reading the Times, In town my mornings are so much occupied that I
find it more convenient to read the newspapers after luncheon.
subQuotationList: ['I had just finished reading the Times,', 'In town my mornings are so much occupied that I\nfind it more convenient to read the newspapers after luncheon.']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
Ah, there's a great deal to be said for that plan--indeed I think my
uncle Egmont used to say he found it less agitating not to read the
morning papers till after dinner,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, there's a great deal to be said for that plan--indeed I think my\nuncle Egmont used to say he found it less agitating not to read the\nmorning papers till after dinner,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
Yes: my good father abhorred hurry.  But now we live in a constant
rush,
subQuotationList: ['Yes: my good father abhorred hurry.  But now we live in a constant\nrush,']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: But I hope you HAD finished your reading, Henry?
subQuotationList: ['But I hope you HAD finished your reading, Henry?']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: Quite--quite,
subQuotationList: ['Quite--quite,']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText: Then I should like Adeline to tell you--
subQuotationList: ['Then I should like Adeline to tell you--']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer']

quoteText: Oh, it's really Newland's story,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, it's really Newland's story,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
Of course, Augusta Welland and Mary Mingott both felt
that, especially in view of Newland's engagement, you and Henry OUGHT
TO KNOW.
subQuotationList: ['Of course,', "Augusta Welland and Mary Mingott both felt\nthat, especially in view of Newland's engagement, you and Henry OUGHT\nTO KNOW."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Welland'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: Ah--
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
You really think this is due to some--some intentional interference of
Lawrence Lefferts's?
subQuotationList: ["You really think this is due to some--some intentional interference of\nLawrence Lefferts's?"]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
I'm certain of it, sir.  Larry has been going it rather harder than
usual lately--if cousin Louisa won't mind my mentioning it--having
rather a stiff affair with the postmaster's wife in their village, or
some one of that sort; and whenever poor Gertrude Lefferts begins to
suspect anything, and he's afraid of trouble, he gets up a fuss of this
kind, to show how awfully moral he is, and talks at the top of his
voice about the impertinence of inviting his wife to meet people he
doesn't wish her to know.  He's simply using Madame Olenska as a
lightning-rod; I've seen him try the same thing often before.
subQuotationList:
["I'm certain of it, sir.  Larry has been going it rather harder than
usual lately--if cousin Louisa won't mind my mentioning it--having
rather a stiff affair with the postmaster's wife in their village, or
some one of that sort; and whenever poor Gertrude Lefferts begins to
suspect anything, and he's afraid of trouble, he gets up a fuss of this
kind, to show how awfully moral he is, and talks at the top of his
voice about the impertinence of inviting his wife to meet people he
doesn't wish her to know.  He's simply using Madame Olenska as a
lightning-rod; I've seen him try the same thing often before."]
speaker: Newland Archer
addressees: ['Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Lawrence Lefferts'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Gertrude Lefferts'], ['Gertrude Lefferts'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: The LEFFERTSES!--
subQuotationList: ['The LEFFERTSES!--']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer']

quoteText:
The LEFFERTSES!-- What would uncle Egmont have
said of Lawrence Lefferts's pronouncing on anybody's social position?
It shows what Society has come to.
subQuotationList: ['The LEFFERTSES!--', "What would uncle Egmont have\nsaid of Lawrence Lefferts's pronouncing on anybody's social position?\nIt shows what Society has come to."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText: We'll hope it has not quite come to that,
subQuotationList: ["We'll hope it has not quite come to that,"]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: Ah, if only you and Louisa went out more!
subQuotationList: ['Ah, if only you and Louisa went out more!']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
Everybody in New York
knows what you and cousin Louisa represent.  That's why Mrs. Mingott
felt she ought not to allow this slight on Countess Olenska to pass
without consulting you.
subQuotationList:
["Everybody in New York
knows what you and cousin Louisa represent.  That's why Mrs. Mingott
felt she ought not to allow this slight on Countess Olenska to pass
without consulting you."]
speaker: Newland Archer
addressees: ['Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
referringExpression: Newland Archer came to his mothers rescue
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
It is the principle that I dislike, As
long as a member of a well-known family is backed up by that family it
should be considered--final.
subQuotationList: ['It is the principle that I dislike,', 'As\nlong as a member of a well-known family is backed up by that family it\nshould be considered--final.']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText: It seems so to me,
subQuotationList: ['It seems so to me,']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer']

quoteText:
I had no idea, that things had come to
such a pass. It occurs to
me, my dear, that the Countess Olenska is already a sort of
relation--through Medora Manson's first husband.  At any rate, she will
be when Newland marries. Have you
read this morning's Times, Newland?
subQuotationList:
['I had no idea,', 'that things had come to
such a pass.', "It occurs to
me, my dear, that the Countess Olenska is already a sort of
relation--through Medora Manson's first husband.  At any rate, she will
be when Newland marries.", "Have you
read this morning's Times, Newland?"]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText: Why, yes, sir,
subQuotationList: ['Why, yes, sir,']
speaker: Newland Archer
addressees: ['Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
If Louisa's health allowed
her to dine out--I wish you would say to Mrs. Lovell Mingott--she and I
would have been happy to--er--fill the places of the Lawrence
Leffertses at her dinner.
subQuotationList:
["If Louisa's health allowed
her to dine out--I wish you would say to Mrs. Lovell Mingott--she and I
would have been happy to--er--fill the places of the Lawrence
Leffertses at her dinner."]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Lawrence Lefferts'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott']]]

quoteText: As you know, this is impossible.
subQuotationList: ['As you know, this is impossible.']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
But Newland tells me he has read this morning's Times;
therefore he has probably seen that Louisa's relative, the Duke of St.
Austrey, arrives next week on the Russia.  He is coming to enter his
new sloop, the Guinevere, in next summer's International Cup Race; and
also to have a little canvasback shooting at Trevenna.
subQuotationList:
["But Newland tells me he has read this morning's Times;
therefore he has probably seen that Louisa's relative, the Duke of St.
Austrey, arrives next week on the Russia.  He is coming to enter his
new sloop, the Guinevere, in next summer's International Cup Race; and
also to have a little canvasback shooting at Trevenna."]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['The Duke'], ['Duke'], ['The Duke'], ['The Duke']]]

quoteText:
Before taking him down to Maryland we are inviting a few friends to
meet him here--only a little dinner--with a reception afterward.  I am
sure Louisa will be as glad as I am if Countess Olenska will let us
include her among our guests.
subQuotationList:
['Before taking him down to Maryland we are inviting a few friends to
meet him here--only a little dinner--with a reception afterward.  I am
sure Louisa will be as glad as I am if Countess Olenska will let us
include her among our guests.']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
referringExpression: Mr van der Luyden paused again and continued
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Duke'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['The Duke'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
I think I have
Louisa's authority for saying that she will herself leave the
invitation to dine when she drives out presently: with our cards--of
course with our cards.
subQuotationList:
["I think I have
Louisa's authority for saying that she will herself leave the
invitation to dine when she drives out presently: with our cards--of
course with our cards."]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
referringExpression: He got up bent his long body with a stiff friendliness toward his cousin and added
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
There is nothing to thank me for, dear Adeline; nothing whatever.
This kind of thing must not happen in New York; it shall not, as long
as I can help it,
subQuotationList: ['There is nothing to thank me for, dear Adeline; nothing whatever.\nThis kind of thing must not happen in New York; it shall not, as long\nas I can help it,']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
No one but
Patti ought to attempt the Sonnambula.
subQuotationList: ['No one but\nPatti ought to attempt the Sonnambula.']
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText: I want you to talk to me about May,
subQuotationList: ['I want you to talk to me about May,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You knew the Duke before?
subQuotationList: ['You knew the Duke before?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, yes--we used to see him every winter at Nice.  He's very fond of
gambling--he used to come to the house a great deal.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, yes--we used to see him every winter at Nice.  He's very fond of\ngambling--he used to come to the house a great deal."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I think he's the dullest man I
ever met.
subQuotationList: ["I think he's the dullest man I\never met."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
May is a darling; I've seen no young girl in New York so handsome and
so intelligent.  Are you very much in love with her?
subQuotationList: ["May is a darling; I've seen no young girl in New York so handsome and\nso intelligent.  Are you very much in love with her?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: As much as a man can be.
subQuotationList: ['As much as a man can be.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Do you think, then, there is a limit?
subQuotationList: ['Do you think, then, there is a limit?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: To being in love?  If there is, I haven't found it!
subQuotationList: ["To being in love?  If there is, I haven't found it!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah--it's really and truly a romance?
subQuotationList: ["Ah--it's really and truly a romance?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: The most romantic of romances!
subQuotationList: ['The most romantic of romances!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
How delightful!  And you found it all out for yourselves--it was not
in the least arranged for you?
subQuotationList: ['How delightful!  And you found it all out for yourselves--it was not\nin the least arranged for you?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Have you forgotten, that in our country we don't allow our marriages to be
arranged for us?
subQuotationList: ['Have you forgotten,', "that in our country we don't allow our marriages to be\narranged for us?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes, I'd forgotten.  You must forgive me if I
sometimes make these mistakes.  I don't always remember that everything
here is good that was--that was bad where I've come from.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', "I'd forgotten.  You must forgive me if I\nsometimes make these mistakes.  I don't always remember that everything\nhere is good that was--that was bad where I've come from."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I'm so sorry, but you ARE among friends here,
you know.
subQuotationList: ["I'm so sorry,", 'but you ARE among friends here,\nyou know.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes--I know.  Wherever I go I have that feeling.  That's why I came
home.  I want to forget everything else, to become a complete American
again, like the Mingotts and Wellands, and you and your delightful
mother, and all the other good people here tonight.  Ah, here's May
arriving, and you will want to hurry away to her,
subQuotationList:
["Yes--I know.  Wherever I go I have that feeling.  That's why I came
home.  I want to forget everything else, to become a complete American
again, like the Mingotts and Wellands, and you and your delightful
mother, and all the other good people here tonight.  Ah, here's May
arriving, and you will want to hurry away to her,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Oh, I have so many rivals; you see she's already
surrounded.  There's the Duke being introduced.
subQuotationList: ['Oh,', "I have so many rivals; you see she's already\nsurrounded.  There's the Duke being introduced."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Then stay with me a little longer,
subQuotationList: ['Then stay with me a little longer,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Yes, let me stay,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, let me stay,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Tomorrow, then, after five--I shall expect you,
subQuotationList: ['Tomorrow, then, after five--I shall expect you,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Tomorrow--
subQuotationList: ['Tomorrow--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It was good of you, dear Newland, to devote yourself
so unselfishly to Madame Olenska.  I told your cousin Henry he must
really come to the rescue.
subQuotationList: ['It was good of you, dear Newland, to devote yourself\nso unselfishly to Madame Olenska.  I told your cousin Henry he must\nreally come to the rescue.']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
I've never seen May looking
lovelier.  The Duke thinks her the handsomest girl in the room.
subQuotationList: ["I've never seen May looking\nlovelier.  The Duke thinks her the handsomest girl in the room."]
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden

quoteText:
La signora e
fuori; ma verra subito
subQuotationList: ['La signora e\nfuori; ma verra subito']
speaker: Nastasia

quoteText: Verra--verra.
subQuotationList: ['Verra--verra.']
speaker: Nastasia
referringExpression: The roundbosomed maid came in drew the curtains pushed back a log and said

quoteText: How do you like my funny house? To me it's like heaven.
subQuotationList: ['How do you like my funny house?', "To me it's like heaven."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You've arranged it delightfully,
subQuotationList: ["You've arranged it delightfully,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, it's a poor little place.  My relations despise it.  But at any
rate it's less gloomy than the van der Luydens'.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, it's a poor little place.  My relations despise it.  But at any\nrate it's less gloomy than the van der Luydens'."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: It's delicious--what you've done here,
subQuotationList: ["It's delicious--what you've done here,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

subQuotationList: ['I like the little house,', 'but I suppose what I like is\nthe blessedness of its being here, in my own country and my own town;\nand then, of being alone in it.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You like so much to be alone?
subQuotationList: ['You like so much to be alone?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes; as long as my friends keep me from feeling lonely.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; as long as my friends keep me from feeling lonely.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Nastasia will bring the tea presently, I see you've already
chosen your corner.
subQuotationList: ['Nastasia will bring the tea presently,', "I see you've already\nchosen your corner."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: She sat down near the fire said

quoteText: This is the hour I like best--don't you?
subQuotationList: ["This is the hour I like best--don't you?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I was afraid you'd
forgotten the hour.  Beaufort must have been very engrossing.
subQuotationList: ["I was afraid you'd\nforgotten the hour.  Beaufort must have been very engrossing."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Why--have you waited long?  Mr. Beaufort took me
to see a number of houses--since it seems I'm not to be allowed to stay
in this one.
subQuotationList: ["Why--have you waited long?  Mr. Beaufort took me\nto see a number of houses--since it seems I'm not to be allowed to stay\nin this one."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I've never been in a city where there seems to
be such a feeling against living in des quartiers excentriques.  What
does it matter where one lives?  I'm told this street is respectable.
subQuotationList: ["I've never been in a city where there seems to\nbe such a feeling against living in des quartiers excentriques.  What\ndoes it matter where one lives?  I'm told this street is respectable."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: She appeared to dismiss both Beaufort and himself from her mind and went on

quoteText: It's not fashionable.
subQuotationList: ["It's not fashionable."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Fashionable!  Do you all think so much of that?  Why not make one's
own fashions?  But I suppose I've lived too independently; at any rate,
I want to do what you all do--I want to feel cared for and safe.
subQuotationList: ["Fashionable!  Do you all think so much of that?  Why not make one's\nown fashions?  But I suppose I've lived too independently; at any rate,\nI want to do what you all do--I want to feel cared for and safe."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
That's what your friends want you to feel.  New York's an awfully safe
place,
subQuotationList: ["That's what your friends want you to feel.  New York's an awfully safe\nplace,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes, isn't it?  One feels that, Being here is like--like--being taken on a holiday when one has been a
good little girl and done all one's lessons.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, isn't it?  One feels that,", "Being here is like--like--being taken on a holiday when one has been a\ngood little girl and done all one's lessons."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Last night, New York laid itself out for you.  The van der
Luydens do nothing by halves.
subQuotationList: ['Last night,', 'New York laid itself out for you.  The van der\nLuydens do nothing by halves.']
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
No: how kind they are!  It was such a nice party.  Every one seems to
have such an esteem for them.
subQuotationList: ['No: how kind they are!  It was such a nice party.  Every one seems to\nhave such an esteem for them.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
The van der Luydens, are the most powerful influence in New York society.
Unfortunately--owing to her health--they receive very seldom.
subQuotationList: ['The van der Luydens,', 'are the most powerful influence in New York society.\nUnfortunately--owing to her health--they receive very seldom.']
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']], [['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: Isn't that perhaps the reason?
subQuotationList: ["Isn't that perhaps the reason?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: The reason--?
subQuotationList: ['The reason--?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: For their great influence; that they make themselves so rare.
subQuotationList: ['For their great influence; that they make themselves so rare.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
But you'll explain these things to me--you'll tell me all I ought to
know,
subQuotationList: ["But you'll explain these things to me--you'll tell me all I ought to\nknow,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
It's you who are telling me; opening my eyes to things I'd looked at
so long that I'd ceased to see them.
subQuotationList: ["It's you who are telling me; opening my eyes to things I'd looked at\nso long that I'd ceased to see them."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
Ah, then we can both help each other.  But I want help so much more.
You must tell me just what to do.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, then we can both help each other.  But I want help so much more.\nYou must tell me just what to do.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: There are plenty of people to tell you what to do,
subQuotationList: ['There are plenty of people to tell you what to do,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh--all my aunts?  And my dear old Granny?
subQuotationList: ['Oh--all my aunts?  And my dear old Granny?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
They're all a little vexed with me for setting up for
myself--poor Granny especially.  She wanted to keep me with her; but I
had to be free--
subQuotationList: ["They're all a little vexed with me for setting up for\nmyself--poor Granny especially.  She wanted to keep me with her; but I\nhad to be free--"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott']]]

quoteText:
I think I understand how you feel, Still, your family can
advise you; explain differences; show you the way.
subQuotationList: ['I think I understand how you feel,', 'Still, your family can\nadvise you; explain differences; show you the way.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Is New York such a labyrinth?  I
thought it so straight up and down--like Fifth Avenue.  And with all
the cross streets numbered!
subQuotationList: ['Is New York such a labyrinth?  I\nthought it so straight up and down--like Fifth Avenue.  And with all\nthe cross streets numbered!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
If you knew how I like it for just THAT--the straight-up-and-downness,
and the big honest labels on everything!
subQuotationList: ['If you knew how I like it for just THAT--the straight-up-and-downness,\nand the big honest labels on everything!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: She seemed to guess his faint disapproval of this and added

quoteText: Everything may be labelled--but everybody is not.
subQuotationList: ['Everything may be labelled--but everybody is not.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Perhaps.  I may simplify too much--but you'll warn me if I do.
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps.  I may simplify too much--but you'll warn me if I do."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
There are only two people here
who make me feel as if they understood what I mean and could explain
things to me: you and Mr. Beaufort.
subQuotationList: ['There are only two people here\nwho make me feel as if they understood what I mean and could explain\nthings to me: you and Mr. Beaufort.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I understand.  But just at first don't let go of
your old friends' hands: I mean the older women, your Granny Mingott,
Mrs. Welland, Mrs. van der Luyden.  They like and admire you--they want
to help you.
subQuotationList:
["I understand.  But just at first don't let go of
your old friends' hands: I mean the older women, your Granny Mingott,
Mrs. Welland, Mrs. van der Luyden.  They like and admire you--they want
to help you."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Welland'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
Oh, I know--I know!  But on condition
that they don't hear anything unpleasant.  Aunt Welland put it in those
very words when I tried....  Does no one want to know the truth here,
Mr. Archer?  The real loneliness is living among all these kind people
who only ask one to pretend!
subQuotationList:
["Oh, I know--I know!  But on condition
that they don't hear anything unpleasant.  Aunt Welland put it in those
very words when I tried....  Does no one want to know the truth here,
Mr. Archer?  The real loneliness is living among all these kind people
who only ask one to pretend!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: She shook her head and sighed
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Welland']]]

quoteText: Madame Olenska!--Oh, don't, Ellen,
subQuotationList: ["Madame Olenska!--Oh, don't, Ellen,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Does no one cry here, either?  I suppose there's no need to, in
heaven,
subQuotationList: ["Does no one cry here, either?  I suppose there's no need to, in\nheaven,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
My dear Countess, I've brought an old friend of mine to see you--Mrs.
Struthers.  She wasn't asked to the party last night, and she wants to
know you.
subQuotationList: ["My dear Countess, I've brought an old friend of mine to see you--Mrs.\nStruthers.  She wasn't asked to the party last night, and she wants to\nknow you."]
speaker: The Duke
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
How kind!  How
good of the Duke to think of me!
subQuotationList: ['How kind!  How\ngood of the Duke to think of me!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Of course I
shall be too happy to come.
subQuotationList: ['Of course I\nshall be too happy to come.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Rather
subQuotationList: ['Rather']
speaker: The Duke

quoteText: They'll go at once?
subQuotationList: ["They'll go at once?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It's so delicious--waking every morning to smell lilies-of-the-valley
in one's room!
subQuotationList: ["It's so delicious--waking every morning to smell lilies-of-the-valley\nin one's room!"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Yesterday they came late.  I hadn't time in the morning--
subQuotationList: ["Yesterday they came late.  I hadn't time in the morning--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
But your remembering each day to send them makes me love them so much
more than if you'd given a standing order, and they came every morning
on the minute, like one's music-teacher--as I know Gertrude Lefferts's
did, for instance, when she and Lawrence were engaged.
subQuotationList:
["But your remembering each day to send them makes me love them so much
more than if you'd given a standing order, and they came every morning
on the minute, like one's music-teacher--as I know Gertrude Lefferts's
did, for instance, when she and Lawrence were engaged."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Ah--they would!
subQuotationList: ['Ah--they would!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
When I sent your lilies yesterday afternoon I saw some rather
gorgeous yellow roses and packed them off to Madame Olenska.  Was that
right?
subQuotationList: ['When I sent your lilies yesterday afternoon I saw some rather\ngorgeous yellow roses and packed them off to Madame Olenska.  Was that\nright?']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: He looked sideways at her fruitlike cheek and felt rich and secure enough to add

quoteText:
How dear of you!  Anything of that kind delights her.  It's odd she
didn't mention it: she lunched with us today, and spoke of Mr.
Beaufort's having sent her wonderful orchids, and cousin Henry van der
Luyden a whole hamper of carnations from Skuytercliff.  She seems so
surprised to receive flowers.  Don't people send them in Europe?  She
thinks it such a pretty custom.
subQuotationList:
["How dear of you!  Anything of that kind delights her.  It's odd she
didn't mention it: she lunched with us today, and spoke of Mr.
Beaufort's having sent her wonderful orchids, and cousin Henry van der
Luyden a whole hamper of carnations from Skuytercliff.  She seems so
surprised to receive flowers.  Don't people send them in Europe?  She
thinks it such a pretty custom."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['May Wellend', 'Old Mrs. Mingott', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Oh, well, no wonder mine were overshadowed by Beaufort's,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, well, no wonder mine were overshadowed by Beaufort's,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
If you call it long!  Isabel Chivers and Reggie were engaged for two
years: Grace and Thorley for nearly a year and a half.  Why aren't we
very well off as we are?
subQuotationList: ["If you call it long!  Isabel Chivers and Reggie were engaged for two\nyears: Grace and Thorley for nearly a year and a half.  Why aren't we\nvery well off as we are?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Never, if we won't let them, I suppose,
subQuotationList: ["Never, if we won't let them, I suppose,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
We might be much better off.  We might be altogether together--we
might travel.
subQuotationList: ['We might be much better off.  We might be altogether together--we\nmight travel.']
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: That would be lovely,
subQuotationList: ['That would be lovely,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: As if the mere 'differently' didn't account for it!
subQuotationList: ["As if the mere 'differently' didn't account for it!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Newland!  You're so original!
subQuotationList: ["Newland!  You're so original!"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Original!  We're all as like each other as those dolls cut out of the
same folded paper.  We're like patterns stencilled on a wall.  Can't
you and I strike out for ourselves, May?
subQuotationList: ["Original!  We're all as like each other as those dolls cut out of the\nsame folded paper.  We're like patterns stencilled on a wall.  Can't\nyou and I strike out for ourselves, May?"]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland']]]

quoteText: Mercy--shall we elope?
subQuotationList: ['Mercy--shall we elope?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: If you would--
subQuotationList: ['If you would--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You DO love me, Newland!  I'm so happy.
subQuotationList: ["You DO love me, Newland!  I'm so happy."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: But then--why not be happier?
subQuotationList: ['But then--why not be happier?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: We can't behave like people in novels, though, can we?
subQuotationList: ["We can't behave like people in novels, though, can we?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Why not--why not--why not?
subQuotationList: ['Why not--why not--why not?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I'm not clever enough to argue with you.  But that kind of thing is
rather--vulgar, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["I'm not clever enough to argue with you.  But that kind of thing is\nrather--vulgar, isn't it?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Are you so much afraid, then, of being vulgar?
subQuotationList: ['Are you so much afraid, then, of being vulgar?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Of course I should hate it--so
would you,
subQuotationList: ['Of course I should hate it--so\nwould you,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Oh, did I tell you that I
showed Ellen my ring?  She thinks it the most beautiful setting she
ever saw.  There's nothing like it in the rue de la Paix, she said.  I
do love you, Newland, for being so artistic!
subQuotationList:
["Oh, did I tell you that I
showed Ellen my ring?  She thinks it the most beautiful setting she
ever saw.  There's nothing like it in the rue de la Paix, she said.  I
do love you, Newland, for being so artistic!"]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: Sameness--sameness!
subQuotationList: ['Sameness--sameness!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What learned things you read!
subQuotationList: ['What learned things you read!']
speaker: Janey Archer
referringExpression: She glanced at the writingtable heaped with books opened a volume of the Contes Drolatiques made a wry face over the archaic French and sighed

quoteText: Well--?
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Mother's very angry.
subQuotationList: ["Mother's very angry."]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Angry?  With whom?  About what?
subQuotationList: ['Angry?  With whom?  About what?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Miss Sophy Jackson has just been here.  She brought word that her
brother would come in after dinner: she couldn't say very much, because
he forbade her to: he wishes to give all the details himself.  He's
with cousin Louisa van der Luyden now.
subQuotationList:
["Miss Sophy Jackson has just been here.  She brought word that her
brother would come in after dinner: she couldn't say very much, because
he forbade her to: he wishes to give all the details himself.  He's
with cousin Louisa van der Luyden now."]
speaker: Janey Archer
mentionTextsList: [['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'She', ' her\nbrother', 'she', 'he', 'her', 'he', 'himself', 'He', 'cousin Louisa van der Luyden']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Sophy Jackson'], ['Miss Sophy Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Miss Sophy Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Miss Sophy Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
For heaven's sake, my dear girl, try a fresh start.  It would take an
omniscient Deity to know what you're talking about.
subQuotationList: ["For heaven's sake, my dear girl, try a fresh start.  It would take an\nomniscient Deity to know what you're talking about."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It's not a time to be profane, Newland....  Mother feels badly enough
about your not going to church ...
subQuotationList: ["It's not a time to be profane, Newland....  Mother feels badly enough\nabout your not going to church ..."]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText:
NEWLAND!  Do listen.  Your friend Madame Olenska was at Mrs. Lemuel
Struthers's party last night: she went there with the Duke and Mr.
Beaufort.
subQuotationList: ["NEWLAND!  Do listen.  Your friend Madame Olenska was at Mrs. Lemuel\nStruthers's party last night: she went there with the Duke and Mr.\nBeaufort."]
speaker: Janey Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Duke'], ['Julius Beaufort']]]

quoteText:
Well, what of it?  I
knew she meant to.
subQuotationList: ['Well, what of it?  I\nknew she meant to.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You knew she meant to--and
you didn't try to stop her?  To warn her?
subQuotationList: ["You knew she meant to--and\nyou didn't try to stop her?  To warn her?"]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Stop her?  Warn her?
subQuotationList: ['Stop her?  Warn her?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I'm not engaged to be
married to the Countess Olenska!
subQuotationList: ["I'm not engaged to be\nmarried to the Countess Olenska!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You're marrying into her family.
subQuotationList: ["You're marrying into her family."]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Oh, family--family!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, family--family!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Newland--don't you care about Family?
subQuotationList: ["Newland--don't you care about Family?"]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Not a brass farthing.
subQuotationList: ['Not a brass farthing.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Nor about what cousin Louisa van der Luyden will think?
subQuotationList: ['Nor about what cousin Louisa van der Luyden will think?']
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Not the half of one--if she thinks such old maid's rubbish.
subQuotationList: ["Not the half of one--if she thinks such old maid's rubbish."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Mother is not an old maid,
subQuotationList: ['Mother is not an old maid,']
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Hang Countess Olenska!  Don't be a goose, Janey--I'm not her keeper.
subQuotationList: ["Hang Countess Olenska!  Don't be a goose, Janey--I'm not her keeper."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No; but you DID ask the Wellands to announce your engagement sooner so
that we might all back her up; and if it hadn't been for that cousin
Louisa would never have invited her to the dinner for the Duke.
subQuotationList: ["No; but you DID ask the Wellands to announce your engagement sooner so\nthat we might all back her up; and if it hadn't been for that cousin\nLouisa would never have invited her to the dinner for the Duke."]
speaker: Janey Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Janey Archer', 'Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Duke']]]

quoteText:
Well--what harm was there in inviting her?  She was the best-looking
woman in the room; she made the dinner a little less funereal than the
usual van der Luyden banquet.
subQuotationList: ['Well--what harm was there in inviting her?  She was the best-looking\nwoman in the room; she made the dinner a little less funereal than the\nusual van der Luyden banquet.']
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
You know cousin Henry asked her to please you: he persuaded cousin
Louisa.  And now they're so upset that they're going back to
Skuytercliff tomorrow.  I think, Newland, you'd better come down.  You
don't seem to understand how mother feels.
subQuotationList:
["You know cousin Henry asked her to please you: he persuaded cousin
Louisa.  And now they're so upset that they're going back to
Skuytercliff tomorrow.  I think, Newland, you'd better come down.  You
don't seem to understand how mother feels."]
speaker: Janey Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Archer']]]

quoteText: Has Janey told you?
subQuotationList: ['Has Janey told you?']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: She raised a troubled brow from her needlework to ask

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
But I can't
take it very seriously.
subQuotationList: ["But I can't\ntake it very seriously."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Not the fact of having offended cousin Louisa and cousin Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Not the fact of having offended cousin Louisa and cousin Henry?']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
The fact that they can be offended by such a trifle as Countess
Olenska's going to the house of a woman they consider common.
subQuotationList: ["The fact that they can be offended by such a trifle as Countess\nOlenska's going to the house of a woman they consider common."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: Consider--!
subQuotationList: ['Consider--!']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
Well, who is; but who has good music, and amuses people on Sunday
evenings, when the whole of New York is dying of inanition.
subQuotationList: ['Well, who is; but who has good music, and amuses people on Sunday\nevenings, when the whole of New York is dying of inanition.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Good music?  All I know is, there was a woman who got up on a table
and sang the things they sing at the places you go to in Paris.  There
was smoking and champagne.
subQuotationList: ['Good music?  All I know is, there was a woman who got up on a table\nand sang the things they sing at the places you go to in Paris.  There\nwas smoking and champagne.']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
Well--that kind of thing happens in other places, and the world still
goes on.
subQuotationList: ['Well--that kind of thing happens in other places, and the world still\ngoes on.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I don't suppose, dear, you're really defending the French Sunday?
subQuotationList: ["I don't suppose, dear, you're really defending the French Sunday?"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
I've heard you often enough, mother, grumble at the English Sunday
when we've been in London.
subQuotationList: ["I've heard you often enough, mother, grumble at the English Sunday\nwhen we've been in London."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: New York is neither Paris nor London.
subQuotationList: ['New York is neither Paris nor London.']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: Oh, no, it's not!
subQuotationList: ["Oh, no, it's not!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You mean, I suppose, that society here is not as brilliant?  You're
right, I daresay; but we belong here, and people should respect our
ways when they come among us.  Ellen Olenska especially: she came back
to get away from the kind of life people lead in brilliant societies.
subQuotationList:
["You mean, I suppose, that society here is not as brilliant?  You're
right, I daresay; but we belong here, and people should respect our
ways when they come among us.  Ellen Olenska especially: she came back
to get away from the kind of life people lead in brilliant societies."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Janey Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Newland Archer'], ['Janey Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Newland Archer'], ['Janey Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
I was
going to put on my bonnet and ask you to take me to see cousin Louisa
for a moment before dinner.
subQuotationList: ['I was\ngoing to put on my bonnet and ask you to take me to see cousin Louisa\nfor a moment before dinner.']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
I thought
you might explain to her what you've just said: that society abroad is
different ... that people are not as particular, and that Madame
Olenska may not have realised how we feel about such things.  It would
be, you know, dear,
subQuotationList:
["I thought
you might explain to her what you've just said: that society abroad is
different ... that people are not as particular, and that Madame
Olenska may not have realised how we feel about such things.  It would
be, you know, dear,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
in Madame
Olenska's interest if you did.
subQuotationList: ["in Madame\nOlenska's interest if you did."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
Dearest mother, I really don't see how we're concerned in the matter.
The Duke took Madame Olenska to Mrs. Struthers's--in fact he brought
Mrs. Struthers to call on her.  I was there when they came.  If the van
der Luydens want to quarrel with anybody, the real culprit is under
their own roof.
subQuotationList:
["Dearest mother, I really don't see how we're concerned in the matter.
The Duke took Madame Olenska to Mrs. Struthers's--in fact he brought
Mrs. Struthers to call on her.  I was there when they came.  If the van
der Luydens want to quarrel with anybody, the real culprit is under
their own roof."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['The Duke'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['The Duke'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Duke'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
Quarrel?  Newland, did you ever know of cousin Henry's quarrelling?
Besides, the Duke's his guest; and a stranger too.  Strangers don't
discriminate: how should they?  Countess Olenska is a New Yorker, and
should have respected the feelings of New York.
subQuotationList:
["Quarrel?  Newland, did you ever know of cousin Henry's quarrelling?
Besides, the Duke's his guest; and a stranger too.  Strangers don't
discriminate: how should they?  Countess Olenska is a New Yorker, and
should have respected the feelings of New York."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['The Duke'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]
