quoteText:
Well, then, if they must have a victim, you have my leave to throw
Madame Olenska to them, I don't see
myself--or you either--offering ourselves up to expiate her crimes.
subQuotationList: ['Well, then, if they must have a victim, you have my leave to throw\nMadame Olenska to them,', "I don't see\nmyself--or you either--offering ourselves up to expiate her crimes."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']], [['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Oh, of course you see only the Mingott side,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, of course you see only the Mingott side,']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: Mr. Henry van der Luyden.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Henry van der Luyden.']
speaker: The Butler
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']
referringExpression: The sad butler drew back the drawingroom portieres and announced

quoteText: Another lamp,
subQuotationList: ['Another lamp,']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: she cried to the retreating servant

quoteText: We were just talking about you, sir,
subQuotationList: ['We were just talking about you, sir,']
speaker: Newland Archer
addressees: ['Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: And the Countess Olenska.
subQuotationList: ['And the Countess Olenska.']
speaker: Newland Archer
addressees: ['Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText: Ah--a charming woman.  I have just been to see her,
subQuotationList: ['Ah--a charming woman.  I have just been to see her,']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden

quoteText:
She has a real gift for arranging flowers.  I had sent
her a few carnations from Skuytercliff, and I was astonished.  Instead
of massing them in big bunches as our head-gardener does, she had
scattered them about loosely, here and there ... I can't say how.  The
Duke had told me: he said:  'Go and see how cleverly she's arranged her
drawing-room.'  And she has.  I should really like to take Louisa to
see her, if the neighbourhood were not so--unpleasant.
subQuotationList:
["She has a real gift for arranging flowers.  I had sent
her a few carnations from Skuytercliff, and I was astonished.  Instead
of massing them in big bunches as our head-gardener does, she had
scattered them about loosely, here and there ... I can't say how.  The
Duke had told me: he said:  'Go and see how cleverly she's arranged her
drawing-room.'  And she has.  I should really like to take Louisa to
see her, if the neighbourhood were not so--unpleasant."]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
referringExpression: He sank into the chair laid his hat and gloves on the floor beside him in the oldfashioned way and went on
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Duke'], ['The Duke'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
The fact is, the fact is, I dropped in to thank her for the very pretty note she
wrote me about my flowers; and also--but this is between ourselves, of
course--to give her a friendly warning about allowing the Duke to carry
her off to parties with him.  I don't know if you've heard--
subQuotationList:
['The fact is,', "the fact is, I dropped in to thank her for the very pretty note she
wrote me about my flowers; and also--but this is between ourselves, of
course--to give her a friendly warning about allowing the Duke to carry
her off to parties with him.  I don't know if you've heard--"]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Duke'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Duke'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer']]]

quoteText:
Has the Duke been carrying
her off to parties?
subQuotationList: ['Has the Duke been carrying\nher off to parties?']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
You know what these English grandees are.  They're all alike.  Louisa
and I are very fond of our cousin--but it's hopeless to expect people
who are accustomed to the European courts to trouble themselves about
our little republican distinctions.  The Duke goes where he's amused.
subQuotationList:
["You know what these English grandees are.  They're all alike.  Louisa
and I are very fond of our cousin--but it's hopeless to expect people
who are accustomed to the European courts to trouble themselves about
our little republican distinctions.  The Duke goes where he's amused."]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['The Duke'], ['The Duke']]]

quoteText:
Yes--it seems he took
her with him last night to Mrs. Lemuel Struthers's.  Sillerton Jackson
has just been to us with the foolish story, and Louisa was rather
troubled.  So I thought the shortest way was to go straight to Countess
Olenska and explain--by the merest hint, you know--how we feel in New
York about certain things.  I felt I might, without indelicacy, because
the evening she dined with us she rather suggested ... rather let me
see that she would be grateful for guidance.  And she WAS.
subQuotationList:
["Yes--it seems he took
her with him last night to Mrs. Lemuel Struthers's.  Sillerton Jackson
has just been to us with the foolish story, and Louisa was rather
troubled.  So I thought the shortest way was to go straight to Countess
Olenska and explain--by the merest hint, you know--how we feel in New
York about certain things.  I felt I might, without indelicacy, because
the evening she dined with us she rather suggested ... rather let me
see that she would be grateful for guidance.  And she WAS."]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Duke'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Duke'], ['Mrs. Struthers'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
How kind you both are, dear Henry--always!  Newland will particularly
appreciate what you have done because of dear May and his new
relations.
subQuotationList: ['How kind you both are, dear Henry--always!  Newland will particularly\nappreciate what you have done because of dear May and his new\nrelations.']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
Immensely, sir.
But I was sure you'd like Madame Olenska.
subQuotationList: ["Immensely, sir.\nBut I was sure you'd like Madame Olenska."]
speaker: Newland Archer
addressees: ['Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
I never ask
to my house, my dear Newland, any one whom I do not like.
And so I have just told Sillerton Jackson.
subQuotationList: ['I never ask\nto my house, my dear Newland,', 'any one whom I do not like.\nAnd so I have just told Sillerton Jackson.']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden

quoteText:
But Louisa will be waiting.  We are dining early,
to take the Duke to the Opera.
subQuotationList: ['But Louisa will be waiting.  We are dining early,\nto take the Duke to the Opera.']
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['The Duke']]]

quoteText: Gracious--how romantic!
subQuotationList: ['Gracious--how romantic!']
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText:
Provided it all turns out for
the best, Newland, you must stay and see Sillerton Jackson when he comes
this evening: I really shan't know what to say to him.
subQuotationList: ['Provided it all turns out for\nthe best,', "Newland, you must stay and see Sillerton Jackson when he comes\nthis evening: I really shan't know what to say to him."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson']]]

quoteText: Poor mother!  But he won't come--
subQuotationList: ["Poor mother!  But he won't come--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
My dear sir-- I have sent for
you to go into a little matter; a matter which, for the moment, I
prefer not to mention either to Mr. Skipworth or Mr. Redwood.
subQuotationList: ['My dear sir--', 'I have sent for\nyou to go into a little matter; a matter which, for the moment, I\nprefer not to mention either to Mr. Skipworth or Mr. Redwood.']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText:
For family
reasons--
subQuotationList: ['For family\nreasons--']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText:
The Mingott family, Mrs. Manson Mingott sent for me yesterday.  Her
grand-daughter the Countess Olenska wishes to sue her husband for
divorce.  Certain papers have been placed in my hands. In view of your prospective alliance with the
family I should like to consult you--to consider the case with
you--before taking any farther steps.
subQuotationList:
['The Mingott family,', 'Mrs. Manson Mingott sent for me yesterday.  Her
grand-daughter the Countess Olenska wishes to sue her husband for
divorce.  Certain papers have been placed in my hands.', 'In view of your prospective alliance with the
family I should like to consult you--to consider the case with
you--before taking any farther steps.']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska']], [['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
If you will run your eye over these
papers--
subQuotationList: ['If you will run your eye over these\npapers--']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, sir; but just because of the
prospective relationship, I should prefer your consulting Mr. Skipworth
or Mr. Redwood.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon, sir; but just because of the\nprospective relationship, I should prefer your consulting Mr. Skipworth\nor Mr. Redwood.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I respect your scruple, sir; but in this case I believe
true delicacy requires you to do as I ask.  Indeed, the suggestion is
not mine but Mrs. Manson Mingott's and her son's.  I have seen Lovell
Mingott; and also Mr. Welland.  They all named you.
subQuotationList:
["I respect your scruple, sir; but in this case I believe
true delicacy requires you to do as I ask.  Indeed, the suggestion is
not mine but Mrs. Manson Mingott's and her son's.  I have seen Lovell
Mingott; and also Mr. Welland.  They all named you."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Mr. Welland'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Welland', 'Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: Her uncles ought to deal with this,
subQuotationList: ['Her uncles ought to deal with this,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
They have.  The matter has been gone into by the family.  They are
opposed to the Countess's idea; but she is firm, and insists on a legal
opinion.
subQuotationList: ["They have.  The matter has been gone into by the family.  They are\nopposed to the Countess's idea; but she is firm, and insists on a legal\nopinion."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: Does she want to marry again?
subQuotationList: ['Does she want to marry again?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I believe it is suggested; but she denies it.
subQuotationList: ['I believe it is suggested; but she denies it.']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: Then--
subQuotationList: ['Then--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Will you oblige me, Mr. Archer, by first looking through these papers?
Afterward, when we have talked the case over, I will give you my
opinion.
subQuotationList: ['Will you oblige me, Mr. Archer, by first looking through these papers?\nAfterward, when we have talked the case over, I will give you my\nopinion.']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText:
You know, when it comes to the point, your parents have always let you
have your way ever since you were a little girl,
subQuotationList: ['You know, when it comes to the point, your parents have always let you\nhave your way ever since you were a little girl,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes; and that's what makes it
so hard to refuse the very last thing they'll ever ask of me as a
little girl.
subQuotationList: ["Yes; and that's what makes it\nso hard to refuse the very last thing they'll ever ask of me as a\nlittle girl."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Here are the letters, sir.  If you wish, I'll see Madame Olenska,
subQuotationList: ["Here are the letters, sir.  If you wish, I'll see Madame Olenska,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Thank you--thank you, Mr. Archer.  Come and dine with me tonight if
you're free, and we'll go into the matter afterward: in case you wish
to call on our client tomorrow.
subQuotationList: ["Thank you--thank you, Mr. Archer.  Come and dine with me tonight if\nyou're free, and we'll go into the matter afterward: in case you wish\nto call on our client tomorrow."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'Mr. Letterblair'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: Are we only Pharisees after all?
subQuotationList: ['Are we only Pharisees after all?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
The
whole family are against a divorce.  And I think rightly.
subQuotationList: ['The\nwhole family are against a divorce.  And I think rightly.']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair
referringExpression: Mr Letterblair leaning back in his chair and pushing the port westward said

quoteText:
But
why, sir?  If there ever was a case--
subQuotationList: ['But\nwhy, sir?  If there ever was a case--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well--what's the use?  SHE'S here--he's there; the Atlantic's between
them.  She'll never get back a dollar more of her money than what he's
voluntarily returned to her: their damned heathen marriage settlements
take precious good care of that.  As things go over there, Olenski's
acted generously: he might have turned her out without a penny.
subQuotationList:
["Well--what's the use?  SHE'S here--he's there; the Atlantic's between
them.  She'll never get back a dollar more of her money than what he's
voluntarily returned to her: their damned heathen marriage settlements
take precious good care of that.  As things go over there, Olenski's
acted generously: he might have turned her out without a penny."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
I understand, though, that she attaches
no importance to the money.  Therefore, as the family say, why not let
well enough alone?
subQuotationList: ['I understand, though,', 'that she attaches\nno importance to the money.  Therefore, as the family say, why not let\nwell enough alone?']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: I think that's for her to decide.
subQuotationList: ["I think that's for her to decide."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: H'm--have you considered the consequences if she decides for divorce?
subQuotationList: ["H'm--have you considered the consequences if she decides for divorce?"]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText:
You mean the threat in her husband's letter?  What weight would that
carry?  It's no more than the vague charge of an angry blackguard.
subQuotationList: ["You mean the threat in her husband's letter?  What weight would that\ncarry?  It's no more than the vague charge of an angry blackguard."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes; but it might make some unpleasant talk if he really defends the
suit.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; but it might make some unpleasant talk if he really defends the\nsuit.']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: Unpleasant--!
subQuotationList: ['Unpleasant--!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Divorce is
always unpleasant.
subQuotationList: ['Divorce is\nalways unpleasant.']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: You agree with me?
subQuotationList: ['You agree with me?']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: Naturally,
subQuotationList: ['Naturally,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well, then, I may count on you; the Mingotts may count on you; to use
your influence against the idea?
subQuotationList: ['Well, then, I may count on you; the Mingotts may count on you; to use\nyour influence against the idea?']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
I can't pledge myself till I've seen the Countess
Olenska,
subQuotationList: ["I can't pledge myself till I've seen the Countess\nOlenska,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Mr. Archer, I don't understand you.  Do you want to marry into a
family with a scandalous divorce-suit hanging over it?
subQuotationList: ["Mr. Archer, I don't understand you.  Do you want to marry into a\nfamily with a scandalous divorce-suit hanging over it?"]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: I don't think that has anything to do with the case.
subQuotationList: ["I don't think that has anything to do with the case."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You may be sure, sir, that I shan't commit myself till I've reported
to you; what I meant was that I'd rather not give an opinion till I've
heard what Madame Olenska has to say.
subQuotationList: ["You may be sure, sir, that I shan't commit myself till I've reported\nto you; what I meant was that I'd rather not give an opinion till I've\nheard what Madame Olenska has to say."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
When I was a girl, we knew everybody
between the Battery and Canal Street; and only the people one knew had
carriages.  It was perfectly easy to place any one then; now one can't
tell, and I prefer not to try.
subQuotationList:
['When I was a girl,', "we knew everybody
between the Battery and Canal Street; and only the people one knew had
carriages.  It was perfectly easy to place any one then; now one can't
tell, and I prefer not to try."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
Lord love us--three whole days at Skuytercliff! You'd better take all
your furs, and a hot-water-bottle.
subQuotationList: ['Lord love us--three whole days at Skuytercliff!', "You'd better take all\nyour furs, and a hot-water-bottle."]
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText: Why?  Is the house so cold?
subQuotationList: ['Why?  Is the house so cold?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: No; but the missus is,
subQuotationList: ['No; but the missus is,']
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
But I thought her so kind.  She came herself to invite me. Granny says
I must certainly go.
subQuotationList: ['But I thought her so kind.  She came herself to invite me. Granny says\nI must certainly go.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Granny would, of course.  And I say it's a shame you're going to miss
the little oyster supper I'd planned for you at Delmonico's next
Sunday, with Campanini and Scalchi and a lot of jolly people.
subQuotationList: ["Granny would, of course.  And I say it's a shame you're going to miss\nthe little oyster supper I'd planned for you at Delmonico's next\nSunday, with Campanini and Scalchi and a lot of jolly people."]
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
Ah--that does tempt me!  Except the other evening at Mrs. Struthers's
I've not met a single artist since I've been here.
subQuotationList: ["Ah--that does tempt me!  Except the other evening at Mrs. Struthers's\nI've not met a single artist since I've been here."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
What kind of artists?  I know one or two painters, very good fellows,
that I could bring to see you if you'd allow me,
subQuotationList: ["What kind of artists?  I know one or two painters, very good fellows,\nthat I could bring to see you if you'd allow me,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Painters?  Are there painters in New York?
subQuotationList: ['Painters?  Are there painters in New York?']
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
That would
be charming.  But I was really thinking of dramatic artists, singers,
actors, musicians.  My husband's house was always full of them.
subQuotationList: ["That would\nbe charming.  But I was really thinking of dramatic artists, singers,\nactors, musicians.  My husband's house was always full of them."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I do think, that the imprevu adds
to one's enjoyment.  It's perhaps a mistake to see the same people
every day.
subQuotationList: ['I do think,', "that the imprevu adds\nto one's enjoyment.  It's perhaps a mistake to see the same people\nevery day."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
It's confoundedly dull, anyhow; New York is dying of dullness, And when I try to liven it up for you, you go back
on me.  Come--think better of it!  Sunday is your last chance, for
Campanini leaves next week for Baltimore and Philadelphia; and I've a
private room, and a Steinway, and they'll sing all night for me.
subQuotationList:
["It's confoundedly dull, anyhow; New York is dying of dullness,", "And when I try to liven it up for you, you go back
on me.  Come--think better of it!  Sunday is your last chance, for
Campanini leaves next week for Baltimore and Philadelphia; and I've a
private room, and a Steinway, and they'll sing all night for me."]
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
How delicious!  May I think it over, and write to you tomorrow
morning?
subQuotationList: ['How delicious!  May I think it over, and write to you tomorrow\nmorning?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Why not now?
subQuotationList: ['Why not now?']
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText: It's too serious a question to decide at this late hour.
subQuotationList: ["It's too serious a question to decide at this late hour."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Do you call it late?
subQuotationList: ['Do you call it late?']
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
Yes; because I have still to talk
business with Mr. Archer for a little while.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; because I have still to talk\nbusiness with Mr. Archer for a little while.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Ah,
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
I say,
Newland, if you can persuade the Countess to stop in town of course
you're included in the supper,
subQuotationList: ["I say,\nNewland, if you can persuade the Countess to stop in town of course\nyou're included in the supper,"]
speaker: Julius Beaufort
referringExpression: he kissed with a practised air and calling out

quoteText: You know painters, then?  You live in their milieu?
subQuotationList: ['You know painters, then?  You live in their milieu?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Oh, not exactly.  I don't know that the arts have a milieu here, any
of them; they're more like a very thinly settled outskirt.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, not exactly.  I don't know that the arts have a milieu here, any\nof them; they're more like a very thinly settled outskirt."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: But you care for such things?
subQuotationList: ['But you care for such things?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Immensely.  When I'm in Paris or London I never miss an exhibition.  I
try to keep up.
subQuotationList: ["Immensely.  When I'm in Paris or London I never miss an exhibition.  I\ntry to keep up."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I used to care immensely too: my life was full of such things.  But
now I want to try not to.
subQuotationList: ['I used to care immensely too: my life was full of such things.  But\nnow I want to try not to.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You want to try not to?
subQuotationList: ['You want to try not to?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes: I want to cast off all my old life, to become just like everybody
else here.
subQuotationList: ['Yes: I want to cast off all my old life, to become just like everybody\nelse here.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You'll never be like everybody else,
subQuotationList: ["You'll never be like everybody else,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, don't say that.  If
you knew how I hate to be different!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, don't say that.  If\nyou knew how I hate to be different!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I want to get away from it all,
subQuotationList: ['I want to get away from it all,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I know.  Mr. Letterblair
has told me.
subQuotationList: ['I know.  Mr. Letterblair\nhas told me.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah?
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: That's the reason I've come.  He asked me to--you see I'm in the firm.
subQuotationList: ["That's the reason I've come.  He asked me to--you see I'm in the firm."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You mean
you can manage it for me?  I can talk to you instead of Mr.
Letterblair?  Oh, that will be so much easier!
subQuotationList: ['You mean\nyou can manage it for me?  I can talk to you instead of Mr.\nLetterblair?  Oh, that will be so much easier!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I am here to talk about it,
subQuotationList: ['I am here to talk about it,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Now we're coming to hard facts,
subQuotationList: ["Now we're coming to hard facts,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I
want to be free; I want to wipe out all the past.
subQuotationList: ['I\nwant to be free; I want to wipe out all the past.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I understand that.
subQuotationList: ['I understand that.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Then you'll help me?
subQuotationList: ["Then you'll help me?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: First-- perhaps I ought to know a little more.
subQuotationList: ['First--', 'perhaps I ought to know a little more.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You know about my husband--my life with him?
subQuotationList: ['You know about my husband--my life with him?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Well--then--what more is there?  In this country are such things
tolerated?  I'm a Protestant--our church does not forbid divorce in
such cases.
subQuotationList: ["Well--then--what more is there?  In this country are such things\ntolerated?  I'm a Protestant--our church does not forbid divorce in\nsuch cases."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Certainly not.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly not.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I've looked through the papers you gave to Mr. Letterblair,
subQuotationList: ["I've looked through the papers you gave to Mr. Letterblair,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well--can there be anything more abominable?
subQuotationList: ['Well--can there be anything more abominable?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: No.
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Of course you know, that if your husband chooses
to fight the case--as he threatens to--
subQuotationList: ['Of course you know,', 'that if your husband chooses\nto fight the case--as he threatens to--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes--?
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
He can say things--things that might be unpl--might be disagreeable to
you: say them publicly, so that they would get about, and harm you even
if--
subQuotationList: ['He can say things--things that might be unpl--might be disagreeable to\nyou: say them publicly, so that they would get about, and harm you even\nif--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: If--?
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I mean: no matter how unfounded they were.
subQuotationList: ['I mean: no matter how unfounded they were.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
What harm could such accusations, even if he made them publicly, do me
here?
subQuotationList: ['What harm could such accusations, even if he made them publicly, do me\nhere?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
New York society is a very small world
compared with the one you've lived in.  And it's ruled, in spite of
appearances, by a few people with--well, rather old-fashioned ideas.
subQuotationList: ["New York society is a very small world\ncompared with the one you've lived in.  And it's ruled, in spite of\nappearances, by a few people with--well, rather old-fashioned ideas."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Our ideas about marriage and
divorce are particularly old-fashioned.  Our legislation favours
divorce--our social customs don't.
subQuotationList: ["Our ideas about marriage and\ndivorce are particularly old-fashioned.  Our legislation favours\ndivorce--our social customs don't."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Never?
subQuotationList: ['Never?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Well--not if the woman, however injured, however irreproachable, has
appearances in the least degree against her, has exposed herself by any
unconventional action to--to offensive insinuations--
subQuotationList: ['Well--not if the woman, however injured, however irreproachable, has\nappearances in the least degree against her, has exposed herself by any\nunconventional action to--to offensive insinuations--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes, that's what my family tell me.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', "that's what my family tell me."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: It's not unnatural--
subQuotationList: ["It's not unnatural--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: OUR family,
subQuotationList: ['OUR family,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
For you'll
be my cousin soon,
subQuotationList: ["For you'll\nbe my cousin soon,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I hope so.
subQuotationList: ['I hope so.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: And you take their view?
subQuotationList: ['And you take their view?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Sincerely--
subQuotationList: ['Sincerely--']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Sincerely, then--what should you gain
that would compensate for the possibility--the certainty--of a lot of
beastly talk?
subQuotationList: ['Sincerely, then--what should you gain\nthat would compensate for the possibility--the certainty--of a lot of\nbeastly talk?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: But my freedom--is that nothing?
subQuotationList: ['But my freedom--is that nothing?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
But aren't you as free as air as it is? Who can
touch you?  Mr. Letterblair tells me the financial question has been
settled--
subQuotationList: ["But aren't you as free as air as it is?", 'Who can\ntouch you?  Mr. Letterblair tells me the financial question has been\nsettled--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, yes,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Well, then: is it worth while to risk what may be infinitely
disagreeable and painful?  Think of the newspapers--their vileness!
It's all stupid and narrow and unjust--but one can't make over society.
subQuotationList: ["Well, then: is it worth while to risk what may be infinitely\ndisagreeable and painful?  Think of the newspapers--their vileness!\nIt's all stupid and narrow and unjust--but one can't make over society."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No,
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
The individual, in such cases, is nearly always sacrificed to what is
supposed to be the collective interest: people cling to any convention
that keeps the family together--protects the children, if there are
any,
subQuotationList:
['The individual, in such cases, is nearly always sacrificed to what is
supposed to be the collective interest: people cling to any convention
that keeps the family together--protects the children, if there are
any,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It's my business, you know, to help you to see these
things as the people who are fondest of you see them.  The Mingotts,
the Wellands, the van der Luydens, all your friends and relations: if I
didn't show you honestly how they judge such questions, it wouldn't be
fair of me, would it?
subQuotationList:
["It's my business, you know,", "to help you to see these
things as the people who are fondest of you see them.  The Mingotts,
the Wellands, the van der Luydens, all your friends and relations: if I
didn't show you honestly how they judge such questions, it wouldn't be
fair of me, would it?"]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska']], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Welland', 'Mr. Welland'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Welland', 'Mr. Welland', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: No; it wouldn't be fair.
subQuotationList: ["No; it wouldn't be fair."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Very well; I will do what you wish,
subQuotationList: ['Very well; I will do what you wish,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I--I do want to help you,
subQuotationList: ['I--I do want to help you,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You do help me.  Good night, my cousin.
subQuotationList: ['You do help me.  Good night, my cousin.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Silly goose!  I told her myself what nonsense it
was.  Wanting to pass herself off as Ellen Mingott and an old maid,
when she has the luck to be a married woman and a Countess!
subQuotationList: ['Silly goose!  I told her myself what nonsense it\nwas.  Wanting to pass herself off as Ellen Mingott and an old maid,\nwhen she has the luck to be a married woman and a Countess!']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
referringExpression: Mrs Mingott who had summoned him for a confidential interview had congratulated him on his cleverness and added

quoteText:
Do you think, he will send her
a bunch of yellow roses tomorrow morning?
subQuotationList: ['Do you think,', 'he will send her\na bunch of yellow roses tomorrow morning?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I was thinking of that too--I was going to leave the theatre in order
to take the picture away with me,
subQuotationList: ['I was thinking of that too--I was going to leave the theatre in order\nto take the picture away with me,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What do you do while May is away?
subQuotationList: ['What do you do while May is away?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: She looked down at the motherofpearl operaglass in her smoothly gloved hands and said

quoteText: I stick to my work,
subQuotationList: ['I stick to my work,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I have done what you wished--what you advised,
subQuotationList: ['I have done what you wished--what you advised,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Ah--I'm glad,
subQuotationList: ["Ah--I'm glad,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I understand--that you were right, but sometimes life is difficult ...  perplexing...
subQuotationList: ['I understand--that you were right,', 'but sometimes life is difficult ...  perplexing...']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I know.
subQuotationList: ['I know.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
And I wanted to tell you that I DO feel you were right; and that I'm
grateful to you,
subQuotationList: ["And I wanted to tell you that I DO feel you were right; and that I'm\ngrateful to you,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Oh,
well so have I for that matter, and I'll be the Industrious Apprentice
too. Look here,
what I'm really after is the name of the dark lady in that swell box of
yours--with the Beauforts, wasn't she?  The one your friend Lefferts
seems so smitten by.
subQuotationList:
["Oh,
well so have I for that matter, and I'll be the Industrious Apprentice
too.", "Look here,
what I'm really after is the name of the dark lady in that swell box of
yours--with the Beauforts, wasn't she?  The one your friend Lefferts
seems so smitten by."]
speaker: Ned Winsett
mentionTextsList: [[], [' the name of the dark lady in that swell box of\nyours', 'the Beauforts', 'she', 'Lefferts']]

quoteText: It's not for an interview, I hope?
subQuotationList: ["It's not for an interview, I hope?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well--not for the press; just for myself, The
fact is she's a neighbour of mine--queer quarter for such a beauty to
settle in--and she's been awfully kind to my little boy, who fell down
her area chasing his kitten, and gave himself a nasty cut.  She rushed
in bareheaded, carrying him in her arms, with his knee all beautifully
bandaged, and was so sympathetic and beautiful that my wife was too
dazzled to ask her name.
subQuotationList:
['Well--not for the press; just for myself,', "The
fact is she's a neighbour of mine--queer quarter for such a beauty to
settle in--and she's been awfully kind to my little boy, who fell down
her area chasing his kitten, and gave himself a nasty cut.  She rushed
in bareheaded, carrying him in her arms, with his knee all beautifully
bandaged, and was so sympathetic and beautiful that my wife was too
dazzled to ask her name."]
speaker: Ned Winsett
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: That is the Countess Olenska--a granddaughter of old Mrs. Mingott's.
subQuotationList: ["That is the Countess Olenska--a granddaughter of old Mrs. Mingott's."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Whew--a Countess! Well, I didn't know
Countesses were so neighbourly.  Mingotts ain't.
subQuotationList: ['Whew--a Countess!', "Well, I didn't know\nCountesses were so neighbourly.  Mingotts ain't."]
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText: They would be, if you'd let them.
subQuotationList: ["They would be, if you'd let them."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Old Mrs. Mingott'], ['Ned Winsett'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Old Mrs. Mingott']]]

quoteText: Ah, well--
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well--']
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText:
I wonder, how a Countess happens to live in our
slum?
subQuotationList: ['I wonder,', 'how a Countess happens to live in our\nslum?']
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText:
Because she doesn't care a hang about where she lives--or about any of
our little social sign-posts,
subQuotationList: ["Because she doesn't care a hang about where she lives--or about any of\nour little social sign-posts,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
H'm--been in bigger places, I suppose, Well,
here's my corner.
subQuotationList: ["H'm--been in bigger places, I suppose,", "Well,\nhere's my corner."]
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText:
The fact is, life isn't much a fit for either of us, I'm down and out; nothing to be done about it.  I've got only
one ware to produce, and there's no market for it here, and won't be in
my time.  But you're free and you're well-off.  Why don't you get into
touch?  There's only one way to do it: to go into politics.
subQuotationList:
["The fact is, life isn't much a fit for either of us,", "I'm down and out; nothing to be done about it.  I've got only
one ware to produce, and there's no market for it here, and won't be in
my time.  But you're free and you're well-off.  Why don't you get into
touch?  There's only one way to do it: to go into politics."]
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText:
Look at
the career of the honest man in American politics!  They don't want us.
subQuotationList: ["Look at\nthe career of the honest man in American politics!  They don't want us."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Who's 'they'?  Why don't you all get together and be 'they'
yourselves?
subQuotationList: ["Who's 'they'?  Why don't you all get together and be 'they'\nyourselves?"]
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText:
Culture!  Yes--if we had it!  But there are just a few little local
patches, dying out here and there for lack of--well, hoeing and
cross-fertilising: the last remnants of the old European tradition that
your forebears brought with them.  But you're in a pitiful little
minority: you've got no centre, no competition, no audience.  You're
like the pictures on the walls of a deserted house:  'The Portrait of a
Gentleman.'  You'll never amount to anything, any of you, till you roll
up your sleeves and get right down into the muck.  That, or emigrate
... God!  If I could emigrate ...
subQuotationList:
["Culture!  Yes--if we had it!  But there are just a few little local
patches, dying out here and there for lack of--well, hoeing and
cross-fertilising: the last remnants of the old European tradition that
your forebears brought with them.  But you're in a pitiful little
minority: you've got no centre, no competition, no audience.  You're
like the pictures on the walls of a deserted house:  'The Portrait of a
Gentleman.'  You'll never amount to anything, any of you, till you roll
up your sleeves and get right down into the muck.  That, or emigrate
... God!  If I could emigrate ..."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Mr. van der Luyden, is in, sir; but my
impression is that he is either finishing his nap or else reading
yesterday's Evening Post.  I heard him say, sir, on his return from
church this morning, that he intended to look through the Evening Post
after luncheon; if you like, sir, I might go to the library door and
listen--
subQuotationList:
['Mr. van der Luyden,', "is in, sir; but my
impression is that he is either finishing his nap or else reading
yesterday's Evening Post.  I heard him say, sir, on his return from
church this morning, that he intended to look through the Evening Post
after luncheon; if you like, sir, I might go to the library door and
listen--"]
speaker: The Butler
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden']], [['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: Ah, you've come!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, you've come!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I came to
see what you were running away from.
subQuotationList: ['I came to\nsee what you were running away from.']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: he took her hand and answered

quoteText:
Ah, well--you will see,
presently.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well--you will see,\npresently.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Why--do you mean that you've been overtaken?
subQuotationList: ["Why--do you mean that you've been overtaken?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Shall we walk on?  I'm so cold after the
sermon.  And what does it matter, now you're here to protect me?
subQuotationList: ["Shall we walk on?  I'm so cold after the\nsermon.  And what does it matter, now you're here to protect me?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: She shrugged her shoulders with a little movement like Nastasias and rejoined

quoteText: Ellen--what is it?  You must tell me.
subQuotationList: ['Ellen--what is it?  You must tell me.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, presently--let's run a race first: my feet are freezing to the
ground,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, presently--let's run a race first: my feet are freezing to the\nground,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I knew you'd come!
subQuotationList: ["I knew you'd come!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: That shows you wanted me to,
subQuotationList: ['That shows you wanted me to,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Where did you come from?
subQuotationList: ['Where did you come from?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: It was because I got your note.
subQuotationList: ['It was because I got your note.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: May asked you to take care of me.
subQuotationList: ['May asked you to take care of me.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I didn't need any asking.
subQuotationList: ["I didn't need any asking."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You mean--I'm so evidently helpless and defenceless?  What a poor
thing you must all think me!  But women here seem not--seem never to
feel the need: any more than the blessed in heaven.
subQuotationList: ["You mean--I'm so evidently helpless and defenceless?  What a poor\nthing you must all think me!  But women here seem not--seem never to\nfeel the need: any more than the blessed in heaven."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: What sort of a need?
subQuotationList: ['What sort of a need?']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: He lowered his voice to ask

quoteText: Ah, don't ask me!  I don't speak your language,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, don't ask me!  I don't speak your language,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: What did I come for, if I don't speak yours?
subQuotationList: ["What did I come for, if I don't speak yours?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, my friend--!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my friend--!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Ellen--why won't you tell me what's happened?
subQuotationList: ["Ellen--why won't you tell me what's happened?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Does anything ever happen in heaven?
subQuotationList: ['Does anything ever happen in heaven?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I will tell you--but where, where, where?
One can't be alone for a minute in that great seminary of a house, with
all the doors wide open, and always a servant bringing tea, or a log
for the fire, or the newspaper!  Is there nowhere in an American house
where one may be by one's self?  You're so shy, and yet you're so
public.  I always feel as if I were in the convent again--or on the
stage, before a dreadfully polite audience that never applauds.
subQuotationList:
["I will tell you--but where, where, where?
One can't be alone for a minute in that great seminary of a house, with
all the doors wide open, and always a servant bringing tea, or a log
for the fire, or the newspaper!  Is there nowhere in an American house
where one may be by one's self?  You're so shy, and yet you're so
public.  I always feel as if I were in the convent again--or on the
stage, before a dreadfully polite audience that never applauds."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Ah, you don't like us!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, you don't like us!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Why--the house is open!
subQuotationList: ['Why--the house is open!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No; only for today, at least.  I wanted to see it,
and Mr. van der Luyden had the fire lit and the windows opened, so that
we might stop there on the way back from church this morning.
subQuotationList: ['No; only for today, at least.  I wanted to see it,\nand Mr. van der Luyden had the fire lit and the windows opened, so that\nwe might stop there on the way back from church this morning.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
It's still unlocked--what luck!
Come in and we can have a quiet talk.  Mrs. van der Luyden has driven
over to see her old aunts at Rhinebeck and we shan't be missed at the
house for another hour.
subQuotationList:
["It's still unlocked--what luck!
Come in and we can have a quiet talk.  Mrs. van der Luyden has driven
over to see her old aunts at Rhinebeck and we shan't be missed at the
house for another hour."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: You're laughing now; but when you wrote me you were unhappy,
subQuotationList: ["You're laughing now; but when you wrote me you were unhappy,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes. But I can't feel unhappy when you're here.
subQuotationList: ['Yes.', "But I can't feel unhappy when you're here."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I sha'n't be here long,
subQuotationList: ["I sha'n't be here long,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No; I know.  But I'm improvident: I live in the moment when I'm happy.
subQuotationList: ["No; I know.  But I'm improvident: I live in the moment when I'm happy."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

subQuotationList: ["Ellen, if I'm really a help to you--if you really wanted me to\ncome--tell me what's wrong, tell me what it is you're running away\nfrom,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah--!
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: So that was it?
subQuotationList: ['So that was it?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I didn't know he was here,
subQuotationList: ["I didn't know he was here,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Hallo, Beaufort--this way!  Madame Olenska was expecting you,
subQuotationList: ['Hallo, Beaufort--this way!  Madame Olenska was expecting you,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
If only this new dodge for talking along a wire had been a little bit
nearer perfection I might have told you all this from town, and been
toasting my toes before the club fire at this minute, instead of
tramping after you through the snow,
subQuotationList:
['If only this new dodge for talking along a wire had been a little bit
nearer perfection I might have told you all this from town, and been
toasting my toes before the club fire at this minute, instead of
tramping after you through the snow,']
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText: Mercy, how pale you look, Newland!
subQuotationList: ['Mercy, how pale you look, Newland!']
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText:
Newland, dear, I've
noticed lately that you've been coughing; I do hope you're not letting
yourself be overworked?
subQuotationList: ["Newland, dear, I've\nnoticed lately that you've been coughing; I do hope you're not letting\nyourself be overworked?"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: Newland--has anything happened?
subQuotationList: ['Newland--has anything happened?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Yes--I found I had to see you,
subQuotationList: ['Yes--I found I had to see you,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What is it?
subQuotationList: ['What is it?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Nothing.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing.']
speaker: Miss Welland
referringExpression: she looked at him with surprise and answered

quoteText: Tell me what you do all day,
subQuotationList: ['Tell me what you do all day,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You see, my dear fellow, we camp--we
literally camp.  I tell my wife and May that I want to teach them how
to rough it.
subQuotationList: ['You see, my dear fellow, we camp--we\nliterally camp.  I tell my wife and May that I want to teach them how\nto rough it.']
speaker: Mr. Welland
referringExpression: Mr Welland beaming across a breakfast table miraculously supplied with the most varied delicacies was presently saying to Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Welland'], ['Mr. Welland'], ['Mrs. Welland'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland']]]

quoteText:
You can't be too careful, especially toward spring, If I'd only been as prudent at your age May would have been
dancing at the Assemblies now, instead of spending her winters in a
wilderness with an old invalid.
subQuotationList: ["You can't be too careful, especially toward spring,", "If I'd only been as prudent at your age May would have been\ndancing at the Assemblies now, instead of spending her winters in a\nwilderness with an old invalid."]
speaker: Mr. Welland

quoteText:
Oh, but I love it here, Papa; you know I do.  If only Newland could
stay I should like it a thousand times better than New York.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, but I love it here, Papa; you know I do.  If only Newland could\nstay I should like it a thousand times better than New York.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
But European society is not given to divorce: Countess Olenska thought
she would be conforming to American ideas in asking for her freedom.
subQuotationList: ['But European society is not given to divorce: Countess Olenska thought\nshe would be conforming to American ideas in asking for her freedom.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I'm always thinking of May,
subQuotationList: ["I'm always thinking of May,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
We might be seeing it all this spring--even the Easter ceremonies at
Seville,
subQuotationList: ['We might be seeing it all this spring--even the Easter ceremonies at\nSeville,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Easter in Seville?  And it will be Lent next week!
subQuotationList: ['Easter in Seville?  And it will be Lent next week!']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Why shouldn't we be married in Lent?
subQuotationList: ["Why shouldn't we be married in Lent?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Of course I didn't mean that, dearest; but soon after Easter--so that
we could sail at the end of April.  I know I could arrange it at the
office.
subQuotationList: ["Of course I didn't mean that, dearest; but soon after Easter--so that\nwe could sail at the end of April.  I know I could arrange it at the\noffice."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, do go on, Newland; I do love your descriptions.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, do go on, Newland; I do love your descriptions.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
But why should they be only descriptions?  Why shouldn't we make them
real?
subQuotationList: ["But why should they be only descriptions?  Why shouldn't we make them\nreal?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: We shall, dearest, of course; next year.
subQuotationList: ['We shall, dearest, of course; next year.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Don't you want them to be real sooner?  Can't I persuade you to break
away now?
subQuotationList: ["Don't you want them to be real sooner?  Can't I persuade you to break\naway now?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Why should we dream away another year?  Look at me, dear!  Don't you
understand how I want you for my wife?
subQuotationList: ["Why should we dream away another year?  Look at me, dear!  Don't you\nunderstand how I want you for my wife?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I'm not sure
if I DO understand, Is it--is it because you're not
certain of continuing to care for me?
subQuotationList: ["I'm not sure\nif I DO understand,", "Is it--is it because you're not\ncertain of continuing to care for me?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: My God--perhaps--I don't know,
subQuotationList: ["My God--perhaps--I don't know,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: If that is it--is there some one else?
subQuotationList: ['If that is it--is there some one else?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Some one else--between you and me?
subQuotationList: ['Some one else--between you and me?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Let us talk frankly,
Newland.  Sometimes I've felt a difference in you; especially since our
engagement has been announced.
subQuotationList: ["Let us talk frankly,\nNewland.  Sometimes I've felt a difference in you; especially since our\nengagement has been announced."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Dear--what madness!
subQuotationList: ['Dear--what madness!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
If it is, it won't hurt us to
talk about it.
subQuotationList: ["If it is, it won't hurt us to\ntalk about it."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Or even if it's true: why shouldn't we speak of
it?  You might so easily have made a mistake.
subQuotationList: ["Or even if it's true: why shouldn't we speak of\nit?  You might so easily have made a mistake."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Mistakes are always easy to make; but if I had
made one of the kind you suggest, is it likely that I should be
imploring you to hasten our marriage?
subQuotationList: ['Mistakes are always easy to make; but if I had\nmade one of the kind you suggest, is it likely that I should be\nimploring you to hasten our marriage?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes, You might want--once for all--to settle the question: it's
one way.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', "You might want--once for all--to settle the question: it's\none way."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Well--?
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You mustn't think that a
girl knows as little as her parents imagine.  One hears and one
notices--one has one's feelings and ideas.  And of course, long before
you told me that you cared for me, I'd known that there was some one
else you were interested in; every one was talking about it two years
ago at Newport.  And once I saw you sitting together on the verandah at
a dance--and when she came back into the house her face was sad, and I
felt sorry for her; I remembered it afterward, when we were engaged.
subQuotationList:
["You mustn't think that a
girl knows as little as her parents imagine.  One hears and one
notices--one has one's feelings and ideas.  And of course, long before
you told me that you cared for me, I'd known that there was some one
else you were interested in; every one was talking about it two years
ago at Newport.  And once I saw you sitting together on the verandah at
a dance--and when she came back into the house her face was sad, and I
felt sorry for her; I remembered it afterward, when we were engaged."]
speaker: Miss Welland
referringExpression: She dropped back into her seat and went on
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: My dear child--was THAT it?  If you only knew the truth!
subQuotationList: ['My dear child--was THAT it?  If you only knew the truth!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Then there is a truth I don't know?
subQuotationList: ["Then there is a truth I don't know?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I meant, the truth about the old story
you speak of.
subQuotationList: ['I meant, the truth about the old story\nyou speak of.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
But that's what I want to know, Newland--what I ought to know.  I
couldn't have my happiness made out of a wrong--an unfairness--to
somebody else.  And I want to believe that it would be the same with
you.  What sort of a life could we build on such foundations?
subQuotationList:
["But that's what I want to know, Newland--what I ought to know.  I
couldn't have my happiness made out of a wrong--an unfairness--to
somebody else.  And I want to believe that it would be the same with
you.  What sort of a life could we build on such foundations?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I've wanted to say this for a long
time, I've wanted to tell you that, when two people
really love each other, I understand that there may be situations which
make it right that they should--should go against public opinion.  And
if you feel yourself in any way pledged ... pledged to the person we've
spoken of ...  and if there is any way ... any way in which you can
fulfill your pledge ... even by her getting a divorce ...  Newland,
don't give her up because of me!
subQuotationList:
["I've wanted to say this for a long
time,", "I've wanted to tell you that, when two people
really love each other, I understand that there may be situations which
make it right that they should--should go against public opinion.  And
if you feel yourself in any way pledged ... pledged to the person we've
spoken of ...  and if there is any way ... any way in which you can
fulfill your pledge ... even by her getting a divorce ...  Newland,
don't give her up because of me!"]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
There is no pledge--no
obligation whatever--of the kind you think.  Such cases don't
always--present themselves quite as simply as ... But that's no matter
... I love your generosity, because I feel as you do about those things
... I feel that each case must be judged individually, on its own
merits ... irrespective of stupid conventionalities ... I mean, each
woman's right to her liberty--
subQuotationList:
["There is no pledge--no
obligation whatever--of the kind you think.  Such cases don't
always--present themselves quite as simply as ... But that's no matter
... I love your generosity, because I feel as you do about those things
... I feel that each case must be judged individually, on its own
merits ... irrespective of stupid conventionalities ... I mean, each
woman's right to her liberty--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Since you understand so many things, dearest, can't you go a little
farther, and understand the uselessness of our submitting to another
form of the same foolish conventionalities?  If there's no one and
nothing between us, isn't that an argument for marrying quickly, rather
than for more delay?
subQuotationList:
["Since you understand so many things, dearest, can't you go a little
farther, and understand the uselessness of our submitting to another
form of the same foolish conventionalities?  If there's no one and
nothing between us, isn't that an argument for marrying quickly, rather
than for more delay?"]
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: He pulled himself up startled by the turn his thoughts had taken and went on

quoteText: Your cousin the Countess called on mother while you were away,
subQuotationList: ['Your cousin the Countess called on mother while you were away,']
speaker: Janey Archer
referringExpression: Janey Archer announced to her brother
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
She had on a black velvet polonaise with jet buttons, and a tiny green
monkey muff; I never saw her so stylishly dressed, She came alone, early on Sunday afternoon; luckily the fire was lit in
the drawing-room.  She had one of those new card-cases.  She said she
wanted to know us because you'd been so good to her.
subQuotationList:
['She had on a black velvet polonaise with jet buttons, and a tiny green
monkey muff; I never saw her so stylishly dressed,', "She came alone, early on Sunday afternoon; luckily the fire was lit in
the drawing-room.  She had one of those new card-cases.  She said she
wanted to know us because you'd been so good to her."]
speaker: Janey Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Janey Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
Madame Olenska always takes that tone about her
friends.  She's very happy at being among her own people again.
subQuotationList: ["Madame Olenska always takes that tone about her\nfriends.  She's very happy at being among her own people again."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes, so she told us, I must say she seems
thankful to be here.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, so she told us,', 'I must say she seems\nthankful to be here.']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: I hope you liked her, mother.
subQuotationList: ['I hope you liked her, mother.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
She certainly lays herself out to
please, even when she is calling on an old lady.
subQuotationList: ['She certainly lays herself out to\nplease, even when she is calling on an old lady.']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: Mother doesn't think her simple,
subQuotationList: ["Mother doesn't think her simple,"]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: It's just my old-fashioned feeling; dear May is my ideal,
subQuotationList: ["It's just my old-fashioned feeling; dear May is my ideal,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText: Ah, they're not alike.
subQuotationList: ['Ah,', "they're not alike."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, ah--so you kicked over the traces, did you?  And I suppose Augusta
and Welland pulled long faces, and behaved as if the end of the world
had come?  But little May--she knew better, I'll be bound?
subQuotationList: ["Ah, ah--so you kicked over the traces, did you?  And I suppose Augusta\nand Welland pulled long faces, and behaved as if the end of the world\nhad come?  But little May--she knew better, I'll be bound?"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Welland'], ['Mr. Welland'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland']]]

quoteText:
I hoped she did; but after all she wouldn't agree to what I'd gone
down to ask for.
subQuotationList: ["I hoped she did; but after all she wouldn't agree to what I'd gone\ndown to ask for."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Wouldn't she indeed?  And what was that?
subQuotationList: ["Wouldn't she indeed?  And what was that?"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
I wanted to get her to promise that we should be married in April.
What's the use of our wasting another year?
subQuotationList: ["I wanted to get her to promise that we should be married in April.\nWhat's the use of our wasting another year?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
'Ask Mamma,' I
suppose--the usual story.  Ah, these Mingotts--all alike!  Born in a
rut, and you can't root 'em out of it.  When I built this house you'd
have thought I was moving to California!  Nobody ever HAD built above
Fortieth Street--no, says I, nor above the Battery either, before
Christopher Columbus discovered America.  No, no; not one of them wants
to be different; they're as scared of it as the small-pox.  Ah, my dear
Mr. Archer, I thank my stars I'm nothing but a vulgar Spicer; but
there's not one of my own children that takes after me but my little
Ellen.
subQuotationList:
["'Ask Mamma,' I
suppose--the usual story.  Ah, these Mingotts--all alike!  Born in a
rut, and you can't root 'em out of it.  When I built this house you'd
have thought I was moving to California!  Nobody ever HAD built above
Fortieth Street--no, says I, nor above the Battery either, before
Christopher Columbus discovered America.  No, no; not one of them wants
to be different; they're as scared of it as the small-pox.  Ah, my dear
Mr. Archer, I thank my stars I'm nothing but a vulgar Spicer; but
there's not one of my own children that takes after me but my little
Ellen."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Now, why in the world didn't you marry
my little Ellen?
subQuotationList: ["Now, why in the world didn't you marry\nmy little Ellen?"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
referringExpression: She broke off still twinkling at him and asked

quoteText: For one thing, she wasn't there to be married.
subQuotationList: ["For one thing, she wasn't there to be married."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No--to be sure; more's the pity.  And now it's too late; her life is
finished.
subQuotationList: ["No--to be sure; more's the pity.  And now it's too late; her life is\nfinished."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Can't I persuade you to use your
influence with the Wellands, Mrs. Mingott?  I wasn't made for long
engagements.
subQuotationList: ["Can't I persuade you to use your\ninfluence with the Wellands, Mrs. Mingott?  I wasn't made for long\nengagements."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Welland', 'Mr. Welland'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott']]]

quoteText:
No; I can see that.  You've
got a quick eye.  When you were a little boy I've no doubt you liked to
be helped first.
subQuotationList: ["No; I can see that.  You've\ngot a quick eye.  When you were a little boy I've no doubt you liked to\nbe helped first."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: Ah, here's my Ellen now!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, here's my Ellen now!"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
I was just saying to him, my dear:  'Now, why didn't you marry my
little Ellen?'
subQuotationList: ["I was just saying to him, my dear:  'Now, why didn't you marry my\nlittle Ellen?'"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
And what did he
answer?
subQuotationList: ['And what did he\nanswer?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Oh, my darling, I leave you to find that out!  He's been down to
Florida to see his sweetheart.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, my darling, I leave you to find that out!  He's been down to\nFlorida to see his sweetheart."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: Yes, I know.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I know.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I went to see your mother,
to ask where you'd gone.  I sent a note that you never answered, and I
was afraid you were ill.
subQuotationList: ["I went to see your mother,\nto ask where you'd gone.  I sent a note that you never answered, and I\nwas afraid you were ill."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: And of course once you were there you never thought of me again!
subQuotationList: ['And of course once you were there you never thought of me again!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: If she still needs me, she's determined not to let me see it,
subQuotationList: ["If she still needs me, she's determined not to let me see it,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Look at him--in such hot haste to get married that he took French
leave and rushed down to implore the silly girl on his knees!  That's
something like a lover--that's the way handsome Bob Spicer carried off
my poor mother; and then got tired of her before I was weaned--though
they only had to wait eight months for me!  But there--you're not a
Spicer, young man; luckily for you and for May.  It's only my poor
Ellen that has kept any of their wicked blood; the rest of them are all
model Mingotts,
subQuotationList:
["Look at him--in such hot haste to get married that he took French
leave and rushed down to implore the silly girl on his knees!  That's
something like a lover--that's the way handsome Bob Spicer carried off
my poor mother; and then got tired of her before I was weaned--though
they only had to wait eight months for me!  But there--you're not a
Spicer, young man; luckily for you and for May.  It's only my poor
Ellen that has kept any of their wicked blood; the rest of them are all
model Mingotts,"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['May Wellend'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['May Wellend'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Surely, Granny, we can persuade them between us to do as he wishes.
subQuotationList: ['Surely, Granny, we can persuade them between us to do as he wishes.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['May Wellend', 'Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: When can I see you?
subQuotationList: ['When can I see you?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Whenever you like; but it must be soon if you want to see the little
house again.  I am moving next week.
subQuotationList: ['Whenever you like; but it must be soon if you want to see the little\nhouse again.  I am moving next week.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Tomorrow evening?
subQuotationList: ['Tomorrow evening?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Tomorrow; yes; but early.  I'm going out.
subQuotationList: ["Tomorrow; yes; but early.  I'm going out."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Very well; tomorrow evening,
subQuotationList: ['Very well; tomorrow evening,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Gia!
speaker: Nastasia
referringExpression: Nastasia who raised hers in return

quoteText:
What they must have cost at this season--though of course it's the
sentiment one cares about!
subQuotationList: ["What they must have cost at this season--though of course it's the\nsentiment one cares about!"]
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
Dear Mr. Archer--almost my cousin Newland! I am the
Marchioness Manson.
subQuotationList: ['Dear Mr. Archer--almost my cousin Newland!', 'I am the\nMarchioness Manson.']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
My Ellen has taken me in for a few
days.  I came from Cuba, where I have been spending the winter with
Spanish friends--such delightful distinguished people: the highest
nobility of old Castile--how I wish you could know them!  But I was
called away by our dear great friend here, Dr. Carver.  You don't know
Dr. Agathon Carver, founder of the Valley of Love Community?
subQuotationList:
["My Ellen has taken me in for a few
days.  I came from Cuba, where I have been spending the winter with
Spanish friends--such delightful distinguished people: the highest
nobility of old Castile--how I wish you could know them!  But I was
called away by our dear great friend here, Dr. Carver.  You don't know
Dr. Agathon Carver, founder of the Valley of Love Community?"]
speaker: The Marchioness
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Dr. Carver']]]

quoteText:
Ah, New York--New York--how little the life of the spirit has reached
it!  But I see you do know Mr. Winsett.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, New York--New York--how little the life of the spirit has reached\nit!  But I see you do know Mr. Winsett.']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText: Oh, yes--I reached him some time ago; but not by that route,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes--I reached him some time ago; but not by that route,']
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText:
How do you know, Mr.
Winsett?  The spirit bloweth where it listeth.
subQuotationList: ['How do you know, Mr.\nWinsett?  The spirit bloweth where it listeth.']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText: List--oh, list!
subQuotationList: ['List--oh, list!']
speaker: Dr. Carver

quoteText:
But do sit down, Mr. Archer.  We four have been having a delightful
little dinner together, and my child has gone up to dress.  She expects
you; she will be down in a moment.  We were just admiring these
marvellous flowers, which will surprise her when she reappears.
subQuotationList:
['But do sit down, Mr. Archer.  We four have been having a delightful
little dinner together, and my child has gone up to dress.  She expects
you; she will be down in a moment.  We were just admiring these
marvellous flowers, which will surprise her when she reappears.']
speaker: The Marchioness
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Dr. Carver', 'Ned Winsett', 'The Marchioness'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Dr. Carver', 'Ned Winsett', 'The Marchioness'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
I'm afraid I must be off.  Please tell
Madame Olenska that we shall all feel lost when she abandons our
street.  This house has been an oasis.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid I must be off.  Please tell\nMadame Olenska that we shall all feel lost when she abandons our\nstreet.  This house has been an oasis."]
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText:
Ah, but she won't abandon YOU.  Poetry and art are the breath of life
to her.  It IS poetry you write, Mr. Winsett?
subQuotationList: ["Ah, but she won't abandon YOU.  Poetry and art are the breath of life\nto her.  It IS poetry you write, Mr. Winsett?"]
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText: Well, no; but I sometimes read it,
subQuotationList: ['Well, no; but I sometimes read it,']
speaker: Ned Winsett

quoteText:
A caustic spirit--un peu sauvage.  But so witty; Dr. Carver, you DO
think him witty?
subQuotationList: ['A caustic spirit--un peu sauvage.  But so witty; Dr. Carver, you DO\nthink him witty?']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText: I never think of wit,
subQuotationList: ['I never think of wit,']
speaker: Dr. Carver

quoteText:
Ah--ah--you never think of wit!  How merciless he is to us weak
mortals, Mr. Archer!  But he lives only in the life of the spirit; and
tonight he is mentally preparing the lecture he is to deliver presently
at Mrs. Blenker's.  Dr. Carver, would there be time, before you start
for the Blenkers' to explain to Mr. Archer your illuminating discovery
of the Direct Contact?  But no; I see it is nearly nine o'clock, and we
have no right to detain you while so many are waiting for your message.
subQuotationList:
["Ah--ah--you never think of wit!  How merciless he is to us weak
mortals, Mr. Archer!  But he lives only in the life of the spirit; and
tonight he is mentally preparing the lecture he is to deliver presently
at Mrs. Blenker's.  Dr. Carver, would there be time, before you start
for the Blenkers' to explain to Mr. Archer your illuminating discovery
of the Direct Contact?  But no; I see it is nearly nine o'clock, and we
have no right to detain you while so many are waiting for your message."]
speaker: The Marchioness
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr. Carver'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['Newland Archer', 'The Marchioness'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'The Marchioness'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['Dr. Carver']]]

quoteText: I shall see you later, dear friend?
subQuotationList: ['I shall see you later, dear friend?']
speaker: Dr. Carver

quoteText:
As soon as Ellen's carriage comes I will
join you; I do hope the lecture won't have begun.
subQuotationList: ["As soon as Ellen's carriage comes I will\njoin you; I do hope the lecture won't have begun."]
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
Perhaps, if this young
gentleman is interested in my experiences, Mrs. Blenker might allow you
to bring him with you?
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps, if this young\ngentleman is interested in my experiences, Mrs. Blenker might allow you\nto bring him with you?']
speaker: Dr. Carver

quoteText:
Oh, dear friend, if it were possible--I am sure she would be too
happy.  But I fear my Ellen counts on Mr. Archer herself.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, dear friend, if it were possible--I am sure she would be too\nhappy.  But I fear my Ellen counts on Mr. Archer herself.']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText: That, is unfortunate--but here is my card.
subQuotationList: ['That,', 'is unfortunate--but here is my card.']
speaker: Dr. Carver

quoteText:
Ellen will be down in a moment; and before she comes, I am so glad of
this quiet moment with you.
subQuotationList: ['Ellen will be down in a moment; and before she comes, I am so glad of\nthis quiet moment with you.']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
I know everything, dear Mr.
Archer--my child has told me all you have done for her.  Your wise
advice: your courageous firmness--thank heaven it was not too late!
subQuotationList: ['I know everything, dear Mr.\nArcher--my child has told me all you have done for her.  Your wise\nadvice: your courageous firmness--thank heaven it was not too late!']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
Madame Olenska exaggerates; I simply gave her a legal opinion, as she
asked me to.
subQuotationList: ['Madame Olenska exaggerates; I simply gave her a legal opinion, as she\nasked me to.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, but in doing it--in doing it you were the unconscious instrument
of--of--what word have we moderns for Providence, Mr. Archer? Little did you know that at that very moment I was
being appealed to: being approached, in fact--from the other side of
the Atlantic!
subQuotationList:
['Ah, but in doing it--in doing it you were the unconscious instrument
of--of--what word have we moderns for Providence, Mr. Archer?', 'Little did you know that at that very moment I was
being appealed to: being approached, in fact--from the other side of
the Atlantic!']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
By the Count himself--my poor, mad, foolish
Olenski; who asks only to take her back on her own terms.
subQuotationList: ['By the Count himself--my poor, mad, foolish\nOlenski; who asks only to take her back on her own terms.']
speaker: The Marchioness
