referringExpression: She glanced over her shoulder as though fearful of being overheard and then drawing her chair nearer and raising a tiny ivory fan to her lips breathed

quoteText: Good God!
subQuotationList: ['Good God!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You are horrified?  Yes, of course; I understand.  I don't defend poor
Stanislas, though he has always called me his best friend.  He does not
defend himself--he casts himself at her feet: in my person.
subQuotationList: ["You are horrified?  Yes, of course; I understand.  I don't defend poor\nStanislas, though he has always called me his best friend.  He does not\ndefend himself--he casts himself at her feet: in my person."]
speaker: The Marchioness
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski']]]

quoteText: I have his letter here.
subQuotationList: ['I have his letter here.']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText: A letter?--Has Madame Olenska seen it?
subQuotationList: ['A letter?--Has Madame Olenska seen it?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Time--time; I must have
time.  I know my Ellen--haughty, intractable; shall I say, just a shade
unforgiving?
subQuotationList: ['Time--time; I must have\ntime.  I know my Ellen--haughty, intractable; shall I say, just a shade\nunforgiving?']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
But, good heavens, to forgive is one thing; to go back into that
hell--
subQuotationList: ['But, good heavens, to forgive is one thing; to go back into that\nhell--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, yes, So she describes it--my
sensitive child!  But on the material side, Mr. Archer, if one may
stoop to consider such things; do you know what she is giving up?
Those roses there on the sofa--acres like them, under glass and in the
open, in his matchless terraced gardens at Nice!  Jewels--historic
pearls: the Sobieski emeralds--sables,--but she cares nothing for all
these!  Art and beauty, those she does care for, she lives for, as I
always have; and those also surrounded her.  Pictures, priceless
furniture, music, brilliant conversation--ah, that, my dear young man,
if you'll excuse me, is what you've no conception of here!  And she had
it all; and the homage of the greatest.  She tells me she is not
thought handsome in New York--good heavens!  Her portrait has been
painted nine times; the greatest artists in Europe have begged for the
privilege.  Are these things nothing?  And the remorse of an adoring
husband?
subQuotationList:
['Ah, yes,', "So she describes it--my
sensitive child!  But on the material side, Mr. Archer, if one may
stoop to consider such things; do you know what she is giving up?
Those roses there on the sofa--acres like them, under glass and in the
open, in his matchless terraced gardens at Nice!  Jewels--historic
pearls: the Sobieski emeralds--sables,--but she cares nothing for all
these!  Art and beauty, those she does care for, she lives for, as I
always have; and those also surrounded her.  Pictures, priceless
furniture, music, brilliant conversation--ah, that, my dear young man,
if you'll excuse me, is what you've no conception of here!  And she had
it all; and the homage of the greatest.  She tells me she is not
thought handsome in New York--good heavens!  Her portrait has been
painted nine times; the greatest artists in Europe have begged for the
privilege.  Are these things nothing?  And the remorse of an adoring
husband?"]
speaker: The Marchioness
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: She knows nothing yet--of all this?
subQuotationList: ['She knows nothing yet--of all this?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Nothing directly--but
does she suspect?  Who can tell?  The truth is, Mr. Archer, I have been
waiting to see you.  From the moment I heard of the firm stand you had
taken, and of your influence over her, I hoped it might be possible to
count on your support--to convince you ...
subQuotationList:
['Nothing directly--but
does she suspect?  Who can tell?  The truth is, Mr. Archer, I have been
waiting to see you.  From the moment I heard of the firm stand you had
taken, and of your influence over her, I hoped it might be possible to
count on your support--to convince you ...']
speaker: The Marchioness
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: That she ought to go back?  I would rather see her dead!
subQuotationList: ['That she ought to go back?  I would rather see her dead!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah,
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
Here she comes, Am I to understand that you prefer THAT, Mr.
Archer?  After all, marriage is marriage ... and my niece is still a
wife...
subQuotationList: ['Here she comes,', 'Am I to understand that you prefer THAT, Mr.\nArcher?  After all, marriage is marriage ... and my niece is still a\nwife...']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText: What are you two plotting together, aunt Medora?
subQuotationList: ['What are you two plotting together, aunt Medora?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
We were saying, my dear, that here was something beautiful to surprise
you with,
subQuotationList: ['We were saying, my dear, that here was something beautiful to surprise\nyou with,']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
Ah, who is ridiculous enough to send me a
bouquet?  Why a bouquet?  And why tonight of all nights?  I am not
going to a ball; I am not a girl engaged to be married.  But some
people are always ridiculous.
subQuotationList:
['Ah,', 'who is ridiculous enough to send me a
bouquet?  Why a bouquet?  And why tonight of all nights?  I am not
going to a ball; I am not a girl engaged to be married.  But some
people are always ridiculous.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Nastasia!
subQuotationList: ['Nastasia!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: She turned back to the door opened it and called out

quoteText:
Here--throw this into the dustbin! But no--it's not the fault of the poor flowers.  Tell
the boy to carry them to the house three doors away, the house of Mr.
Winsett, the dark gentleman who dined here.  His wife is ill--they may
give her pleasure ... The boy is out, you say?  Then, my dear one, run
yourself; here, put my cloak over you and fly.  I want the thing out of
the house immediately!  And, as you live, don't say they come from me!
subQuotationList:
['Here--throw this into the dustbin!', "But no--it's not the fault of the poor flowers.  Tell
the boy to carry them to the house three doors away, the house of Mr.
Winsett, the dark gentleman who dined here.  His wife is ill--they may
give her pleasure ... The boy is out, you say?  Then, my dear one, run
yourself; here, put my cloak over you and fly.  I want the thing out of
the house immediately!  And, as you live, don't say they come from me!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
And you two--have you made
friends!
subQuotationList: ['And you two--have you made\nfriends!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: she burst into a laugh instead and looking from the Marchioness to Archer asked

quoteText:
It's for Mr. Archer to say, darling; he has waited patiently while you
were dressing.
subQuotationList: ["It's for Mr. Archer to say, darling; he has waited patiently while you\nwere dressing."]
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
Yes--I gave you time enough: my hair wouldn't go, But
that reminds me: I see Dr. Carver is gone, and you'll be late at the
Blenkers'.  Mr. Archer, will you put my aunt in the carriage?
subQuotationList: ["Yes--I gave you time enough: my hair wouldn't go,", "But\nthat reminds me: I see Dr. Carver is gone, and you'll be late at the\nBlenkers'.  Mr. Archer, will you put my aunt in the carriage?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Mind, the carriage is to be back for me at ten!
subQuotationList: ['Mind, the carriage is to be back for me at ten!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: She followed the Marchioness into the hall saw her fitted into a miscellaneous heap of overshoes shawls and tippets and called

quoteText: There's time for a cigarette.
subQuotationList: ["There's time for a cigarette."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: she turned threw herself into her sofacorner and sighed out

quoteText:
What
do you think of me in a temper?
subQuotationList: ['What\ndo you think of me in a temper?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: she glanced at him with laughing eyes and said

quoteText:
It
makes me understand what your aunt has been saying about you.
subQuotationList: ['It\nmakes me understand what your aunt has been saying about you.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I knew she'd been talking about me.  Well?
subQuotationList: ["I knew she'd been talking about me.  Well?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
She said you were used to all kinds of things--splendours and
amusements and excitements--that we could never hope to give you here.
subQuotationList: ['She said you were used to all kinds of things--splendours and\namusements and excitements--that we could never hope to give you here.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Medora is incorrigibly romantic.  It has made up to her for so many
things!
subQuotationList: ['Medora is incorrigibly romantic.  It has made up to her for so many\nthings!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Is your aunt's
romanticism always consistent with accuracy?
subQuotationList: ["Is your aunt's\nromanticism always consistent with accuracy?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You mean: does she speak the truth?
subQuotationList: ['You mean: does she speak the truth?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Well,
I'll tell you: in almost everything she says, there's something true
and something untrue.  But why do you ask?  What has she been telling
you?
subQuotationList:
["Well,
I'll tell you: in almost everything she says, there's something true
and something untrue.  But why do you ask?  What has she been telling
you?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
She says--she pretends that Count Olenski has asked her to persuade
you to go back to him.
subQuotationList: ['She says--she pretends that Count Olenski has asked her to persuade\nyou to go back to him.']
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Marchioness'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Count Olenski'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski']]]

quoteText: You knew, then?
subQuotationList: ['You knew, then?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
She has hinted about a letter: poor
darling!  Medora's hints--
subQuotationList: ["She has hinted about a letter: poor\ndarling!  Medora's hints--"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Is it at your husband's request that she has arrived here suddenly?
subQuotationList: ["Is it at your husband's request that she has arrived here suddenly?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
There again:
one can't tell.  She told me she had had a 'spiritual summons,'
whatever that is, from Dr. Carver.  I'm afraid she's going to marry Dr.
Carver ...  poor Medora, there's always some one she wants to marry.
But perhaps the people in Cuba just got tired of her!  I think she was
with them as a sort of paid companion.  Really, I don't know why she
came.
subQuotationList:
["There again:
one can't tell.  She told me she had had a 'spiritual summons,'
whatever that is, from Dr. Carver.  I'm afraid she's going to marry Dr.
Carver ...  poor Medora, there's always some one she wants to marry.
But perhaps the people in Cuba just got tired of her!  I think she was
with them as a sort of paid companion.  Really, I don't know why she
came."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Marchioness'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Dr. Carver'], ['The Marchioness'], ['The Marchioness'], ['The Marchioness'], ['The Marchioness'], ['The Marchioness']]]

quoteText: But you do believe she has a letter from your husband?
subQuotationList: ['But you do believe she has a letter from your husband?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
After all, it
was to be expected.
subQuotationList: ['After all, it\nwas to be expected.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You know that your aunt believes you will go back?
subQuotationList: ['You know that your aunt believes you will go back?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Many cruel things have been believed of me,
subQuotationList: ['Many cruel things have been believed of me,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Oh, Ellen--forgive me; I'm a fool and a brute!
subQuotationList: ["Oh, Ellen--forgive me; I'm a fool and a brute!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You are horribly nervous; you have your own
troubles.  I know you think the Wellands are unreasonable about your
marriage, and of course I agree with you.  In Europe people don't
understand our long American engagements; I suppose they are not as
calm as we are.
subQuotationList:
["You are horribly nervous; you have your own
troubles.  I know you think the Wellands are unreasonable about your
marriage, and of course I agree with you.  In Europe people don't
understand our long American engagements; I suppose they are not as
calm as we are."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['May Wellend', 'Mr. Welland'], ['Mr. Welland', 'May Wellend'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
Yes, I went south to ask May to marry me after
Easter.  There's no reason why we shouldn't be married then.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', "I went south to ask May to marry me after\nEaster.  There's no reason why we shouldn't be married then."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
And May adores you--and yet you couldn't convince her?  I thought her
too intelligent to be the slave of such absurd superstitions.
subQuotationList: ["And May adores you--and yet you couldn't convince her?  I thought her\ntoo intelligent to be the slave of such absurd superstitions."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: She IS too intelligent--she's not their slave.
subQuotationList: ["She IS too intelligent--she's not their slave."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well, then--I don't understand.
subQuotationList: ["Well, then--I don't understand."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
We had a frank
talk--almost the first.  She thinks my impatience a bad sign.
subQuotationList: ['We had a frank\ntalk--almost the first.  She thinks my impatience a bad sign.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Merciful heavens--a bad sign?
subQuotationList: ['Merciful heavens--a bad sign?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
She thinks it means that I can't trust myself to go on caring for her.
She thinks, in short, I want to marry her at once to get away from some
one that I--care for more.
subQuotationList: ["She thinks it means that I can't trust myself to go on caring for her.\nShe thinks, in short, I want to marry her at once to get away from some\none that I--care for more."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
But if she thinks that--why
isn't she in a hurry too?
subQuotationList: ["But if she thinks that--why\nisn't she in a hurry too?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Because she's not like that: she's so much nobler.  She insists all
the more on the long engagement, to give me time--
subQuotationList: ["Because she's not like that: she's so much nobler.  She insists all\nthe more on the long engagement, to give me time--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Time to give her up for the other woman?
subQuotationList: ['Time to give her up for the other woman?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: If I want to.
subQuotationList: ['If I want to.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: That IS noble,
subQuotationList: ['That IS noble,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Yes.  But it's ridiculous.
subQuotationList: ["Yes.  But it's ridiculous."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ridiculous?  Because you don't care for any one else?
subQuotationList: ["Ridiculous?  Because you don't care for any one else?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Because I don't mean to marry any one else.
subQuotationList: ["Because I don't mean to marry any one else."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah.
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: This other woman--does she love you?
subQuotationList: ['This other woman--does she love you?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: she looked up at him and asked

quoteText:
Oh, there's no other woman; I mean, the person that May was thinking
of is--was never--
subQuotationList: ["Oh, there's no other woman; I mean, the person that May was thinking\nof is--was never--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Then, why, after all, are you in such haste?
subQuotationList: ['Then, why, after all, are you in such haste?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: There's your carriage,
subQuotationList: ["There's your carriage,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes; I suppose I must be going.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; I suppose I must be going.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You're going to Mrs. Struthers's?
subQuotationList: ["You're going to Mrs. Struthers's?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I must go where I am invited, or I
should be too lonely.  Why not come with me?
subQuotationList: ['I must go where I am invited, or I\nshould be too lonely.  Why not come with me?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
May guessed the truth, There is another woman--but not the
one she thinks.
subQuotationList: ['May guessed the truth,', 'There is another woman--but not the\none she thinks.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, don't make love to me!  Too many people have
done that,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, don't make love to me!  Too many people have\ndone that,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I have never made love to you, and I
never shall.  But you are the woman I would have married if it had been
possible for either of us.
subQuotationList: ['I have never made love to you,', 'and I\nnever shall.  But you are the woman I would have married if it had been\npossible for either of us.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Possible for either of us?
subQuotationList: ['Possible for either of us?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
And you say that--when it's you who've made it
impossible?
subQuotationList: ["And you say that--when it's you who've made it\nimpossible?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I'VE made it impossible--?
subQuotationList: ["I'VE made it impossible--?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You, you, YOU! Isn't it you who made me give up divorcing--give it
up because you showed me how selfish and wicked it was, how one must
sacrifice one's self to preserve the dignity of marriage ... and to
spare one's family the publicity, the scandal?  And because my family
was going to be your family--for May's sake and for yours--I did what
you told me, what you proved to me that I ought to do.  Ah,
subQuotationList:
['You, you, YOU!', "Isn't it you who made me give up divorcing--give it
up because you showed me how selfish and wicked it was, how one must
sacrifice one's self to preserve the dignity of marriage ... and to
spare one's family the publicity, the scandal?  And because my family
was going to be your family--for May's sake and for yours--I did what
you told me, what you proved to me that I ought to do.  Ah,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']], [['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
I've made no secret of having done it for
you!
subQuotationList: ["I've made no secret of having done it for\nyou!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Good God, When I thought--
subQuotationList: ['Good God,', 'When I thought--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You thought?
subQuotationList: ['You thought?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Ah, don't ask me what I thought!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, don't ask me what I thought!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I do ask you.
subQuotationList: ['I do ask you.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Well, then: there were things in that letter you asked me to read--
subQuotationList: ['Well, then: there were things in that letter you asked me to read--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: My husband's letter?
subQuotationList: ["My husband's letter?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I had nothing to fear from that letter: absolutely nothing!  All I
feared was to bring notoriety, scandal, on the family--on you and May.
subQuotationList: ['I had nothing to fear from that letter: absolutely nothing!  All I\nfeared was to bring notoriety, scandal, on the family--on you and May.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Good God,
subQuotationList: ['Good God,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: At least I loved you--
subQuotationList: ['At least I loved you--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ellen!  What madness!  Why are you crying?  Nothing's done that can't
be undone.  I'm still free, and you're going to be.
subQuotationList: ["Ellen!  What madness!  Why are you crying?  Nothing's done that can't\nbe undone.  I'm still free, and you're going to be."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, my poor Newland--I suppose this had to be.  But it doesn't in the
least alter things,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, my poor Newland--I suppose this had to be.  But it doesn't in the\nleast alter things,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: It alters the whole of life for me.
subQuotationList: ['It alters the whole of life for me.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No, no--it mustn't, it can't.  You're engaged to May Welland; and I'm
married.
subQuotationList: ["No, no--it mustn't, it can't.  You're engaged to May Welland; and I'm\nmarried."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Nonsense!  It's too late for
that sort of thing.  We've no right to lie to other people or to
ourselves.  We won't talk of your marriage; but do you see me marrying
May after this?
subQuotationList:
["Nonsense!  It's too late for
that sort of thing.  We've no right to lie to other people or to
ourselves.  We won't talk of your marriage; but do you see me marrying
May after this?"]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['May Wellend', 'Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
I don't see you, putting that question to May.
Do you?
subQuotationList: ["I don't see you,", 'putting that question to May.\nDo you?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: It's too late to do anything else.
subQuotationList: ["It's too late to do anything else."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You say that because it's the easiest thing to say at this moment--not
because it's true.  In reality it's too late to do anything but what
we'd both decided on.
subQuotationList: ["You say that because it's the easiest thing to say at this moment--not\nbecause it's true.  In reality it's too late to do anything but what\nwe'd both decided on."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Ah, I don't understand you!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, I don't understand you!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You don't understand because you haven't yet guessed how you've
changed things for me: oh, from the first--long before I knew all you'd
done.
subQuotationList: ["You don't understand because you haven't yet guessed how you've\nchanged things for me: oh, from the first--long before I knew all you'd\ndone."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: All I'd done?
subQuotationList: ["All I'd done?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes.  I was perfectly unconscious at first that people here were shy
of me--that they thought I was a dreadful sort of person.  It seems
they had even refused to meet me at dinner.  I found that out
afterward; and how you'd made your mother go with you to the van der
Luydens'; and how you'd insisted on announcing your engagement at the
Beaufort ball, so that I might have two families to stand by me instead
of one--
subQuotationList:
["Yes.  I was perfectly unconscious at first that people here were shy
of me--that they thought I was a dreadful sort of person.  It seems
they had even refused to meet me at dinner.  I found that out
afterward; and how you'd made your mother go with you to the van der
Luydens'; and how you'd insisted on announcing your engagement at the
Beaufort ball, so that I might have two families to stand by me instead
of one--"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Julius Beaufort']]]

quoteText:
Just imagine, how stupid and unobservant I was!  I knew
nothing of all this till Granny blurted it out one day.  New York
simply meant peace and freedom to me: it was coming home.  And I was so
happy at being among my own people that every one I met seemed kind and
good, and glad to see me.  But from the very beginning, I felt there was no one as kind as you; no one who gave me reasons
that I understood for doing what at first seemed so hard
and--unnecessary.  The very good people didn't convince me; I felt
they'd never been tempted.  But you knew; you understood; you had felt
the world outside tugging at one with all its golden hands--and yet you
hated the things it asks of one; you hated happiness bought by
disloyalty and cruelty and indifference.  That was what I'd never known
before--and it's better than anything I've known.
subQuotationList:
['Just imagine,', 'how stupid and unobservant I was!  I knew
nothing of all this till Granny blurted it out one day.  New York
simply meant peace and freedom to me: it was coming home.  And I was so
happy at being among my own people that every one I met seemed kind and
good, and glad to see me.  But from the very beginning,', "I felt there was no one as kind as you; no one who gave me reasons
that I understood for doing what at first seemed so hard
and--unnecessary.  The very good people didn't convince me; I felt
they'd never been tempted.  But you knew; you understood; you had felt
the world outside tugging at one with all its golden hands--and yet you
hated the things it asks of one; you hated happiness bought by
disloyalty and cruelty and indifference.  That was what I'd never known
before--and it's better than anything I've known."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Manson Mingott']], [['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
Ah, don't let us undo what you've done! I can't go back
now to that other way of thinking.  I can't love you unless I give you
up.
subQuotationList: ["Ah, don't let us undo what you've done!", "I can't go back\nnow to that other way of thinking.  I can't love you unless I give you\nup."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: And Beaufort?  Is he to replace me?
subQuotationList: ['And Beaufort?  Is he to replace me?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
He's waiting for you now at Mrs. Struthers's; why don't you go to
him?
subQuotationList: ["He's waiting for you now at Mrs. Struthers's; why don't you go to\nhim?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I shall not go out this evening; tell
the carriage to go and fetch the Signora Marchesa,
subQuotationList: ['I shall not go out this evening; tell\nthe carriage to go and fetch the Signora Marchesa,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Why this sacrifice?  Since you tell me that you're
lonely I've no right to keep you from your friends.
subQuotationList: ["Why this sacrifice?  Since you tell me that you're\nlonely I've no right to keep you from your friends."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I shan't be lonely now.  I
WAS lonely; I WAS afraid.  But the emptiness and the darkness are gone;
when I turn back into myself now I'm like a child going at night into a
room where there's always a light.
subQuotationList:
["I shan't be lonely now.  I
WAS lonely; I WAS afraid.  But the emptiness and the darkness are gone;
when I turn back into myself now I'm like a child going at night into a
room where there's always a light."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I don't understand you!
subQuotationList: ["I don't understand you!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yet you understand May!
subQuotationList: ['Yet you understand May!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
May is ready
to give me up.
subQuotationList: ['May is ready\nto give me up.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
What!  Three days after you've entreated her on your knees to hasten
your marriage?
subQuotationList: ["What!  Three days after you've entreated her on your knees to hasten\nyour marriage?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: She's refused; that gives me the right--
subQuotationList: ["She's refused; that gives me the right--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah, you've taught me what an ugly word that is,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, you've taught me what an ugly word that is,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: If we do this now it will be worse afterward--worse for every one--
subQuotationList: ['If we do this now it will be worse afterward--worse for every one--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No--no--no!
subQuotationList: ['No--no--no!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
The lady was very happy at the flowers, She thought it was her signor marito who had sent them, and
she cried a little and said it was a folly.
subQuotationList: ['The lady was very happy at the flowers,', 'She thought it was her signor marito who had sent them, and\nshe cried a little and said it was a folly.']
speaker: Nastasia

quoteText:
Newland!  I hope there's no bad news in that telegram?  I waited on
purpose, in case--
subQuotationList: ["Newland!  I hope there's no bad news in that telegram?  I waited on\npurpose, in case--"]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText:
Look here--what day is Easter this
year?
subQuotationList: ['Look here--what day is Easter this\nyear?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Easter?  Newland!
Why, of course, the first week in April.  Why?
subQuotationList: ['Easter?  Newland!\nWhy, of course, the first week in April.  Why?']
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: The first week?
subQuotationList: ['The first week?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: The first week, did you say?
subQuotationList: ['The first week, did you say?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: For mercy's sake what's the matter?
subQuotationList: ["For mercy's sake what's the matter?"]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Nothing's the matter, except that I'm going to be married in a month.
subQuotationList: ["Nothing's the matter, except that I'm going to be married in a month."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh Newland, how wonderful!  I'm so glad!  But, dearest, why do you
keep on laughing?  Do hush, or you'll wake Mamma.
subQuotationList: ["Oh Newland, how wonderful!  I'm so glad!  But, dearest, why do you\nkeep on laughing?  Do hush, or you'll wake Mamma."]
speaker: Janey Archer

quoteText: Got the ring all right?
subQuotationList: ['Got the ring all right?']
speaker: Young Van Der Luyden
referringExpression: whispered young van der Luyden Newland

quoteText:
How like a first night at the Opera! Poor Janey! even by screwing her
head around she can see only the people in the few front pews; and
they're mostly dowdy Newlands and Dagonets. And all the while, I suppose, real people were living
somewhere, and real things happening to them ...
subQuotationList:
['How like a first night at the Opera!', 'Poor Janey!', "even by screwing her
head around she can see only the people in the few front pews; and
they're mostly dowdy Newlands and Dagonets.", 'And all the while, I suppose,', 'real people were living
somewhere, and real things happening to them ...']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: THERE THEY COME!
subQuotationList: ['THERE THEY COME!']
speaker: Young Van Der Luyden

quoteText: Newland--I say: SHE'S HERE!
subQuotationList: ["Newland--I say: SHE'S HERE!"]
speaker: Young Van Der Luyden

quoteText: My God, HAVE I got the ring?
subQuotationList: ['My God,', 'HAVE I got the ring?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Dearly beloved, we are gathered together here,
subQuotationList: ['Dearly beloved, we are gathered together here,']
speaker: The Rector
addressees: ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'The Marchioness', 'Young Van Der Luyden', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Welland']

quoteText: Your arm--I SAY, GIVE HER YOUR ARM!
subQuotationList: ['Your arm--I SAY, GIVE HER YOUR ARM!']
speaker: Young Van Der Luyden

quoteText: Darling!
subQuotationList: ['Darling!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes, of course I thought
I'd lost the ring; no wedding would be complete if the poor devil of a
bridegroom didn't go through that.  But you DID keep me waiting, you
know!  I had time to think of every horror that might possibly happen.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, of course I thought
I'd lost the ring; no wedding would be complete if the poor devil of a
bridegroom didn't go through that.  But you DID keep me waiting, you
know!  I had time to think of every horror that might possibly happen."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
But none ever CAN happen now, can it, Newland,
as long as we two are together?
subQuotationList: ['But none ever CAN happen now, can it, Newland,\nas long as we two are together?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I was surprised,
though--weren't you?--that aunt Medora came after all.  Ellen wrote
that they were neither of them well enough to take the journey; I do
wish it had been she who had recovered!  Did you see the exquisite old
lace she sent me?
subQuotationList:
["I was surprised,
though--weren't you?--that aunt Medora came after all.  Ellen wrote
that they were neither of them well enough to take the journey; I do
wish it had been she who had recovered!  Did you see the exquisite old
lace she sent me?"]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'The Marchioness'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'The Marchioness'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Yes--I--no: yes, it was beautiful,
subQuotationList: ['Yes--I--no: yes, it was beautiful,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Aren't you tired?  It will be good to have some tea when we
arrive--I'm sure the aunts have got everything beautifully ready,
subQuotationList: ["Aren't you tired?  It will be good to have some tea when we\narrive--I'm sure the aunts have got everything beautifully ready,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, how awfully kind of the van der Luydens--they've sent their man
over from Skuytercliff to meet us,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, how awfully kind of the van der Luydens--they've sent their man\nover from Skuytercliff to meet us,"]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
I'm extremely sorry, sir, that a little accident
has occurred at the Miss du Lacs': a leak in the water-tank.  It
happened yesterday, and Mr. van der Luyden, who heard of it this
morning, sent a housemaid up by the early train to get the Patroon's
house ready.  It will be quite comfortable, I think you'll find, sir;
and the Miss du Lacs have sent their cook over, so that it will be
exactly the same as if you'd been at Rhinebeck.
subQuotationList:
["I'm extremely sorry, sir,", "that a little accident
has occurred at the Miss du Lacs': a leak in the water-tank.  It
happened yesterday, and Mr. van der Luyden, who heard of it this
morning, sent a housemaid up by the early train to get the Patroon's
house ready.  It will be quite comfortable, I think you'll find, sir;
and the Miss du Lacs have sent their cook over, so that it will be
exactly the same as if you'd been at Rhinebeck."]
speaker: The Coachman
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer']], [['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
It'll be exactly the same, sir, I do assure
you--
subQuotationList: ["It'll be exactly the same, sir, I do assure\nyou--"]
speaker: The Coachman

quoteText:
The same as Rhinebeck?  The Patroon's house?  But it will be
a hundred thousand times better--won't it, Newland?  It's too dear and
kind of Mr. van der Luyden to have thought of it.
subQuotationList: ["The same as Rhinebeck?  The Patroon's house?  But it will be\na hundred thousand times better--won't it, Newland?  It's too dear and\nkind of Mr. van der Luyden to have thought of it."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Only fancy, I've never been inside it--have you?  The van der Luydens
show it to so few people.  But they opened it for Ellen, it seems, and
she told me what a darling little place it was: she says it's the only
house she's seen in America that she could imagine being perfectly
happy in.
subQuotationList:
["Only fancy, I've never been inside it--have you?  The van der Luydens
show it to so few people.  But they opened it for Ellen, it seems, and
she told me what a darling little place it was: she says it's the only
house she's seen in America that she could imagine being perfectly
happy in."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Well--that's what we're going to be, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["Well--that's what we're going to be, isn't it?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, it's just our luck
beginning--the wonderful luck we're always going to have together!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, it's just our luck\nbeginning--the wonderful luck we're always going to have together!"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Of course we must dine with Mrs. Carfry, dearest,
subQuotationList: ['Of course we must dine with Mrs. Carfry, dearest,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You must take May to see Mrs.
Carfry.
subQuotationList: ['You must take May to see Mrs.\nCarfry.']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: Mrs Archers last word had been

quoteText:
It's all very well for you, Newland; you KNOW them.  But I shall feel
so shy among a lot of people I've never met.  And what shall I wear?
subQuotationList: ["It's all very well for you, Newland; you KNOW them.  But I shall feel\nso shy among a lot of people I've never met.  And what shall I wear?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Wear, dearest?  I thought a trunkful of things had come from Paris
last week.
subQuotationList: ['Wear, dearest?  I thought a trunkful of things had come from Paris\nlast week.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes, of course.  I meant to say that I shan't know WHICH to wear.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, of course.  I meant to say that I shan't know WHICH to wear."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I've never dined out in London; and I don't want
to be ridiculous.
subQuotationList: ["I've never dined out in London; and I don't want\nto be ridiculous."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
But don't Englishwomen dress
just like everybody else in the evening?
subQuotationList: ["But don't Englishwomen dress\njust like everybody else in the evening?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Newland!  How can you ask such funny questions?  When they go to the
theatre in old ball-dresses and bare heads.
subQuotationList: ['Newland!  How can you ask such funny questions?  When they go to the\ntheatre in old ball-dresses and bare heads.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Well, perhaps they wear new ball-dresses at home; but at any rate Mrs.
Carfry and Miss Harle won't.  They'll wear caps like my mother's--and
shawls; very soft shawls.
subQuotationList: ["Well, perhaps they wear new ball-dresses at home; but at any rate Mrs.\nCarfry and Miss Harle won't.  They'll wear caps like my mother's--and\nshawls; very soft shawls."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes; but how will the other women be dressed?
subQuotationList: ['Yes; but how will the other women be dressed?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Not as well as you, dear,
subQuotationList: ['Not as well as you, dear,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
That's dear of you, Newland;
but it doesn't help me much.
subQuotationList: ["That's dear of you, Newland;\nbut it doesn't help me much."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Why not wear your wedding-dress?  That can't
be wrong, can it?
subQuotationList: ["Why not wear your wedding-dress?  That can't\nbe wrong, can it?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, dearest!  If I only had it here!  But it's gone to Paris to be
made over for next winter, and Worth hasn't sent it back.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, dearest!  If I only had it here!  But it's gone to Paris to be\nmade over for next winter, and Worth hasn't sent it back."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Oh, well-- Look here--the fog's lifting.
If we made a dash for the National Gallery we might manage to catch a
glimpse of the pictures.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, well--', "Look here--the fog's lifting.\nIf we made a dash for the National Gallery we might manage to catch a\nglimpse of the pictures."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: There's Italy
subQuotationList: ["There's Italy"]
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: Archer had pointed southward and said

quoteText:
It would be lovely to go there next winter, if only you didn't have to
be in New York.
subQuotationList: ["It would be lovely to go there next winter, if only you didn't have to\nbe in New York."]
speaker: Miss Welland
referringExpression: May her feet in a gentianbed had smiled cheerfully and replied

quoteText: Look me up, won't you?
subQuotationList: ["Look me up, won't you?"]
speaker: The Duke
referringExpression: the Duke instantly and cordially recognising him had said

quoteText:
Probably there'll be nobody at Mrs. Carfry's--London's a desert at
this season, and you've made yourself much too beautiful,
subQuotationList: ["Probably there'll be nobody at Mrs. Carfry's--London's a desert at\nthis season, and you've made yourself much too beautiful,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I don't want them to think that we dress like savages,
subQuotationList: ["I don't want them to think that we dress like savages,"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
It's their armour, their defence against the unknown,
and their defiance of it.
subQuotationList: ["It's their armour,", 'their defence against the unknown,\nand their defiance of it.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You see, Monsieur, it's worth everything, isn't it, to keep one's
intellectual liberty, not to enslave one's powers of appreciation,
one's critical independence?  It was because of that that I abandoned
journalism, and took to so much duller work: tutoring and private
secretaryship.  There is a good deal of drudgery, of course; but one
preserves one's moral freedom, what we call in French one's quant a
soi.  And when one hears good talk one can join in it without
compromising any opinions but one's own; or one can listen, and answer
it inwardly.  Ah, good conversation--there's nothing like it, is there?
The air of ideas is the only air worth breathing.  And so I have never
regretted giving up either diplomacy or journalism--two different forms
of the same self-abdication.
subQuotationList:
["You see, Monsieur, it's worth everything, isn't it, to keep one's
intellectual liberty, not to enslave one's powers of appreciation,
one's critical independence?  It was because of that that I abandoned
journalism, and took to so much duller work: tutoring and private
secretaryship.  There is a good deal of drudgery, of course; but one
preserves one's moral freedom, what we call in French one's quant a
soi.  And when one hears good talk one can join in it without
compromising any opinions but one's own; or one can listen, and answer
it inwardly.  Ah, good conversation--there's nothing like it, is there?
The air of ideas is the only air worth breathing.  And so I have never
regretted giving up either diplomacy or journalism--two different forms
of the same self-abdication."]
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
Voyez-vous, Monsieur, to be able to look life
in the face: that's worth living in a garret for, isn't it?  But, after
all, one must earn enough to pay for the garret; and I confess that to
grow old as a private tutor--or a 'private' anything--is almost as
chilling to the imagination as a second secretaryship at Bucharest.
Sometimes I feel I must make a plunge: an immense plunge.  Do you
suppose, for instance, there would be any opening for me in America--in
New York?
subQuotationList:
["Voyez-vous, Monsieur, to be able to look life
in the face: that's worth living in a garret for, isn't it?  But, after
all, one must earn enough to pay for the garret; and I confess that to
grow old as a private tutor--or a 'private' anything--is almost as
chilling to the imagination as a second secretaryship at Bucharest.
Sometimes I feel I must make a plunge: an immense plunge.  Do you
suppose, for instance, there would be any opening for me in America--in
New York?"]
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: New York--New York--but must it be especially New York?
subQuotationList: ['New York--New York--but must it be especially New York?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I--I thought it
your metropolis: is not the intellectual life more active there?
subQuotationList: ['I--I thought it\nyour metropolis: is not the intellectual life more active there?']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
One throws out random
suggestions--more to one's self than to others.  In reality, I see no
immediate prospect--
subQuotationList: ["One throws out random\nsuggestions--more to one's self than to others.  In reality, I see no\nimmediate prospect--"]
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
But Mrs. Carfry will think that I ought to be
taking you upstairs.
subQuotationList: ['But Mrs. Carfry will think that I ought to be\ntaking you upstairs.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
That young tutor is an interesting fellow: we had some awfully good
talk after dinner about books and things,
subQuotationList: ['That young tutor is an interesting fellow: we had some awfully good\ntalk after dinner about books and things,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: The little Frenchman?  Wasn't he dreadfully common?
subQuotationList: ["The little Frenchman?  Wasn't he dreadfully common?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Common--common WHERE?
subQuotationList: ['Common--common WHERE?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Why, I should say anywhere but in his school-room.  Those
people are always awkward in society.  But then,
subQuotationList: ['Why, I should say anywhere but in his school-room.  Those\npeople are always awkward in society.  But then,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: I suppose I shouldn't have known if he was clever.
subQuotationList: ["I suppose I shouldn't have known if he was clever."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Ah--then I won't ask him to dine!
subQuotationList: ["Ah--then I won't ask him to dine!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Goodness--ask the Carfrys' tutor?
subQuotationList: ["Goodness--ask the Carfrys' tutor?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Well, not on the same day with the Carfrys, if you prefer I shouldn't.
But I did rather want another talk with him.  He's looking for a job in
New York.
subQuotationList: ["Well, not on the same day with the Carfrys, if you prefer I shouldn't.\nBut I did rather want another talk with him.  He's looking for a job in\nNew York."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
A job in New York?  What sort of a job?  People don't have French
tutors: what does he want to do?
subQuotationList: ["A job in New York?  What sort of a job?  People don't have French\ntutors: what does he want to do?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Chiefly to enjoy good conversation, I understand,
subQuotationList: ['Chiefly to enjoy good conversation, I understand,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh,
Newland, how funny!  Isn't that FRENCH?
subQuotationList: ["Oh,\nNewland, how funny!  Isn't that FRENCH?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
After that I suppose we shall have pretty
nearly finished rubbing off each other's angles,
subQuotationList: ["After that I suppose we shall have pretty\nnearly finished rubbing off each other's angles,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
My dear Newland, I had no idea that you and May had arrived!  You
yourself came only yesterday, you say?  Ah,
business--business--professional duties ... I understand.  Many
husbands, I know, find it impossible to join their wives here except
for the week-end.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Newland, I had no idea that you and May had arrived!  You
yourself came only yesterday, you say?  Ah,
business--business--professional duties ... I understand.  Many
husbands, I know, find it impossible to join their wives here except
for the week-end.']
speaker: The Marchioness
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
But marriage is one long sacrifice, as I
used often to remind my Ellen--
subQuotationList: ['But marriage is one long sacrifice, as I\nused often to remind my Ellen--']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
No, I am not staying here, but with the Blenkers, in their delicious
solitude at Portsmouth.  Beaufort was kind enough to send his famous
trotters for me this morning, so that I might have at least a glimpse
of one of Regina's garden-parties; but this evening I go back to rural
life.  The Blenkers, dear original beings, have hired a primitive old
farm-house at Portsmouth where they gather about them representative
people ...
subQuotationList:
["No, I am not staying here, but with the Blenkers, in their delicious
solitude at Portsmouth.  Beaufort was kind enough to send his famous
trotters for me this morning, so that I might have at least a glimpse
of one of Regina's garden-parties; but this evening I go back to rural
life.  The Blenkers, dear original beings, have hired a primitive old
farm-house at Portsmouth where they gather about them representative
people ..."]
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
This week Dr. Agathon Carver is holding a
series of Inner Thought meetings there.  A contrast indeed to this gay
scene of worldly pleasure--but then I have always lived on contrasts!
To me the only death is monotony.  I always say to Ellen: Beware of
monotony; it's the mother of all the deadly sins.  But my poor child is
going through a phase of exaltation, of abhorrence of the world.  You
know, I suppose, that she has declined all invitations to stay at
Newport, even with her grandmother Mingott?  I could hardly persuade
her to come with me to the Blenkers', if you will believe it!  The life
she leads is morbid, unnatural.  Ah, if she had only listened to me
when it was still possible ... When the door was still open ... But
shall we go down and watch this absorbing match?  I hear your May is
one of the competitors.
subQuotationList:
["This week Dr. Agathon Carver is holding a
series of Inner Thought meetings there.  A contrast indeed to this gay
scene of worldly pleasure--but then I have always lived on contrasts!
To me the only death is monotony.  I always say to Ellen: Beware of
monotony; it's the mother of all the deadly sins.  But my poor child is
going through a phase of exaltation, of abhorrence of the world.  You
know, I suppose, that she has declined all invitations to stay at
Newport, even with her grandmother Mingott?  I could hardly persuade
her to come with me to the Blenkers', if you will believe it!  The life
she leads is morbid, unnatural.  Ah, if she had only listened to me
when it was still possible ... When the door was still open ... But
shall we go down and watch this absorbing match?  I hear your May is
one of the competitors."]
speaker: The Marchioness
referringExpression: She drooped slightly beneath her protecting brim and added
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr. Carver'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland']]]

quoteText:
Hullo, Medora!  Did the trotters do their
business?  Forty minutes, eh?  ...  Well, that's not so bad,
considering your nerves had to be spared.
subQuotationList: ["Hullo, Medora!  Did the trotters do their\nbusiness?  Forty minutes, eh?  ...  Well, that's not so bad,\nconsidering your nerves had to be spared."]
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
Que
voulez-vous?
subQuotationList: ['Que\nvoulez-vous?']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText: You know May's going to carry off the first prize.
subQuotationList: ["You know May's going to carry off the first prize."]
speaker: Julius Beaufort
referringExpression: he glanced at Archer to say

quoteText: Ah, then it remains in the family,
subQuotationList: ['Ah, then it remains in the family,']
speaker: The Marchioness

quoteText:
Gad, not one of the lot holds
the bow as she does
subQuotationList: ['Gad,', 'not one of the lot holds\nthe bow as she does']
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText:
Yes; but that's the only
kind of target she'll ever hit.
subQuotationList: ["Yes; but that's the only\nkind of target she'll ever hit."]
speaker: Julius Beaufort

quoteText:
Shall we go to see Granny? I should like to
tell her myself that I've won the prize.  There's lots of time before
dinner.
subQuotationList: ['Shall we go to see Granny?', "I should like to\ntell her myself that I've won the prize.  There's lots of time before\ndinner."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Welland', 'Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott']], [['Mrs. Manson Mingott']]]

quoteText:
Quite an heirloom, in fact, my dear, You
must leave it in fee to your eldest girl. Well, well, what have I said
to make you shake out the red flag?  Ain't there going to be any
daughters--only boys, eh?  Good gracious, look at her blushing again
all over her blushes!  What--can't I say that either?  Mercy me--when
my children beg me to have all those gods and goddesses painted out
overhead I always say I'm too thankful to have somebody about me that
NOTHING can shock!
subQuotationList:
['Quite an heirloom, in fact, my dear,', 'You
must leave it in fee to your eldest girl.', "Well, well, what have I said
to make you shake out the red flag?  Ain't there going to be any
daughters--only boys, eh?  Good gracious, look at her blushing again
all over her blushes!  What--can't I say that either?  Mercy me--when
my children beg me to have all those gods and goddesses painted out
overhead I always say I'm too thankful to have somebody about me that
NOTHING can shock!"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['May Wellend']], [['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland']], [['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland']]]

quoteText:
Well, now tell me all about the party, please, my dears, for I shall
never get a straight word about it out of that silly Medora,
subQuotationList: ['Well, now tell me all about the party, please, my dears, for I shall\nnever get a straight word about it out of that silly Medora,']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Cousin Medora?  But I
thought she was going back to Portsmouth?
subQuotationList: ['Cousin Medora?  But I\nthought she was going back to Portsmouth?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
So
she is--but she's got to come here first to pick up Ellen.  Ah--you
didn't know Ellen had come to spend the day with me?  Such fol-de-rol,
her not coming for the summer; but I gave up arguing with young people
about fifty years ago.  Ellen--ELLEN!
subQuotationList:
["So
she is--but she's got to come here first to pick up Ellen.  Ah--you
didn't know Ellen had come to spend the day with me?  Such fol-de-rol,
her not coming for the summer; but I gave up arguing with young people
about fifty years ago.  Ellen--ELLEN!"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Marchioness'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
Run down and fetch her, like a good grandson; this pretty lady will
describe the party to me,
subQuotationList: ['Run down and fetch her, like a good grandson; this pretty lady will\ndescribe the party to me,']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: What am I?  A son-in-law--
subQuotationList: ['What am I?  A son-in-law--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
She doesn't know--she hasn't guessed.  Shouldn't I know if she came up
behind me, I wonder?
subQuotationList: ["She doesn't know--she hasn't guessed.  Shouldn't I know if she came up\nbehind me, I wonder?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
If
she doesn't turn before that sail crosses the Lime Rock light I'll go
back.
subQuotationList: ["If\nshe doesn't turn before that sail crosses the Lime Rock light I'll go\nback."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I'm sorry you didn't find Ellen--I should have liked to see her
again, But perhaps she
wouldn't have cared--she seems so changed.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry you didn't find Ellen--I should have liked to see her\nagain,", "But perhaps she\nwouldn't have cared--she seems so changed."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Changed?
subQuotationList: ['Changed?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
So indifferent to her friends, I mean; giving up New York and her
house, and spending her time with such queer people.  Fancy how
hideously uncomfortable she must be at the Blenkers'!  She says she
does it to keep cousin Medora out of mischief: to prevent her marrying
dreadful people.  But I sometimes think we've always bored her.
subQuotationList:
["So indifferent to her friends, I mean; giving up New York and her
house, and spending her time with such queer people.  Fancy how
hideously uncomfortable she must be at the Blenkers'!  She says she
does it to keep cousin Medora out of mischief: to prevent her marrying
dreadful people.  But I sometimes think we've always bored her."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Marchioness'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Miss Welland', 'Mr. Welland'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
After all, I
wonder if she wouldn't be happier with her husband.
subQuotationList: ["After all, I\nwonder if she wouldn't be happier with her husband."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Sancta simplicitas!
subQuotationList: ['Sancta simplicitas!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I don't think I ever heard
you say a cruel thing before.
subQuotationList: ["I don't think I ever heard\nyou say a cruel thing before."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Cruel?
subQuotationList: ['Cruel?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Well--watching the contortions of the damned is supposed to be a
favourite sport of the angels; but I believe even they don't think
people happier in hell.
subQuotationList: ["Well--watching the contortions of the damned is supposed to be a\nfavourite sport of the angels; but I believe even they don't think\npeople happier in hell."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: It's a pity she ever married abroad then,
subQuotationList: ["It's a pity she ever married abroad then,"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: A party for the Blenkers--the Blenkers?
subQuotationList: ['A party for the Blenkers--the Blenkers?']
speaker: Mr. Welland

quoteText: Good gracious--
subQuotationList: ['Good gracious--']
speaker: Mr. Welland

quoteText:
'Some of us,' my dear--more than one?
Three o'clock is such a very awkward hour.  I have to be here at
half-past three to take my drops: it's really no use trying to follow
Bencomb's new treatment if I don't do it systematically; and if I join
you later, of course I shall miss my drive.
subQuotationList:
["'Some of us,' my dear--more than one?
Three o'clock is such a very awkward hour.  I have to be here at
half-past three to take my drops: it's really no use trying to follow
Bencomb's new treatment if I don't do it systematically; and if I join
you later, of course I shall miss my drive."]
speaker: Mr. Welland

quoteText:
Of course I'll drive with Papa--I'm sure Newland will find something
to do,
subQuotationList: ["Of course I'll drive with Papa--I'm sure Newland will find something\nto do,"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Oh, I think for a change I'll just save it instead of
spending it--
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I think for a change I'll just save it instead of\nspending it--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No; but you see
it doesn't matter, because when there's nothing particular to do he
reads a book.
subQuotationList: ["No; but you see\nit doesn't matter, because when there's nothing particular to do he\nreads a book."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I shall be back by
six, you know, dear: Papa never drives later than that--
subQuotationList: ['I shall be back by\nsix, you know, dear: Papa never drives later than that--']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Oh, Mr. Archer!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Mr. Archer!']
speaker: Miss Blenker

quoteText:
Gracious--where did you drop from?  I must have been sound asleep in
the hammock.  Everybody else has gone to Newport.  Did you ring?
subQuotationList: ['Gracious--where did you drop from?  I must have been sound asleep in\nthe hammock.  Everybody else has gone to Newport.  Did you ring?']
speaker: Miss Blenker

quoteText:
I--no--that is, I was just
going to.  I had to come up the island to see about a horse, and I
drove over on a chance of finding Mrs. Blenker and your visitors.  But
the house seemed empty--so I sat down to wait.
subQuotationList:
['I--no--that is, I was just
going to.  I had to come up the island to see about a horse, and I
drove over on a chance of finding Mrs. Blenker and your visitors.  But
the house seemed empty--so I sat down to wait.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
The house IS empty.  Mother's not here, or the
Marchioness--or anybody but me.
subQuotationList: ["The house IS empty.  Mother's not here, or the\nMarchioness--or anybody but me."]
speaker: Miss Blenker

quoteText:
Didn't you know that Professor and Mrs. Sillerton are
giving a garden-party for mother and all of us this afternoon?  It was
too unlucky that I couldn't go; but I've had a sore throat, and mother
was afraid of the drive home this evening.  Did you ever know anything
so disappointing?  Of course, I shouldn't have
minded half as much if I'd known you were coming.
subQuotationList:
["Didn't you know that Professor and Mrs. Sillerton are
giving a garden-party for mother and all of us this afternoon?  It was
too unlucky that I couldn't go; but I've had a sore throat, and mother
was afraid of the drive home this evening.  Did you ever know anything
so disappointing?  Of course,", "I shouldn't have
minded half as much if I'd known you were coming."]
speaker: Miss Blenker

quoteText:
But Madame Olenska--has she gone to
Newport too?
subQuotationList: ['But Madame Olenska--has she gone to\nNewport too?']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: Archer found the strength to break in

quoteText:
Madame Olenska--didn't you
know she'd been called away?
subQuotationList: ["Madame Olenska--didn't you\nknow she'd been called away?"]
speaker: Miss Blenker

quoteText: Called away?--
subQuotationList: ['Called away?--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, my best parasol!  I lent it to that goose of a Katie, because it
matched her ribbons, and the careless thing must have dropped it here.
We Blenkers are all like that ... real Bohemians!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my best parasol!  I lent it to that goose of a Katie, because it\nmatched her ribbons, and the careless thing must have dropped it here.\nWe Blenkers are all like that ... real Bohemians!']
speaker: Miss Blenker

quoteText:
Yes, Ellen was called away yesterday: she lets
us call her Ellen, you know.  A telegram came from Boston: she said she
might be gone for two days.  I do LOVE the way she does her hair, don't
you?
subQuotationList:
["Yes, Ellen was called away yesterday: she lets
us call her Ellen, you know.  A telegram came from Boston: she said she
might be gone for two days.  I do LOVE the way she does her hair, don't
you?"]
speaker: Miss Blenker
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
You don't happen to know why Madame
Olenska went to Boston?  I hope it was not on account of bad news?
subQuotationList: ["You don't happen to know why Madame\nOlenska went to Boston?  I hope it was not on account of bad news?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, I don't
believe so.  She didn't tell us what was in the telegram.  I think she
didn't want the Marchioness to know.  She's so romantic-looking, isn't
she?  Doesn't she remind you of Mrs. Scott-Siddons when she reads 'Lady
Geraldine's Courtship'?  Did you never hear her?
subQuotationList:
["Oh, I don't
believe so.  She didn't tell us what was in the telegram.  I think she
didn't want the Marchioness to know.  She's so romantic-looking, isn't
she?  Doesn't she remind you of Mrs. Scott-Siddons when she reads 'Lady
Geraldine's Courtship'?  Did you never hear her?"]
speaker: Miss Blenker
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
You don't know, I suppose--I shall be in
Boston tomorrow.  If I could manage to see her--
subQuotationList: ["You don't know, I suppose--I shall be in\nBoston tomorrow.  If I could manage to see her--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, of course; how lovely of you!  She's staying at the
Parker House; it must be horrible there in this weather.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, of course; how lovely of you!  She's staying at the\nParker House; it must be horrible there in this weather."]
speaker: Miss Blenker

quoteText: Out?--
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Oh
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I'm here on business--just got here, But what on earth are you doing in this wilderness?
subQuotationList: ["I'm here on business--just got here,", 'But what on earth are you doing in this wilderness?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I?  Oh, I'm here on business too,
subQuotationList: ["I?  Oh, I'm here on business too,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You do your hair differently,
subQuotationList: ['You do your hair differently,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Differently?  No--it's only that I do it as best I can when I'm
without Nastasia.
subQuotationList: ["Differently?  No--it's only that I do it as best I can when I'm\nwithout Nastasia."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Nastasia; but isn't she with you?
subQuotationList: ["Nastasia; but isn't she with you?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No; I'm alone.  For two days it was not worth while to bring her.
subQuotationList: ["No; I'm alone.  For two days it was not worth while to bring her."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You're alone--at the Parker House?
subQuotationList: ["You're alone--at the Parker House?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Does it strike you
as dangerous?
subQuotationList: ['Does it strike you\nas dangerous?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: No; not dangerous--
subQuotationList: ['No; not dangerous--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: But unconventional?  I see; I suppose it is.
subQuotationList: ['But unconventional?  I see; I suppose it is.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I hadn't thought of it, because I've just done something so
much more unconventional.
subQuotationList: ["I hadn't thought of it, because I've just done something so\nmuch more unconventional."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I've just refused to take back a sum of money--that belonged to
me.
subQuotationList: ["I've just refused to take back a sum of money--that belonged to\nme."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Some one--has come here to meet you?
subQuotationList: ['Some one--has come here to meet you?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: With this offer?
subQuotationList: ['With this offer?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: And you refused--because of the conditions?
subQuotationList: ['And you refused--because of the conditions?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I refused,
subQuotationList: ['I refused,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: What were the conditions?
subQuotationList: ['What were the conditions?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, they were not onerous: just to sit at the head of his table now
and then.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, they were not onerous: just to sit at the head of his table now\nand then.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: He wants you back--at any price?
subQuotationList: ['He wants you back--at any price?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well--a considerable price.  At least the sum is considerable for me.
subQuotationList: ['Well--a considerable price.  At least the sum is considerable for me.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: It was to meet him here that you came?
subQuotationList: ['It was to meet him here that you came?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Meet him--my husband?  HERE?
At this season he's always at Cowes or Baden.
subQuotationList: ["Meet him--my husband?  HERE?\nAt this season he's always at Cowes or Baden."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: He sent some one?
subQuotationList: ['He sent some one?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: With a letter?
subQuotationList: ['With a letter?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No; just a message.  He never writes.  I don't
think I've had more than one letter from him.
subQuotationList: ["No; just a message.  He never writes.  I don't\nthink I've had more than one letter from him."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Why does he never write?
subQuotationList: ['Why does he never write?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Why should he?  What does one have secretaries for?
subQuotationList: ['Why should he?  What does one have secretaries for?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: And the person?
subQuotationList: ['And the person?']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: He paused again and then took another plunge

quoteText:
The emissary?  The emissary, might, for all I care, have left already; but he has insisted on
waiting till this evening ... in case ... on the chance ...
subQuotationList: ['The emissary?  The emissary,', 'might, for all I care, have left already; but he has insisted on\nwaiting till this evening ... in case ... on the chance ...']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: And you came out here to think the chance over?
subQuotationList: ['And you came out here to think the chance over?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I came out to get a breath of air.  The hotel's too stifling.  I'm
taking the afternoon train back to Portsmouth.
subQuotationList: ["I came out to get a breath of air.  The hotel's too stifling.  I'm\ntaking the afternoon train back to Portsmouth."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You're not changed.
subQuotationList: ["You're not changed."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
referringExpression: she turned her eyes again to his face and said

quoteText:
This is horrible.  Why shouldn't we go out a little on the bay?
There's a breeze, and it will be cooler.  We might take the steamboat
down to Point Arley.
subQuotationList: ["This is horrible.  Why shouldn't we go out a little on the bay?\nThere's a breeze, and it will be cooler.  We might take the steamboat\ndown to Point Arley."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
On a Monday morning there won't be anybody on the boat.  My train
doesn't leave till evening: I'm going back to New York.  Why shouldn't
we?
subQuotationList: ["On a Monday morning there won't be anybody on the boat.  My train\ndoesn't leave till evening: I'm going back to New York.  Why shouldn't\nwe?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Haven't we done all we could?
subQuotationList: ["Haven't we done all we could?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You mustn't say things like that to me,
subQuotationList: ["You mustn't say things like that to me,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I'll say anything you like; or nothing.  I won't open my mouth unless
you tell me to.  What harm can it do to anybody?  All I want is to
listen to you,
subQuotationList: ["I'll say anything you like; or nothing.  I won't open my mouth unless\nyou tell me to.  What harm can it do to anybody?  All I want is to\nlisten to you,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh,
don't calculate, give me the day!  I want to get you
away from that man.  At what time was he coming?
subQuotationList: ["Oh,\ndon't calculate,", 'give me the day!  I want to get you\naway from that man.  At what time was he coming?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: At eleven.
subQuotationList: ['At eleven.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Then you must come at once.
subQuotationList: ['Then you must come at once.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You needn't be afraid--if I don't come.
subQuotationList: ["You needn't be afraid--if I don't come."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Nor you either--if you do.  I swear I only want to hear about you, to
know what you've been doing.  It's a hundred years since we've met--it
may be another hundred before we meet again.
subQuotationList: ["Nor you either--if you do.  I swear I only want to hear about you, to\nknow what you've been doing.  It's a hundred years since we've met--it\nmay be another hundred before we meet again."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Why didn't you come
down to the beach to fetch me, the day I was at Granny's?
subQuotationList: ["Why didn't you come\ndown to the beach to fetch me, the day I was at Granny's?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Because you didn't look round--because you didn't know I was there.  I
swore I wouldn't unless you looked round.
subQuotationList: ["Because you didn't look round--because you didn't know I was there.  I\nswore I wouldn't unless you looked round."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: But I didn't look round on purpose.
subQuotationList: ["But I didn't look round on purpose."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: On purpose?
subQuotationList: ['On purpose?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I knew you were there; when you drove in I recognised the ponies.  So
I went down to the beach.
subQuotationList: ['I knew you were there; when you drove in I recognised the ponies.  So\nI went down to the beach.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: To get away from me as far as you could?
subQuotationList: ['To get away from me as far as you could?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: To get away from you as far as I could.
subQuotationList: ['To get away from you as far as I could.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Well, you see
it's no use.  I may as well tell you, that the business I
came here for was just to find you.  But, look here, we must start or
we shall miss our boat.
subQuotationList:
["Well, you see
it's no use.  I may as well tell you,", 'that the business I
came here for was just to find you.  But, look here, we must start or
we shall miss our boat.']
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Our boat?
subQuotationList: ['Our boat?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Oh, but I must
go back to the hotel first:  I must leave a note--
subQuotationList: ['Oh, but I must\ngo back to the hotel first:  I must leave a note--']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: As many notes as you please.  You can write here.
subQuotationList: ['As many notes as you please.  You can write here.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I've even got an
envelope--you see how everything's predestined!  There--steady the
thing on your knee, and I'll get the pen going in a second.  They have
to be humoured; wait--
subQuotationList:
["I've even got an
envelope--you see how everything's predestined!  There--steady the
thing on your knee, and I'll get the pen going in a second.  They have
to be humoured; wait--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It's like jerking down the mercury in a
thermometer: just a trick.  Now try--
subQuotationList: ["It's like jerking down the mercury in a\nthermometer: just a trick.  Now try--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I told you everything was predestined!  Here's a cab for us.  You
see!
subQuotationList: ["I told you everything was predestined!  Here's a cab for us.  You\nsee!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Shall I take it in?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I take it in?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: If she doesn't come soon I'll go in and find her,
subQuotationList: ["If she doesn't come soon I'll go in and find her,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: This is hopeless--I'll ask for a private room,
subQuotationList: ["This is hopeless--I'll ask for a private room,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
But Dr. Carver--aren't you afraid of Dr. Carver?  I hear he's been
staying with you at the Blenkers'.
subQuotationList: ["But Dr. Carver--aren't you afraid of Dr. Carver?  I hear he's been\nstaying with you at the Blenkers'."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, the Carver danger is over.  Dr. Carver is a very
clever man.  He wants a rich wife to finance his plans, and Medora is
simply a good advertisement as a convert.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, the Carver danger is over.  Dr. Carver is a very\nclever man.  He wants a rich wife to finance his plans, and Medora is\nsimply a good advertisement as a convert.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: A convert to what?
subQuotationList: ['A convert to what?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
To all sorts of new and crazy social schemes.  But, do you know, they
interest me more than the blind conformity to tradition--somebody
else's tradition--that I see among our own friends.  It seems stupid to
have discovered America only to make it into a copy of another
country.
subQuotationList:
["To all sorts of new and crazy social schemes.  But, do you know, they
interest me more than the blind conformity to tradition--somebody
else's tradition--that I see among our own friends.  It seems stupid to
have discovered America only to make it into a copy of another
country."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Do you suppose Christopher
Columbus would have taken all that trouble just to go to the Opera with
the Selfridge Merrys?
subQuotationList: ['Do you suppose Christopher\nColumbus would have taken all that trouble just to go to the Opera with\nthe Selfridge Merrys?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
And Beaufort--do you say these things to
Beaufort?
subQuotationList: ['And Beaufort--do you say these things to\nBeaufort?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
