I haven't seen him for a long time.  But I used to; and he
understands.
subQuotationList: ["I haven't seen him for a long time.  But I used to; and he\nunderstands."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Ah, it's what I've always told you; you don't like us. And you like
Beaufort because he's so unlike us.
subQuotationList: ["Ah, it's what I've always told you; you don't like us. And you like\nBeaufort because he's so unlike us."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
We're damnably dull.  We've no character, no colour,
no variety.--I wonder, why you don't go back?
subQuotationList: ["We're damnably dull.  We've no character, no colour,\nno variety.--I wonder,", "why you don't go back?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I believe it's because of you.
subQuotationList: ["I believe it's because of you."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
At least, it was you who made me understand that
under the dullness there are things so fine and sensitive and delicate
that even those I most cared for in my other life look cheap in
comparison.  I don't know how to explain myself but it seems as if I'd never before understood with
how much that is hard and shabby and base the most exquisite pleasures
may be paid.
subQuotationList:
['At least,', "it was you who made me understand that
under the dullness there are things so fine and sensitive and delicate
that even those I most cared for in my other life look cheap in
comparison.  I don't know how to explain myself", "but it seems as if I'd never before understood with
how much that is hard and shabby and base the most exquisite pleasures
may be paid."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I want, to be perfectly honest with you--and with
myself.  For a long time I've hoped this chance would come: that I
might tell you how you've helped me, what you've made of me--
subQuotationList: ['I want,', "to be perfectly honest with you--and with\nmyself.  For a long time I've hoped this chance would come: that I\nmight tell you how you've helped me, what you've made of me--"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: And what do you make out that you've made of me?
subQuotationList: ["And what do you make out that you've made of me?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Of you?
subQuotationList: ['Of you?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Yes: for I'm of your making much more than you ever were of mine.  I'm
the man who married one woman because another one told him to.
subQuotationList: ["Yes: for I'm of your making much more than you ever were of mine.  I'm\nthe man who married one woman because another one told him to."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I thought--you promised--you
were not to say such things today.
subQuotationList: ['I thought--you promised--you\nwere not to say such things today.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Ah--how like a woman!  None of you will ever see a bad business
through!
subQuotationList: ['Ah--how like a woman!  None of you will ever see a bad business\nthrough!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: IS it a bad business--for May?
subQuotationList: ['IS it a bad business--for May?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
For that's the thing we've always got to think of--haven't we--by your
own showing?
subQuotationList: ["For that's the thing we've always got to think of--haven't we--by your\nown showing?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: My own showing?
subQuotationList: ['My own showing?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Or if not, if it's not worth while to have given up, to have missed
things, so that others may be saved from disillusionment and
misery--then everything I came home for, everything that made my other
life seem by contrast so bare and so poor because no one there took
account of them--all these things are a sham or a dream--
subQuotationList:
['Or if not,', "if it's not worth while to have given up, to have missed
things, so that others may be saved from disillusionment and
misery--then everything I came home for, everything that made my other
life seem by contrast so bare and so poor because no one there took
account of them--all these things are a sham or a dream--"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
And in that case
there's no reason on earth why you shouldn't go back?
subQuotationList: ["And in that case\nthere's no reason on earth why you shouldn't go back?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, IS there no reason?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, IS there no reason?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Not if you staked your all on the success of my marriage.  My
marriage, isn't going to be a sight to keep you
here.
subQuotationList: ['Not if you staked your all on the success of my marriage.  My\nmarriage,', "isn't going to be a sight to keep you\nhere."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
What's the use?  You gave
me my first glimpse of a real life, and at the same moment you asked me
to go on with a sham one.  It's beyond human enduring--that's all.
subQuotationList: ["What's the use?  You gave\nme my first glimpse of a real life, and at the same moment you asked me\nto go on with a sham one.  It's beyond human enduring--that's all."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, don't say that; when I'm enduring it!
subQuotationList: ["Oh, don't say that; when I'm enduring it!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You too--oh, all this time, you too?
subQuotationList: ['You too--oh, all this time, you too?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What's the use--when you will go back?
subQuotationList: ["What's the use--when you will go back?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh--I shan't go yet!
subQuotationList: ["Oh--I shan't go yet!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Not yet?  Some time, then?  Some time that you already foresee?
subQuotationList: ['Not yet?  Some time, then?  Some time that you already foresee?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I promise you: not as long as
you hold out.  Not as long as we can look straight at each other like
this.
subQuotationList: ['I promise you: not as long as\nyou hold out.  Not as long as we can look straight at each other like\nthis.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: What a life for you!--
subQuotationList: ['What a life for you!--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh--as long as it's a part of yours.
subQuotationList: ["Oh--as long as it's a part of yours."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: And mine a part of yours?
subQuotationList: ['And mine a part of yours?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: And that's to be all--for either of us?
subQuotationList: ["And that's to be all--for either of us?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well; it IS all, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["Well; it IS all, isn't it?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Don't--don't be unhappy,
subQuotationList: ["Don't--don't be unhappy,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
You won't go back--you won't go
back?
subQuotationList: ["You won't go back--you won't go\nback?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I won't go back,
subQuotationList: ["I won't go back,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Surely, Monsieur, we met in London?
subQuotationList: ['Surely, Monsieur, we met in London?']
speaker: M. Riviere
referringExpression: he advanced toward Archer lifted his hat and said

quoteText: Ah, to be sure: in London!
subQuotationList: ['Ah, to be sure: in London!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: So you DID get here, after all?
subQuotationList: ['So you DID get here, after all?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, I got here--yes,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I got here--yes,']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
But not for
long; I return the day after tomorrow.
subQuotationList: ['But not for\nlong; I return the day after tomorrow.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
I wonder, Monsieur, since I've had the good luck to run across you, if
I might--
subQuotationList: ["I wonder, Monsieur, since I've had the good luck to run across you, if\nI might--"]
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
I was just going to suggest it: come to luncheon, won't you?  Down
town, I mean: if you'll look me up in my office I'll take you to a very
decent restaurant in that quarter.
subQuotationList: ["I was just going to suggest it: come to luncheon, won't you?  Down\ntown, I mean: if you'll look me up in my office I'll take you to a very\ndecent restaurant in that quarter."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You're too kind.  But I
was only going to ask if you would tell me how to reach some sort of
conveyance.  There are no porters, and no one here seems to listen--
subQuotationList: ["You're too kind.  But I\nwas only going to ask if you would tell me how to reach some sort of\nconveyance.  There are no porters, and no one here seems to listen--"]
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
I know: our American stations must surprise you.  When you ask for a
porter they give you chewing-gum.  But if you'll come along I'll
extricate you; and you must really lunch with me, you know.
subQuotationList: ["I know: our American stations must surprise you.  When you ask for a\nporter they give you chewing-gum.  But if you'll come along I'll\nextricate you; and you must really lunch with me, you know."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['M. Riviere'], ['M. Riviere'], ['M. Riviere'], ['M. Riviere'], ['M. Riviere'], ['M. Riviere'], ['M. Riviere']]]

quoteText: I believe I saw you, sir, yesterday in Boston.
subQuotationList: ['I believe I saw you, sir, yesterday in Boston.']
speaker: M. Riviere
referringExpression: the young man before accepting the seat he proffered began

quoteText:
It is extraordinary, very extraordinary, that
we should have met in the circumstances in which I find myself.
subQuotationList: ['It is extraordinary, very extraordinary,', 'that\nwe should have met in the circumstances in which I find myself.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: What circumstances?
subQuotationList: ['What circumstances?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I have come,
not to look for employment, as I spoke of doing when we last met, but
on a special mission--
subQuotationList: ['I have come,\nnot to look for employment, as I spoke of doing when we last met, but\non a special mission--']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: Ah--!
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: A special mission,
subQuotationList: ['A special mission,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Do sit down
subQuotationList: ['Do sit down']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: It was about this mission that you wanted to consult me?
subQuotationList: ['It was about this mission that you wanted to consult me?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Not in my own behalf: on that score I--I
have fully dealt with myself.  I should like--if I may--to speak to you
about the Countess Olenska.
subQuotationList: ['Not in my own behalf: on that score I--I\nhave fully dealt with myself.  I should like--if I may--to speak to you\nabout the Countess Olenska.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: And on whose behalf, do you wish to do this?
subQuotationList: ['And on whose behalf,', 'do you wish to do this?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well--I might say HERS, if it
did not sound like a liberty.  Shall I say instead: on behalf of
abstract justice?
subQuotationList: ['Well--I might say HERS, if it\ndid not sound like a liberty.  Shall I say instead: on behalf of\nabstract justice?']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
In other words: you are Count
Olenski's messenger?
subQuotationList: ["In other words: you are Count\nOlenski's messenger?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Not to YOU, Monsieur.  If I come to you, it is on quite
other grounds.
subQuotationList: ['Not to YOU, Monsieur.  If I come to you, it is on quite\nother grounds.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: What right have you, in the circumstances, to BE on any other ground? If you're an emissary you're an emissary.
subQuotationList: ['What right have you, in the circumstances, to BE on any other ground?', "If you're an emissary you're an emissary."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
My mission is over: as far as the Countess
Olenska goes, it has failed.
subQuotationList: ['My mission is over: as far as the Countess\nOlenska goes, it has failed.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: I can't help that,
subQuotationList: ["I can't help that,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No: but you can help-- You can help, Monsieur, I am convinced, to make it
equally a failure with her family.
subQuotationList: ['No: but you can help--', 'You can help, Monsieur, I am convinced, to make it\nequally a failure with her family.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: Well--and by God I will!
subQuotationList: ['Well--and by God I will!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Why the devil, should you have
thought--since I suppose you're appealing to me on the ground of my
relationship to Madame Olenska--that I should take a view contrary to
the rest of her family?
subQuotationList:
['Why the devil,', "should you have
thought--since I suppose you're appealing to me on the ground of my
relationship to Madame Olenska--that I should take a view contrary to
the rest of her family?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, Monsieur--
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Monsieur--']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
I can't imagine, why you should have come to me
when there are others so much nearer to the Countess; still less why
you thought I should be more accessible to the arguments I suppose you
were sent over with.
subQuotationList:
["I can't imagine,", 'why you should have come to me
when there are others so much nearer to the Countess; still less why
you thought I should be more accessible to the arguments I suppose you
were sent over with.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
The
arguments I want to present to you, Monsieur, are my own and not those
I was sent over with.
subQuotationList: ['The\narguments I want to present to you, Monsieur, are my own and not those\nI was sent over with.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: Then I see still less reason for listening to them.
subQuotationList: ['Then I see still less reason for listening to them.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Monsieur--will you tell me one
thing?  Is it my right to be here that you question?  Or do you perhaps
believe the whole matter to be already closed?
subQuotationList: ['Monsieur--will you tell me one\nthing?  Is it my right to be here that you question?  Or do you perhaps\nbelieve the whole matter to be already closed?']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: I beg your pardon: but why isn't the matter closed?
subQuotationList: ["I beg your pardon: but why isn't the matter closed?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You do, then, agree with
the rest of the family that, in face of the new proposals I have
brought, it is hardly possible for Madame Olenska not to return to her
husband?
subQuotationList:
['You do, then, agree with
the rest of the family that, in face of the new proposals I have
brought, it is hardly possible for Madame Olenska not to return to her
husband?']
speaker: M. Riviere
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Old Mrs. Mingott', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland', 'May Wellend', 'Mr. Welland'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Good God!
subQuotationList: ['Good God!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Before seeing her, I saw--at Count Olenski's request--Mr. Lovell
Mingott, with whom I had several talks before going to Boston.  I
understand that he represents his mother's view; and that Mrs. Manson
Mingott's influence is great throughout her family.
subQuotationList:
["Before seeing her, I saw--at Count Olenski's request--Mr. Lovell
Mingott, with whom I had several talks before going to Boston.  I
understand that he represents his mother's view; and that Mrs. Manson
Mingott's influence is great throughout her family."]
speaker: M. Riviere
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Old Mrs. Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott']]]

quoteText:
Don't you know,
Monsieur--is it possible you don't know--that the family begin to doubt
if they have the right to advise the Countess to refuse her husband's
last proposals?
subQuotationList:
["Don't you know,
Monsieur--is it possible you don't know--that the family begin to doubt
if they have the right to advise the Countess to refuse her husband's
last proposals?"]
speaker: M. Riviere
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'May Wellend', 'Old Mrs. Mingott', 'Mr. Welland', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'May Wellend', 'Old Mrs. Mingott', 'Mr. Welland', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: The proposals you brought?
subQuotationList: ['The proposals you brought?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: The proposals I brought.
subQuotationList: ['The proposals I brought.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
What is
your object in speaking to me of this?
subQuotationList: ['What is\nyour object in speaking to me of this?']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: he met the young mans question with another

quoteText:
To beg you, Monsieur--to
beg you with all the force I'm capable of--not to let her go back.--Oh,
don't let her!
subQuotationList: ["To beg you, Monsieur--to\nbeg you with all the force I'm capable of--not to let her go back.--Oh,\ndon't let her!"]
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
May I ask, if this is the line you took with the
Countess Olenska?
subQuotationList: ['May I ask,', 'if this is the line you took with the\nCountess Olenska?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No, Monsieur: I
accepted my mission in good faith.  I really believed--for reasons I
need not trouble you with--that it would be better for Madame Olenska
to recover her situation, her fortune, the social consideration that
her husband's standing gives her.
subQuotationList:
["No, Monsieur: I
accepted my mission in good faith.  I really believed--for reasons I
need not trouble you with--that it would be better for Madame Olenska
to recover her situation, her fortune, the social consideration that
her husband's standing gives her."]
speaker: M. Riviere
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
So I supposed: you could hardly have accepted such a mission
otherwise.
subQuotationList: ['So I supposed: you could hardly have accepted such a mission\notherwise.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I should not have accepted it.
subQuotationList: ['I should not have accepted it.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: Well, then--?
subQuotationList: ['Well, then--?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, Monsieur, after I had seen her, after I had listened to her, I
knew she was better off here.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, Monsieur, after I had seen her, after I had listened to her, I\nknew she was better off here.']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: You knew--?
subQuotationList: ['You knew--?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Monsieur, I discharged my mission faithfully: I put the Count's
arguments, I stated his offers, without adding any comment of my own.
The Countess was good enough to listen patiently; she carried her
goodness so far as to see me twice; she considered impartially all I
had come to say.  And it was in the course of these two talks that I
changed my mind, that I came to see things differently.
subQuotationList:
["Monsieur, I discharged my mission faithfully: I put the Count's
arguments, I stated his offers, without adding any comment of my own.
The Countess was good enough to listen patiently; she carried her
goodness so far as to see me twice; she considered impartially all I
had come to say.  And it was in the course of these two talks that I
changed my mind, that I came to see things differently."]
speaker: M. Riviere
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: May I ask what led to this change?
subQuotationList: ['May I ask what led to this change?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Simply seeing the change in HER,
subQuotationList: ['Simply seeing the change in HER,']
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: The change in her?  Then you knew her before?
subQuotationList: ['The change in her?  Then you knew her before?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I used to see her in her husband's
house.  I have known Count Olenski for many years.  You can imagine
that he would not have sent a stranger on such a mission.
subQuotationList: ["I used to see her in her husband's\nhouse.  I have known Count Olenski for many years.  You can imagine\nthat he would not have sent a stranger on such a mission."]
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText: The change--what sort of a change?
subQuotationList: ['The change--what sort of a change?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, Monsieur, if I could tell you! Tenez--the
discovery, I suppose, of what I'd never thought of before: that she's
an American.  And that if you're an American of HER kind--of your
kind--things that are accepted in certain other societies, or at least
put up with as part of a general convenient give-and-take--become
unthinkable, simply unthinkable.  If Madame Olenska's relations
understood what these things were, their opposition to her returning
would no doubt be as unconditional as her own; but they seem to regard
her husband's wish to have her back as proof of an irresistible longing
for domestic life.
subQuotationList:
['Ah, Monsieur, if I could tell you!', "Tenez--the
discovery, I suppose, of what I'd never thought of before: that she's
an American.  And that if you're an American of HER kind--of your
kind--things that are accepted in certain other societies, or at least
put up with as part of a general convenient give-and-take--become
unthinkable, simply unthinkable.  If Madame Olenska's relations
understood what these things were, their opposition to her returning
would no doubt be as unconditional as her own; but they seem to regard
her husband's wish to have her back as proof of an irresistible longing
for domestic life."]
speaker: M. Riviere
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
Whereas it's
far from being as simple as that.
subQuotationList: ["Whereas it's\nfar from being as simple as that."]
speaker: M. Riviere
referringExpression: M Riviere paused and then added

quoteText: Thank you,
subQuotationList: ['Thank you,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: There's nothing to thank me for, Monsieur: it is I, rather--
subQuotationList: ["There's nothing to thank me for, Monsieur: it is I, rather--"]
speaker: M. Riviere

quoteText:
I should
like, though, to add one thing.  You
asked me if I was in Count Olenski's employ.  I am at this moment: I
returned to him, a few months ago, for reasons of private necessity
such as may happen to any one who has persons, ill and older persons,
dependent on him.  But from the moment that I have taken the step of
coming here to say these things to you I consider myself discharged,
and I shall tell him so on my return, and give him the reasons.  That's
all, Monsieur.
subQuotationList:
['I should
like, though,', "to add one thing.  You
asked me if I was in Count Olenski's employ.  I am at this moment: I

dependent on him.  But from the moment that I have taken the step of
coming here to say these things to you I consider myself discharged,
and I shall tell him so on my return, and give him the reasons.  That's

speaker: M. Riviere
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Newland Archer'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: Thank you,
subQuotationList: ['Thank you,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: There's no doubt that Dr. Ashmore is right: there IS a marked trend,
subQuotationList: ["There's no doubt that Dr. Ashmore is right: there IS a marked trend,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: It was odd, though, to preach about it on Thanksgiving,
subQuotationList: ['It was odd, though, to preach about it on Thanksgiving,']
speaker: Miss Sophy Jackson
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
Oh, he means us to give
thanks for what's left.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, he means us to give\nthanks for what's left."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Newland Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']]]

quoteText:
The extravagance in dress-- Sillerton took me
to the first night of the Opera, and I can only tell you that Jane
Merry's dress was the only one I recognised from last year; and even
that had had the front panel changed.  Yet I know she got it out from
Worth only two years ago, because my seamstress always goes in to make
over her Paris dresses before she wears them.
subQuotationList:
['The extravagance in dress--', "Sillerton took me
to the first night of the Opera, and I can only tell you that Jane
Merry's dress was the only one I recognised from last year; and even

speaker: Miss Sophy Jackson
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Jackson'], ['Mrs. Adeline Archer'], ['Mrs. Merry'], ['Mrs. Merry'], ['Mrs. Merry'], ['Mrs. Merry']]]

quoteText: Ah, Jane Merry is one of US,
subQuotationList: ['Ah, Jane Merry is one of US,']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
Yes; she's one of the few.  In my youth, it
was considered vulgar to dress in the newest fashions; and Amy
Sillerton has always told me that in Boston the rule was to put away
one's Paris dresses for two years.  Old Mrs. Baxter Pennilow, who did
everything handsomely, used to import twelve a year, two velvet, two
satin, two silk, and the other six of poplin and the finest cashmere.
It was a standing order, and as she was ill for two years before she
died they found forty-eight Worth dresses that had never been taken out
of tissue paper; and when the girls left off their mourning they were
able to wear the first lot at the Symphony concerts without looking in
advance of the fashion.
subQuotationList:
["Yes; she's one of the few.  In my youth,", "it
was considered vulgar to dress in the newest fashions; and Amy
Sillerton has always told me that in Boston the rule was to put away
one's Paris dresses for two years.  Old Mrs. Baxter Pennilow, who did
everything handsomely, used to import twelve a year, two velvet, two
satin, two silk, and the other six of poplin and the finest cashmere.
It was a standing order, and as she was ill for two years before she
died they found forty-eight Worth dresses that had never been taken out
of tissue paper; and when the girls left off their mourning they were
able to wear the first lot at the Symphony concerts without looking in
advance of the fashion."]
speaker: Miss Sophy Jackson
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
Ah, well, Boston is more conservative than New York; but I always
think it's a safe rule for a lady to lay aside her French dresses for
one season,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, well, Boston is more conservative than New York; but I always\nthink it's a safe rule for a lady to lay aside her French dresses for\none season,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
It was Beaufort who started the new fashion by making his wife clap
her new clothes on her back as soon as they arrived: I must say at
times it takes all Regina's distinction not to look like ... like ...
subQuotationList: ["It was Beaufort who started the new fashion by making his wife clap\nher new clothes on her back as soon as they arrived: I must say at\ntimes it takes all Regina's distinction not to look like ... like ..."]
speaker: Miss Sophy Jackson
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Julius Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Beaufort', 'Julius Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Beaufort']]]

quoteText: Like her rivals,
subQuotationList: ['Like her rivals,']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer']

quoteText:
Poor Regina!  Her
Thanksgiving hasn't been a very cheerful one, I'm afraid.  Have you
heard the rumours about Beaufort's speculations, Sillerton?
subQuotationList: ["Poor Regina!  Her\nThanksgiving hasn't been a very cheerful one, I'm afraid.  Have you\nheard the rumours about Beaufort's speculations, Sillerton?"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson']]]

quoteText:
Of course, Newland, I know you let dear May go to Mrs. Struthers's
Sunday evenings--
subQuotationList: ["Of course, Newland, I know you let dear May go to Mrs. Struthers's\nSunday evenings--"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
Oh, you know,
everybody goes to Mrs. Struthers's now; and she was invited to Granny's
last reception.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, you know,\neverybody goes to Mrs. Struthers's now; and she was invited to Granny's\nlast reception."]
speaker: Miss Welland
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
I know, dear, I know, Such things have to be, I
suppose, as long as AMUSEMENT is what people go out for; but I've never
quite forgiven your cousin Madame Olenska for being the first person to
countenance Mrs. Struthers.
subQuotationList:
['I know, dear, I know,', "Such things have to be, I
suppose, as long as AMUSEMENT is what people go out for; but I've never
quite forgiven your cousin Madame Olenska for being the first person to

speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: Oh, ELLEN--
subQuotationList: ['Oh, ELLEN--']
speaker: Miss Welland
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
I've always thought that people like the Countess Olenska,
who have lived in aristocratic societies, ought to help us to keep up
our social distinctions, instead of ignoring them.
subQuotationList: ["I've always thought that people like the Countess Olenska,\nwho have lived in aristocratic societies, ought to help us to keep up\nour social distinctions, instead of ignoring them."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']
referringExpression: His mother with less than her usual sensitiveness to atmosphere still insisted
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['May Wellend', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson', 'Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: I've no doubt we all seem alike to foreigners,
subQuotationList: ["I've no doubt we all seem alike to foreigners,"]
speaker: Miss Sophy Jackson
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['May Wellend', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson', 'Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
I don't think Ellen cares for society; but nobody knows exactly what
she does care for,
subQuotationList: ["I don't think Ellen cares for society; but nobody knows exactly what\nshe does care for,"]
speaker: Miss Welland
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: Ah, well--
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well--']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: Madame Olenska is a great favourite with the gentlemen,
subQuotationList: ['Madame Olenska is a great favourite with the gentlemen,']
speaker: Miss Sophy Jackson
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
Ah, that's the danger that a young woman like Madame Olenska is always
exposed to,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, that's the danger that a young woman like Madame Olenska is always\nexposed to,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Miss Sophy Jackson', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Janey Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
If the Beaufort smash comes, there are going to be
disclosures.
subQuotationList: ['If the Beaufort smash comes,', 'there are going to be\ndisclosures.']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
There's bound to be, the nastiest kind of a
cleaning up.  He hasn't spent all his money on Regina.
subQuotationList: ["There's bound to be,", "the nastiest kind of a\ncleaning up.  He hasn't spent all his money on Regina."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
Oh, well--that's discounted, isn't it?  My belief is he'll pull out
yet,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, well--that's discounted, isn't it?  My belief is he'll pull out\nyet,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Perhaps--perhaps.  I know he was to see some of the influential people
today.  Of course, it's to be hoped
they can tide him over--this time anyhow.  I shouldn't like to think of
poor Regina's spending the rest of her life in some shabby foreign
watering-place for bankrupts.
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps--perhaps.  I know he was to see some of the influential people
today.  Of course,', "it's to be hoped
they can tide him over--this time anyhow.  I shouldn't like to think of
poor Regina's spending the rest of her life in some shabby foreign
watering-place for bankrupts."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
I don't know, of course, how far your wife's family are aware of what
people say about--well, about Madame Olenska's refusal to accept her
husband's latest offer.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know, of course, how far your wife's family are aware of what\npeople say about--well, about Madame Olenska's refusal to accept her\nhusband's latest offer."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
It's a
pity--it's certainly a pity--that she refused it.
subQuotationList: ["It's a\npity--it's certainly a pity--that she refused it."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: A pity?  In God's name, why?
subQuotationList: ["A pity?  In God's name, why?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well--to put it on the lowest ground--what's she going to live on now?
subQuotationList: ["Well--to put it on the lowest ground--what's she going to live on now?"]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: Now--?
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: If Beaufort--
subQuotationList: ['If Beaufort--']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: What the devil do you mean, sir?
subQuotationList: ['What the devil do you mean, sir?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well--I have it on pretty good authority--in fact, on old Catherine's
herself--that the family reduced Countess Olenska's allowance
considerably when she definitely refused to go back to her husband; and
as, by this refusal, she also forfeits the money settled on her when
she married--which Olenski was ready to make over to her if she
returned--why, what the devil do YOU mean, my dear boy, by asking me
what I mean?
subQuotationList:
["Well--I have it on pretty good authority--in fact, on old Catherine's
herself--that the family reduced Countess Olenska's allowance
considerably when she definitely refused to go back to her husband; and
as, by this refusal, she also forfeits the money settled on her when
she married--which Olenski was ready to make over to her if she
returned--why, what the devil do YOU mean, my dear boy, by asking me
what I mean?"]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Old Mrs. Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
I don't know anything of Madame Olenska's private affairs; but I don't
need to, to be certain that what you insinuate--
subQuotationList: ["I don't know anything of Madame Olenska's private affairs; but I don't\nneed to, to be certain that what you insinuate--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, I don't: it's Lefferts, for one,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I don't: it's Lefferts, for one,"]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: Lefferts--who made love to her and got snubbed for it!
subQuotationList: ['Lefferts--who made love to her and got snubbed for it!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah--DID he?
subQuotationList: ['Ah--DID he?']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText:
Well, well: it's a pity she didn't go back before Beaufort's cropper, If she goes NOW, and if he fails, it will only confirm
the general impression: which isn't by any means peculiar to Lefferts,
by the way.
subQuotationList: ["Well, well: it's a pity she didn't go back before Beaufort's cropper,", "If she goes NOW, and if he fails, it will only confirm\nthe general impression: which isn't by any means peculiar to Lefferts,\nby the way."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: Oh, she won't go back now: less than ever!
subQuotationList: ["Oh, she won't go back now: less than ever!"]
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: Archer had no sooner said it

quoteText:
That's your opinion,
eh?  Well, no doubt you know.  But everybody will tell you that the few
pennies Medora Manson has left are all in Beaufort's hands; and how the
two women are to keep their heads above water unless he does, I can't
imagine.  Of course, Madame Olenska may still soften old Catherine,
who's been the most inexorably opposed to her staying; and old
Catherine could make her any allowance she chooses.  But we all know
that she hates parting with good money; and the rest of the family have
no particular interest in keeping Madame Olenska here.
subQuotationList:
["That's your opinion,
eh?  Well, no doubt you know.  But everybody will tell you that the few
pennies Medora Manson has left are all in Beaufort's hands; and how the
two women are to keep their heads above water unless he does, I can't
imagine.  Of course, Madame Olenska may still soften old Catherine,

Catherine could make her any allowance she chooses.  But we all know

speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson

quoteText: Shall we go up and join my mother?
subQuotationList: ['Shall we go up and join my mother?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: May!
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
This lamp is smoking again; I should think the servants might see that
it's kept properly trimmed,
subQuotationList: ["This lamp is smoking again; I should think the servants might see that\nit's kept properly trimmed,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I'm so sorry: it shan't happen again,
subQuotationList: ["I'm so sorry: it shan't happen again,"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
How young she is!  For what endless years this life will have to go
on!
subQuotationList: ['How young she is!  For what endless years this life will have to go\non!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Look here, I may have to go
to Washington for a few days--soon; next week perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['Look here,', 'I may have to go\nto Washington for a few days--soon; next week perhaps.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: On business?
subQuotationList: ['On business?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
On business, naturally.  There's a patent case coming up before the
Supreme Court--
subQuotationList: ["On business, naturally.  There's a patent case coming up before the\nSupreme Court--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes, I see.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I see.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: The change will do you good,
subQuotationList: ['The change will do you good,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: and you must be sure to go and see Ellen,
subQuotationList: ['and you must be sure to go and see Ellen,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: They smell less if one blows them out,
subQuotationList: ['They smell less if one blows them out,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I've seen bad things in my time; but nothing as bad as
this.  Everybody we know will be hit, one way or another.  And what
will be done about Mrs. Beaufort?  What CAN be done about her?  I pity
Mrs. Manson Mingott as much as anybody: coming at her age, there's no
knowing what effect this affair may have on her.  She always believed
in Beaufort--she made a friend of him!  And there's the whole Dallas
connection: poor Mrs. Beaufort is related to every one of you.  Her
only chance would be to leave her husband--yet how can any one tell her
so?  Her duty is at his side; and luckily she seems always to have been
blind to his private weaknesses.
subQuotationList:
["I've seen bad things in my time; but nothing as bad as
this.  Everybody we know will be hit, one way or another.  And what
will be done about Mrs. Beaufort?  What CAN be done about her?  I pity
Mrs. Manson Mingott as much as anybody: coming at her age, there's no
knowing what effect this affair may have on her.  She always believed
in Beaufort--she made a friend of him!  And there's the whole Dallas
connection: poor Mrs. Beaufort is related to every one of you.  Her
only chance would be to leave her husband--yet how can any one tell her
so?  Her duty is at his side; and luckily she seems always to have been
blind to his private weaknesses."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Beaufort']]]

quoteText:
What
is it?  I can't be disturbed.
subQuotationList: ["What\nis it?  I can't be disturbed."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: Mrs. Julius Beaufort
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Julius Beaufort']
speaker: The Butler
addressees: ['Mrs. Manson Mingott', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Beaufort', 'Miss Welland', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland']
referringExpression: The butler hearing a familiar voice had thrown open the sittingroom door announcing

quoteText: I said to her: And when she said: I said:
subQuotationList: ['I said to her:', 'And when she said:', 'I said:']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
referringExpression: the old woman had stammered into her daughters ear

quoteText:
If only I could
keep it from your father-in-law: he always says: 'Augusta, for pity's
sake, don't destroy my last illusions'--and how am I to prevent his
knowing these horrors?
subQuotationList:
["If only I could
keep it from your father-in-law: he always says: 'Augusta, for pity's
sake, don't destroy my last illusions'--and how am I to prevent his
knowing these horrors?"]
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland

quoteText: After all, Mamma, he won't have SEEN them,
subQuotationList: ["After all, Mamma, he won't have SEEN them,"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Ah, no; thank heaven he's safe in bed.  And
Dr. Bencomb has promised to keep him there till poor Mamma is better,
and Regina has been got away somewhere.
subQuotationList: ["Ah, no; thank heaven he's safe in bed.  And\nDr. Bencomb has promised to keep him there till poor Mamma is better,\nand Regina has been got away somewhere."]
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland

quoteText:
There was the case of poor Grandmamma Spicer;
your great-grandmother, May.  Of course, your great-grandfather's money difficulties were private--losses at
cards, or signing a note for somebody--I never quite knew, because
Mamma would never speak of it.  But she was brought up in the country
because her mother had to leave New York after the disgrace, whatever
it was: they lived up the Hudson alone, winter and summer, till Mamma
was sixteen.  It would never have occurred to Grandmamma Spicer to ask
the family to 'countenance' her, as I understand Regina calls it;
though a private disgrace is nothing compared to the scandal of ruining
hundreds of innocent people.
subQuotationList:
['There was the case of poor Grandmamma Spicer;
your great-grandmother, May.  Of course,', "your great-grandfather's money difficulties were private--losses at
cards, or signing a note for somebody--I never quite knew, because
Mamma would never speak of it.  But she was brought up in the country
because her mother had to leave New York after the disgrace, whatever
it was: they lived up the Hudson alone, winter and summer, till Mamma
was sixteen.  It would never have occurred to Grandmamma Spicer to ask
the family to 'countenance' her, as I understand Regina calls it;
though a private disgrace is nothing compared to the scandal of ruining
hundreds of innocent people."]
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland']], [['Miss Welland'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Old Mrs. Mingott'], ['Old Mrs. Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Old Mrs. Mingott'], ['Mrs. Beaufort']]]

quoteText:
Yes, it would be more becoming in Regina to hide her own countenance
than to talk about other people's, I
understand that the emerald necklace she wore at the Opera last Friday
had been sent on approval from Ball and Black's in the afternoon.  I
wonder if they'll ever get it back?
subQuotationList:
["Yes, it would be more becoming in Regina to hide her own countenance
than to talk about other people's,", "I
understand that the emerald necklace she wore at the Opera last Friday
had been sent on approval from Ball and Black's in the afternoon.  I
wonder if they'll ever get it back?"]
speaker: Mrs. Lovell Mingott

quoteText:
She wants me to telegraph for Ellen Olenska.  I had written to Ellen,
of course, and to Medora; but now it seems that's not enough.  I'm to
telegraph to her immediately, and to tell her that she's to come alone.
subQuotationList: ["She wants me to telegraph for Ellen Olenska.  I had written to Ellen,\nof course, and to Medora; but now it seems that's not enough.  I'm to\ntelegraph to her immediately, and to tell her that she's to come alone."]
speaker: Mrs. Lovell Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Old Mrs. Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['The Marchioness'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: I suppose it must be done,
subQuotationList: ['I suppose it must be done,']
speaker: Mrs. Lovell Mingott

quoteText:
Of course it must be done, Granny knows what she wants,
and we must carry out all her wishes.  Shall I write the telegram for
you, Auntie?  If it goes at once Ellen can probably catch tomorrow
morning's train.
subQuotationList:
['Of course it must be done,', "Granny knows what she wants,
and we must carry out all her wishes.  Shall I write the telegram for
you, Auntie?  If it goes at once Ellen can probably catch tomorrow
morning's train."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['May Wellend', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
Well, it can't go at once.  Jasper and the pantry-boy are both out
with notes and telegrams.
subQuotationList: ["Well, it can't go at once.  Jasper and the pantry-boy are both out\nwith notes and telegrams."]
speaker: Mrs. Lovell Mingott

quoteText:
But here's Newland, ready to
do anything.  Will you take the telegram, Newland?  There'll be just
time before luncheon.
subQuotationList: ["But here's Newland, ready to\ndo anything.  Will you take the telegram, Newland?  There'll be just\ntime before luncheon."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
What a pity, that you and Ellen will cross each other on
the way!--Newland,
subQuotationList: ['What a pity,', 'that you and Ellen will cross each other on\nthe way!--Newland,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
is
obliged to go to Washington about a patent law-suit that is coming up
before the Supreme Court.  I suppose Uncle Lovell will be back by
tomorrow night, and with Granny improving so much it doesn't seem right
to ask Newland to give up an important engagement for the firm--does
it?
subQuotationList:
["is
obliged to go to Washington about a patent law-suit that is coming up
before the Supreme Court.  I suppose Uncle Lovell will be back by
tomorrow night, and with Granny improving so much it doesn't seem right
to ask Newland to give up an important engagement for the firm--does
it?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Oh, of course not, darling.  Your Granny would be the last person to
wish it.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, of course not, darling.  Your Granny would be the last person to\nwish it.']
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland

quoteText:
But why on
earth she should make you telegraph for Ellen Olenska--
subQuotationList: ['But why on\nearth she should make you telegraph for Ellen Olenska--']
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland
referringExpression: he heard his motherinlaw add presumably to Mrs Lovell Mingott

quoteText:
Perhaps it's to urge on her again that after all
her duty is with her husband.
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps it's to urge on her again that after all\nher duty is with her husband."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Olenska--O-len-ska,
subQuotationList: ['Olenska--O-len-ska,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It's an unlikely name for a New York telegraph office; at least in
this quarter,
subQuotationList: ["It's an unlikely name for a New York telegraph office; at least in\nthis quarter,"]
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText:
Hallo, Newland: thought I'd catch you here.  I've just heard of old
Mrs. Mingott's stroke; and as I was on my way to the house I saw you
turning down this street and nipped after you.  I suppose you've come
from there?
subQuotationList:
["Hallo, Newland: thought I'd catch you here.  I've just heard of old
Mrs. Mingott's stroke; and as I was on my way to the house I saw you
turning down this street and nipped after you.  I suppose you've come
from there?"]
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
Very bad, eh? Wiring to the family, I suppose.
I gather it IS bad, if you're including Countess Olenska.
subQuotationList: ['Very bad, eh?', "Wiring to the family, I suppose.\nI gather it IS bad, if you're including Countess Olenska."]
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Mrs. Mingott
is much better: the doctor feels no anxiety whatever
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Mingott\nis much better: the doctor feels no anxiety whatever']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: Archer having regained his selfcontrol went on

quoteText:
The best thing the Beauforts can do, is to go and live at Regina's little place in North
Carolina.  Beaufort has always kept a racing stable, and he had better
breed trotting horses.  I should say he had all the qualities of a
successful horsedealer.
subQuotationList:
['The best thing the Beauforts can do,', "is to go and live at Regina's little place in North
Carolina.  Beaufort has always kept a racing stable, and he had better
breed trotting horses.  I should say he had all the qualities of a
successful horsedealer."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Beaufort', 'Julius Beaufort']], [['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Julius Beaufort']]]

quoteText:
If people of my age WILL eat chicken-salad in the evening what are
they to expect?
subQuotationList: ['If people of my age WILL eat chicken-salad in the evening what are\nthey to expect?']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
It's always one
thing after another, the only thing that makes me think Mamma must be less
well than Dr. Bencomb will admit is this morbid desire to have Ellen
come at once, however inconvenient it is to meet her.
subQuotationList:
["It's always one
thing after another,", 'the only thing that makes me think Mamma must be less
well than Dr. Bencomb will admit is this morbid desire to have Ellen
come at once, however inconvenient it is to meet her.']
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland

quoteText:
Augusta, have you
any other reason for thinking that Bencomb is less to be relied on than
he was?  Have you noticed that he has been less conscientious than
usual in following up my case or your mother's?
subQuotationList:
['Augusta,', "have you
any other reason for thinking that Bencomb is less to be relied on than
he was?  Have you noticed that he has been less conscientious than
usual in following up my case or your mother's?"]
speaker: Mr. Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Augusta Welland']], [['Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Dr. Bencomb'], ['Dr. Bencomb'], ['Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Dr. Bencomb'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott']]]

quoteText:
My dear, how
could you imagine such a thing?  I only meant that, after the decided
stand Mamma took about its being Ellen's duty to go back to her
husband, it seems strange that she should be seized with this sudden
whim to see her, when there are half a dozen other grandchildren that
she might have asked for.  But we must never forget that Mamma, in
spite of her wonderful vitality, is a very old woman.
subQuotationList:
["My dear, how
could you imagine such a thing?  I only meant that, after the decided
stand Mamma took about its being Ellen's duty to go back to her
husband, it seems strange that she should be seized with this sudden
whim to see her, when there are half a dozen other grandchildren that
she might have asked for.  But we must never forget that Mamma, in
spite of her wonderful vitality, is a very old woman."]
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Welland'], ['Mr. Welland'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Welland', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott']]]

quoteText:
Yes:
your mother's a very old woman; and for all we know Bencomb may not be
as successful with very old people.  As you say, my dear, it's always
one thing after another; and in another ten or fifteen years I suppose
I shall have the pleasing duty of looking about for a new doctor.  It's
always better to make such a change before it's absolutely necessary.
subQuotationList:
["Yes:
your mother's a very old woman; and for all we know Bencomb may not be
as successful with very old people.  As you say, my dear, it's always
one thing after another; and in another ten or fifteen years I suppose
I shall have the pleasing duty of looking about for a new doctor.  It's
always better to make such a change before it's absolutely necessary."]
speaker: Mr. Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mr. Welland', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Dr. Bencomb'], ['Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Mrs. Augusta Welland']]]

quoteText:
But all the while, I don't see how Ellen's to
be got here tomorrow evening; and I do like to have things settled for
at least twenty-four hours ahead.
subQuotationList: ['But all the while,', "I don't see how Ellen's to\nbe got here tomorrow evening; and I do like to have things settled for\nat least twenty-four hours ahead."]
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland

quoteText:
Shall I fetch her? I can easily get away from the
office in time to meet the brougham at the ferry, if May will send it
there.
subQuotationList: ['Shall I fetch her?', 'I can easily get away from the\noffice in time to meet the brougham at the ferry, if May will send it\nthere.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
So you see,
Mamma, everything WILL be settled twenty-four hours in advance,
subQuotationList: ['So you see,\nMamma, everything WILL be settled twenty-four hours in advance,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I didn't want
to worry Mamma by raising fresh obstacles; but how can you meet Ellen
tomorrow, and bring her back to New York, when you're going to
Washington?
subQuotationList:
["I didn't want
to worry Mamma by raising fresh obstacles; but how can you meet Ellen
tomorrow, and bring her back to New York, when you're going to
Washington?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Oh, I'm not going,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I'm not going,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Not going?  Why, what's happened?
subQuotationList: ["Not going?  Why, what's happened?"]
speaker: Miss Welland
referringExpression: Her voice was as clear as a bell

quoteText: The case is off--postponed.
subQuotationList: ['The case is off--postponed.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Postponed?  How odd!  I saw a note this morning from Mr. Letterblair
to Mamma saying that he was going to Washington tomorrow for the big
patent case that he was to argue before the Supreme Court.  You said it
was a patent case, didn't you?
subQuotationList:
["Postponed?  How odd!  I saw a note this morning from Mr. Letterblair
to Mamma saying that he was going to Washington tomorrow for the big
patent case that he was to argue before the Supreme Court.  You said it
was a patent case, didn't you?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Well--that's it: the whole office can't go.  Letterblair decided to go
this morning.
subQuotationList: ["Well--that's it: the whole office can't go.  Letterblair decided to go\nthis morning."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Then it's NOT postponed?
subQuotationList: ["Then it's NOT postponed?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: No: but my going is,
subQuotationList: ['No: but my going is,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I'm not going till later on: luckily for the convenience of your
family,
subQuotationList: ["I'm not going till later on: luckily for the convenience of your\nfamily,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes; it IS awfully convenient, that you should
be able to meet Ellen after all; you saw how much Mamma appreciated
your offering to do it.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; it IS awfully convenient,', 'that you should\nbe able to meet Ellen after all; you saw how much Mamma appreciated\nyour offering to do it.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Oh, I'm delighted to do it.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I'm delighted to do it."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Good-bye, dearest,
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, dearest,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
It's all of two hours from Jersey City to
old Catherine's.  It's all of two hours--and it may be more.
subQuotationList: ["It's all of two hours from Jersey City to\nold Catherine's.  It's all of two hours--and it may be more."]
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: He turned away and hurried across Union Square repeating to himself

quoteText:
I don't care which of their visions comes true, as
long as the tunnel isn't built yet.
subQuotationList: ["I don't care which of their visions comes true,", "as\nlong as the tunnel isn't built yet."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: This way--I have the carriage,
subQuotationList: ['This way--I have the carriage,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: If only it doesn't mean--poor Granny!
subQuotationList: ["If only it doesn't mean--poor Granny!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Oh, no, no--she's much better--she's all right, really.  There--we've
passed it!
subQuotationList: ["Oh, no, no--she's much better--she's all right, really.  There--we've\npassed it!"]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: You didn't expect me today?
subQuotationList: ["You didn't expect me today?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, no.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, no.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I meant to go to Washington to see you.  I'd made all my
arrangements--I very nearly crossed you in the train.
subQuotationList: ["I meant to go to Washington to see you.  I'd made all my\narrangements--I very nearly crossed you in the train."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh--
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Do you know--I hardly remembered you?
subQuotationList: ['Do you know--I hardly remembered you?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Hardly remembered me?
subQuotationList: ['Hardly remembered me?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I mean: how shall I explain?  I--it's always so.  EACH TIME YOU HAPPEN
TO ME ALL OVER AGAIN.
subQuotationList: ["I mean: how shall I explain?  I--it's always so.  EACH TIME YOU HAPPEN\nTO ME ALL OVER AGAIN."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, yes: I know!  I know!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes: I know!  I know!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Does it--do I too: to you?
subQuotationList: ['Does it--do I too: to you?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ellen--Ellen--Ellen!
subQuotationList: ['Ellen--Ellen--Ellen!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What a pretty carriage!  Is it May's?
subQuotationList: ["What a pretty carriage!  Is it May's?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: It was May who sent you to fetch me, then?  How kind of her!
subQuotationList: ['It was May who sent you to fetch me, then?  How kind of her!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Your
husband's secretary came to see me the day after we met in Boston.
subQuotationList: ["Your\nhusband's secretary came to see me the day after we met in Boston."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
He writes
to her, then.
subQuotationList: ['He writes\nto her, then.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: M. Riviere went to see you?
subQuotationList: ['M. Riviere went to see you?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Yes: didn't you know?
subQuotationList: ["Yes: didn't you know?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No,
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: And you're not surprised?
subQuotationList: ["And you're not surprised?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Why should I be?  He told me in Boston that he knew
you; that he'd met you in England I think.
subQuotationList: ["Why should I be?  He told me in Boston that he knew\nyou; that he'd met you in England I think."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Ellen--I must ask you one thing.
subQuotationList: ['Ellen--I must ask you one thing.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I wanted to ask it after I saw him, but I couldn't put it in a letter.
It was Riviere who helped you to get away--when you left your husband?
subQuotationList: ["I wanted to ask it after I saw him, but I couldn't put it in a letter.\nIt was Riviere who helped you to get away--when you left your husband?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes: I owe him a great debt,
subQuotationList: ['Yes: I owe him a great debt,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: I think you're the most honest woman I ever met!
subQuotationList: ["I think you're the most honest woman I ever met!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, no--but probably one of the least fussy,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, no--but probably one of the least fussy,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Call it what you like: you look at things as they are.
subQuotationList: ['Call it what you like: you look at things as they are.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah--I've had to.  I've had to look at the Gorgon.
subQuotationList: ["Ah--I've had to.  I've had to look at the Gorgon."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Well--it hasn't blinded you!  You've seen that she's just an old bogey
like all the others.
subQuotationList: ["Well--it hasn't blinded you!  You've seen that she's just an old bogey\nlike all the others."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: She doesn't blind one; but she dries up one's tears.
subQuotationList: ["She doesn't blind one; but she dries up one's tears."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: If you're not blind, then, you must see that this can't last.
subQuotationList: ["If you're not blind, then, you must see that this can't last."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What can't?
subQuotationList: ["What can't?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Our being together--and not together.
subQuotationList: ['Our being together--and not together.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Don't be afraid of me: you needn't squeeze yourself back into your
corner like that.  A stolen kiss isn't what I want.  Look: I'm not even
trying to touch the sleeve of your jacket.  Don't suppose that I don't
understand your reasons for not wanting to let this feeling between us
dwindle into an ordinary hole-and-corner love-affair.  I couldn't have
spoken like this yesterday, because when we've been apart, and I'm
looking forward to seeing you, every thought is burnt up in a great
flame.  But then you come; and you're so much more than I remembered,
and what I want of you is so much more than an hour or two every now
and then, with wastes of thirsty waiting between, that I can sit
perfectly still beside you, like this, with that other vision in my
mind, just quietly trusting to it to come true.
subQuotationList:
["Don't be afraid of me: you needn't squeeze yourself back into your
corner like that.  A stolen kiss isn't what I want.  Look: I'm not even
trying to touch the sleeve of your jacket.  Don't suppose that I don't
understand your reasons for not wanting to let this feeling between us
dwindle into an ordinary hole-and-corner love-affair.  I couldn't have
spoken like this yesterday, because when we've been apart, and I'm
looking forward to seeing you, every thought is burnt up in a great
flame.  But then you come; and you're so much more than I remembered,
and what I want of you is so much more than an hour or two every now
and then, with wastes of thirsty waiting between, that I can sit
perfectly still beside you, like this, with that other vision in my
mind, just quietly trusting to it to come true."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: What do you mean by trusting to it to come true?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean by trusting to it to come true?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Why--you know it will, don't you?
subQuotationList: ["Why--you know it will, don't you?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Your vision of you and me together?
subQuotationList: ['Your vision of you and me together?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You choose your place well to put it to me!
subQuotationList: ['You choose your place well to put it to me!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Do you mean because we're in my wife's brougham?  Shall we get out and
walk, then?  I don't suppose you mind a little snow?
subQuotationList: ["Do you mean because we're in my wife's brougham?  Shall we get out and\nwalk, then?  I don't suppose you mind a little snow?"]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
No; I shan't get out and walk,
because my business is to get to Granny's as quickly as I can.  And
you'll sit beside me, and we'll look, not at visions, but at realities.
subQuotationList: ["No; I shan't get out and walk,\nbecause my business is to get to Granny's as quickly as I can.  And\nyou'll sit beside me, and we'll look, not at visions, but at realities."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I don't know what you mean by realities.  The only reality to me is
this.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know what you mean by realities.  The only reality to me is\nthis."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Is it your idea, then, that I should live with you as your
mistress--since I can't be your wife?
subQuotationList: ["Is it your idea, then, that I should live with you as your\nmistress--since I can't be your wife?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I want--I want somehow to get away with you into a world where words
like that--categories like that--won't exist.  Where we shall be simply
two human beings who love each other, who are the whole of life to each
other; and nothing else on earth will matter.
subQuotationList:
["I want--I want somehow to get away with you into a world where words
like that--categories like that--won't exist.  Where we shall be simply
two human beings who love each other, who are the whole of life to each
other; and nothing else on earth will matter."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, my dear--where
is that country?  Have you ever been there?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my dear--where\nis that country?  Have you ever been there?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
I know so many who've tried to
find it; and, believe me, they all got out by mistake at wayside
stations: at places like Boulogne, or Pisa, or Monte Carlo--and it
wasn't at all different from the old world they'd left, but only rather
smaller and dingier and more promiscuous.
subQuotationList:
["I know so many who've tried to
find it; and, believe me, they all got out by mistake at wayside
stations: at places like Boulogne, or Pisa, or Monte Carlo--and it
wasn't at all different from the old world they'd left, but only rather
smaller and dingier and more promiscuous."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Yes, the Gorgon HAS dried your tears,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, the Gorgon HAS dried your tears,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well, she opened my eyes too; it's a delusion to say that she blinds
people.  What she does is just the contrary--she fastens their eyelids
open, so that they're never again in the blessed darkness.  Isn't there
a Chinese torture like that?  There ought to be.  Ah, believe me, it's
a miserable little country!
subQuotationList:
["Well, she opened my eyes too; it's a delusion to say that she blinds
people.  What she does is just the contrary--she fastens their eyelids
open, so that they're never again in the blessed darkness.  Isn't there
a Chinese torture like that?  There ought to be.  Ah, believe me, it's
a miserable little country!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott']]]

quoteText: Then what, exactly, is your plan for us?
subQuotationList: ['Then what, exactly, is your plan for us?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
For US?  But there's no US in that sense!  We're near each other only
if we stay far from each other.  Then we can be ourselves.  Otherwise
we're only Newland Archer, the husband of Ellen Olenska's cousin, and
Ellen Olenska, the cousin of Newland Archer's wife, trying to be happy
behind the backs of the people who trust them.
subQuotationList:
["For US?  But there's no US in that sense!  We're near each other only
if we stay far from each other.  Then we can be ourselves.  Otherwise
we're only Newland Archer, the husband of Ellen Olenska's cousin, and
Ellen Olenska, the cousin of Newland Archer's wife, trying to be happy
behind the backs of the people who trust them."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionTextsList: [['US', 'US ', 'We', 'we', 'we', 'we', 'Newland Archer', "the husband of Ellen Olenska's cousin", 'Ellen', 'cousin', 'Ellen Olenska']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska', 'Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['May Wellend'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Ah, I'm beyond that,
subQuotationList: ["Ah, I'm beyond that,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No, you're not!  You've never been beyond.  And I have, and I know what it looks like there.
subQuotationList: ["No, you're not!  You've never been beyond.  And I have,", 'and I know what it looks like there.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Why are we stopping?  This is not Granny's,
subQuotationList: ["Why are we stopping?  This is not Granny's,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: No: I shall get out here,
subQuotationList: ['No: I shall get out here,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You're right: I ought not to have come today,
subQuotationList: ["You're right: I ought not to have come today,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
What became of you, dear? I was waiting at Granny's, and
Ellen came alone, and said she had dropped you on the way because you
had to rush off on business.  There's nothing wrong?
subQuotationList: ['What became of you, dear?', "I was waiting at Granny's, and\nEllen came alone, and said she had dropped you on the way because you\nhad to rush off on business.  There's nothing wrong?"]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']], [['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: Only some letters I'd forgotten, and wanted to get off before dinner.
subQuotationList: ["Only some letters I'd forgotten, and wanted to get off before dinner."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah-- I'm sorry you didn't come to
Granny's--unless the letters were urgent.
subQuotationList: ['Ah--', "I'm sorry you didn't come to\nGranny's--unless the letters were urgent."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
They were, Besides, I
don't see why I should have gone to your grandmother's.  I didn't know
you were there.
subQuotationList: ['They were,', "Besides, I\ndon't see why I should have gone to your grandmother's.  I didn't know\nyou were there."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes!
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What news?
subQuotationList: ['What news?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It seems they're going to stay in New York.  I believe he's going into
an insurance business, or something.  They're looking about for a small
house.
subQuotationList: ["It seems they're going to stay in New York.  I believe he's going into\nan insurance business, or something.  They're looking about for a small\nhouse."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: What's the matter?
subQuotationList: ["What's the matter?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: The room is stifling: I want a little air.
subQuotationList: ['The room is stifling: I want a little air.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Newland!  Do shut the window.  You'll catch your death.
subQuotationList: ["Newland!  Do shut the window.  You'll catch your death."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Catch my death!
subQuotationList: ['Catch my death!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Newland!  Are you ill?
subQuotationList: ['Newland!  Are you ill?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Poor May!
subQuotationList: ['Poor May!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Poor?  Why poor?
subQuotationList: ['Poor?  Why poor?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Because I shall never be able to open a window without worrying you,
subQuotationList: ['Because I shall never be able to open a window without worrying you,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I shall never worry if you're happy.
subQuotationList: ["I shall never worry if you're happy."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Ah, my dear; and I shall never be happy unless I can open the windows!
subQuotationList: ['Ah, my dear; and I shall never be happy unless I can open the windows!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: In THIS weather?
subQuotationList: ['In THIS weather?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: All right.  Shall we go together this afternoon?
subQuotationList: ['All right.  Shall we go together this afternoon?']
speaker: Newland Archer
referringExpression: Archer felt it incumbent on him to say

quoteText:
Oh, you'd much
better go alone.  It bores Granny to see the same people too often.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, you'd much\nbetter go alone.  It bores Granny to see the same people too often."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Don't let in any
one else.  If my daughters call, say I'm asleep.
subQuotationList: ["Don't let in any\none else.  If my daughters call, say I'm asleep."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
referringExpression: She held out one of the little hands that nestled in a hollow of her huge lap like pet animals and called to the maid

quoteText:
My dear, am I perfectly hideous? My
daughters tell me it doesn't matter at my age--as if hideousness didn't
matter all the more the harder it gets to conceal!
subQuotationList: ['My dear, am I perfectly hideous?', "My\ndaughters tell me it doesn't matter at my age--as if hideousness didn't\nmatter all the more the harder it gets to conceal!"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: My dear, you're handsomer than ever!
subQuotationList: ["My dear, you're handsomer than ever!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah, but not as handsome as Ellen!
subQuotationList: ['Ah, but not as handsome as Ellen!']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Was she so awfully
handsome the day you drove her up from the ferry?
subQuotationList: ['Was she so awfully\nhandsome the day you drove her up from the ferry?']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Was it because you told her so that
she had to put you out on the way?  In my youth young men didn't desert
pretty women unless they were made to!
subQuotationList: ["Was it because you told her so that\nshe had to put you out on the way?  In my youth young men didn't desert\npretty women unless they were made to!"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
It's a pity she didn't
marry you; I always told her so.  It would have spared me all this
worry.  But who ever thought of sparing their grandmother worry?
subQuotationList: ["It's a pity she didn't\nmarry you; I always told her so.  It would have spared me all this\nworry.  But who ever thought of sparing their grandmother worry?"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
referringExpression: She gave another chuckle and interrupted it to say

quoteText:
Well, it's settled, anyhow: she's going to stay with
me, whatever the rest of the family say!  She hadn't been here five
minutes before I'd have gone down on my knees to keep her--if only, for
the last twenty years, I'd been able to see where the floor was!
subQuotationList:
["Well, it's settled, anyhow: she's going to stay with
me, whatever the rest of the family say!  She hadn't been here five
minutes before I'd have gone down on my knees to keep her--if only, for
the last twenty years, I'd been able to see where the floor was!"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
They'd talked me over,
as no doubt you know: persuaded me, Lovell, and Letterblair, and
Augusta Welland, and all the rest of them, that I must hold out and cut
off her allowance, till she was made to see that it was her duty to go
back to Olenski.  They thought they'd convinced me when the secretary,
or whatever he was, came out with the last proposals: handsome
