proposals I confess they were.  After all, marriage is marriage, and
money's money--both useful things in their way ... and I didn't know
what to answer--
subQuotationList:
["They'd talked me over,
as no doubt you know: persuaded me, Lovell, and Letterblair, and
Augusta Welland, and all the rest of them, that I must hold out and cut
off her allowance, till she was made to see that it was her duty to go
back to Olenski.  They thought they'd convinced me when the secretary,
or whatever he was, came out with the last proposals: handsome
proposals I confess they were.  After all, marriage is marriage, and
money's money--both useful things in their way ... and I didn't know
what to answer--"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Mr. Letterblair'], ['Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Count Olenski'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['M. Riviere'], ['M. Riviere'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland']]]

quoteText: But the minute I laid eyes on her, I said:
subQuotationList: ['But the minute I laid eyes on her, I said:']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
And
now it's settled that she's to stay here and nurse her Granny as long
as there's a Granny to nurse.  It's not a gay prospect, but she doesn't
mind; and of course I've told Letterblair that she's to be given her
proper allowance.
subQuotationList:
["And
now it's settled that she's to stay here and nurse her Granny as long
as there's a Granny to nurse.  It's not a gay prospect, but she doesn't
mind; and of course I've told Letterblair that she's to be given her
proper allowance."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Letterblair'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: She couldn't have gone back--it was impossible!
subQuotationList: ["She couldn't have gone back--it was impossible!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah, my dear, I always knew you were on her side; and that's why I sent
for you today, and why I said to your pretty wife, when she proposed to
come with you: 'No, my dear, I'm pining to see Newland, and I don't
want anybody to share our transports.'  For you see, my dear--
subQuotationList:
["Ah, my dear, I always knew you were on her side; and that's why I sent
for you today, and why I said to your pretty wife, when she proposed to
come with you: 'No, my dear, I'm pining to see Newland, and I don't
want anybody to share our transports.'  For you see, my dear--"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
you see, we shall have a fight yet.  The family
don't want her here, and they'll say it's because I've been ill,
because I'm a weak old woman, that she's persuaded me.  I'm not well
enough yet to fight them one by one, and you've got to do it for me.
subQuotationList:
["you see, we shall have a fight yet.  The family
don't want her here, and they'll say it's because I've been ill,
because I'm a weak old woman, that she's persuaded me.  I'm not well
enough yet to fight them one by one, and you've got to do it for me."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Old Mrs. Mingott', 'Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: I?
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You.  Why not?
subQuotationList: ['You.  Why not?']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: Why not?
subQuotationList: ['Why not?']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: Oh, I don't count--I'm too insignificant.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I don't count--I'm too insignificant."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well, you're Letterblair's partner, ain't you?  You've got to get at
them through Letterblair.  Unless you've got a reason,
subQuotationList: ["Well, you're Letterblair's partner, ain't you?  You've got to get at\nthem through Letterblair.  Unless you've got a reason,"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Mr. Letterblair'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Mr. Letterblair'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
Oh, my dear, I back you to hold your own against them all without my
help; but you shall have it if you need it,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my dear, I back you to hold your own against them all without my\nhelp; but you shall have it if you need it,']
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott']]]

quoteText: Then we're safe!
subQuotationList: ["Then we're safe!"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
I
always knew you'd back us up, because they never quote you when they
talk about its being her duty to go home.
subQuotationList: ["I\nalways knew you'd back us up, because they never quote you when they\ntalk about its being her duty to go home."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: And Madame Olenska?  When am I to see her?
subQuotationList: ['And Madame Olenska?  When am I to see her?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Not today.  One at a time, please.  Madame
Olenska's gone out.
subQuotationList: ["Not today.  One at a time, please.  Madame\nOlenska's gone out."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
She's gone out, my
child: gone in my carriage to see Regina Beaufort.
subQuotationList: ["She's gone out, my\nchild: gone in my carriage to see Regina Beaufort."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
That's what
she's reduced me to already.  The day after she got here she put on her
best bonnet, and told me, as cool as a cucumber, that she was going to
call on Regina Beaufort.
subQuotationList:
["That's what
she's reduced me to already.  The day after she got here she put on her
best bonnet, and told me, as cool as a cucumber, that she was going to
call on Regina Beaufort."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Beaufort']]]

quoteText: says I.
subQuotationList: ['says I.']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: she says.
subQuotationList: ['she says.']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: I answered.
subQuotationList: ['I answered.']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: she says,
subQuotationList: ['she says,']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Well, that floored
me, and I let her go; and finally one day she said it was raining too
hard to go out on foot, and she wanted me to lend her my carriage.
subQuotationList: ['Well, that floored\nme, and I let her go; and finally one day she said it was raining too\nhard to go out on foot, and she wanted me to lend her my carriage.']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: I asked her; and she said:
subQuotationList: ['I asked her; and she said:']
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
--COUSIN!  Now, my dear, I looked out of the window, and saw it
wasn't raining a drop; but I understood her, and I let her have the
carriage....  After all, Regina's a brave woman, and so is she; and
I've always liked courage above everything.
subQuotationList:
["--COUSIN!  Now, my dear, I looked out of the window, and saw it
wasn't raining a drop; but I understood her, and I let her have the
carriage....  After all, Regina's a brave woman, and so is she; and
I've always liked courage above everything."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Eh--eh--eh!  Whose hand did you think you were kissing, young
man--your wife's, I hope?
subQuotationList: ["Eh--eh--eh!  Whose hand did you think you were kissing, young\nman--your wife's, I hope?"]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
Give her her
Granny's love; but you'd better not say anything about our talk.
subQuotationList: ["Give her her\nGranny's love; but you'd better not say anything about our talk."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'Old Mrs. Mingott']]]

quoteText: Ellen,
subQuotationList: ['Ellen,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I shall see you now--we shall be together,
subQuotationList: ['I shall see you now--we shall be together,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah, Granny has told you?
subQuotationList: ['Ah,', 'Granny has told you?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Tomorrow I must see you--somewhere where we can be alone,
subQuotationList: ['Tomorrow I must see you--somewhere where we can be alone,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: But I shall be at Granny's--for the present that is,
subQuotationList: ["But I shall be at Granny's--for the present that is,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Somewhere where we can be alone,
subQuotationList: ['Somewhere where we can be alone,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: In New York?  But there are no churches ... no monuments.
subQuotationList: ['In New York?  But there are no churches ... no monuments.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: There's the Art Museum--in the Park, At half-past two.  I shall be at the door ...
subQuotationList: ["There's the Art Museum--in the Park,", 'At half-past two.  I shall be at the door ...']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: She'll come!
subQuotationList: ["She'll come!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: It's odd, I never came here before.
subQuotationList: ["It's odd,", 'I never came here before.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Ah, well--.  Some day, I suppose, it will be a great Museum.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well--.  Some day, I suppose, it will be a great Museum.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes,
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
It seems cruel, that after a while nothing matters ... any
more than these little things, that used to be necessary and important
to forgotten people, and now have to be guessed at under a magnifying
glass and labelled:  'Use unknown.'
subQuotationList:
['It seems cruel,', "that after a while nothing matters ... any
more than these little things, that used to be necessary and important
to forgotten people, and now have to be guessed at under a magnifying
glass and labelled:  'Use unknown.'"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Yes; but meanwhile--
subQuotationList: ['Yes; but meanwhile--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ah, meanwhile--
subQuotationList: ['Ah, meanwhile--']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Meanwhile everything matters--that concerns you,
subQuotationList: ['Meanwhile everything matters--that concerns you,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What is it you wanted to tell me?
subQuotationList: ['What is it you wanted to tell me?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
What I wanted to tell you? Why, that I believe you
came to New York because you were afraid.
subQuotationList: ['What I wanted to tell you?', 'Why, that I believe you\ncame to New York because you were afraid.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Afraid?
subQuotationList: ['Afraid?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Of my coming to Washington.
subQuotationList: ['Of my coming to Washington.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well--?
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well--yes,
subQuotationList: ['Well--yes,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: You WERE afraid?  You knew--?
subQuotationList: ['You WERE afraid?  You knew--?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes: I knew ...
subQuotationList: ['Yes: I knew ...']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Well, then?
subQuotationList: ['Well, then?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well, then: this is better, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["Well, then: this is better, isn't it?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Better--?
subQuotationList: ['Better--?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
We shall hurt others less.  Isn't it, after all, what you always
wanted?
subQuotationList: ["We shall hurt others less.  Isn't it, after all, what you always\nwanted?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
To have you here, you mean--in reach and yet out of reach?  To meet
you in this way, on the sly?  It's the very reverse of what I want.  I
told you the other day what I wanted.
subQuotationList: ["To have you here, you mean--in reach and yet out of reach?  To meet\nyou in this way, on the sly?  It's the very reverse of what I want.  I\ntold you the other day what I wanted."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: And you still think this--worse?
subQuotationList: ['And you still think this--worse?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
A thousand times! It would be easy to lie to you; but
the truth is I think it detestable.
subQuotationList: ['A thousand times!', 'It would be easy to lie to you; but\nthe truth is I think it detestable.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, so do I!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, so do I!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Well, then--it's my turn to ask: what is
it, in God's name, that you think better?
subQuotationList: ["Well, then--it's my turn to ask: what is\nit, in God's name, that you think better?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: What do you think better?
subQuotationList: ['What do you think better?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I promised Granny to stay with her
because it seemed to me that here I should be safer.
subQuotationList: ['I promised Granny to stay with her\nbecause it seemed to me that here I should be safer.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: From me?
subQuotationList: ['From me?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Safer from loving me?
subQuotationList: ['Safer from loving me?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Safer from doing irreparable harm.  Don't let us be like all the
others!
subQuotationList: ["Safer from doing irreparable harm.  Don't let us be like all the\nothers!"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
What others?  I don't profess to be different from my kind.  I'm
consumed by the same wants and the same longings.
subQuotationList: ["What others?  I don't profess to be different from my kind.  I'm\nconsumed by the same wants and the same longings."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Shall I--once come to you; and then go home?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I--once come to you; and then go home?']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Dearest!
subQuotationList: ['Dearest!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Go home?
What do you mean by going home?
subQuotationList: ['Go home?\nWhat do you mean by going home?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Home to my husband.
subQuotationList: ['Home to my husband.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: And you expect me to say yes to that?
subQuotationList: ['And you expect me to say yes to that?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
What else is there?  I can't
stay here and lie to the people who've been good to me.
subQuotationList: ["What else is there?  I can't\nstay here and lie to the people who've been good to me."]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: But that's the very reason why I ask you to come away!
subQuotationList: ["But that's the very reason why I ask you to come away!"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: And destroy their lives, when they've helped me to remake mine?
subQuotationList: ["And destroy their lives, when they've helped me to remake mine?"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Old Mrs. Mingott', 'May Wellend'], ['Old Mrs. Mingott', 'May Wellend']]]

quoteText: If I were to let her come, I should have to let her go again.
subQuotationList: ['If I were to let her come,', 'I should have to let her go again.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
After all, we have lives of our own....  There's no
use attempting the impossible.  You're so unprejudiced about some
things, so used, as you say, to looking at the Gorgon, that I don't
know why you're afraid to face our case, and see it as it really
is--unless you think the sacrifice is not worth making.
subQuotationList:
['After all,', "we have lives of our own....  There's no
use attempting the impossible.  You're so unprejudiced about some
things, so used, as you say, to looking at the Gorgon, that I don't
know why you're afraid to face our case, and see it as it really
is--unless you think the sacrifice is not worth making."]
speaker: Newland Archer
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Newland Archer', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska', 'Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Call it that, then--I must go,
subQuotationList: ['Call it that, then--I must go,']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText:
Well,
then: come to me once,
subQuotationList: ['Well,\nthen: come to me once,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: When? Tomorrow?
subQuotationList: ['When?', 'Tomorrow?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: The day after.
subQuotationList: ['The day after.']
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Dearest--!
subQuotationList: ['Dearest--!']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, I shall be late--good-bye.  No, don't come any farther than this,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I shall be late--good-bye.  No, don't come any farther than this,"]
speaker: Ellen Olenska

quoteText: Is Mrs. Archer in?
subQuotationList: ['Is Mrs. Archer in?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
This was what had to be, then ... this was what had
to be,
subQuotationList: ['This was what had to be, then ... this was what had\nto be,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I'm dreadfully late--you weren't worried, were you?
subQuotationList: ["I'm dreadfully late--you weren't worried, were you?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Is it late?
subQuotationList: ['Is it late?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: After seven.  I believe you've been asleep!
subQuotationList: ["After seven.  I believe you've been asleep!"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I went to see Granny, and just as I was going away Ellen came in from
a walk; so I stayed and had a long talk with her.  It was ages since
we'd had a real talk....
subQuotationList: ["I went to see Granny, and just as I was going away Ellen came in from\na walk; so I stayed and had a long talk with her.  It was ages since\nwe'd had a real talk...."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Miss Welland', 'Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
A really good talk, She was so dear--just like the old Ellen.
I'm afraid I haven't been fair to her lately.  I've sometimes thought--
subQuotationList: ['A really good talk,', "She was so dear--just like the old Ellen.\nI'm afraid I haven't been fair to her lately.  I've sometimes thought--"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Yes, you've thought--?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, you've thought--?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well, perhaps I haven't judged her fairly.  She's so different--at
least on the surface.  She takes up such odd people--she seems to like
to make herself conspicuous.  I suppose it's the life she's led in that
fast European society; no doubt we seem dreadfully dull to her.  But I
don't want to judge her unfairly.
subQuotationList:
["Well, perhaps I haven't judged her fairly.  She's so different--at
least on the surface.  She takes up such odd people--she seems to like
to make herself conspicuous.  I suppose it's the life she's led in that
fast European society; no doubt we seem dreadfully dull to her.  But I
don't want to judge her unfairly."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['May Wellend', 'Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
She hates Ellen, and she's trying to overcome the
feeling, and to get me to help her to overcome it.
subQuotationList: ['She hates Ellen,', "and she's trying to overcome the\nfeeling, and to get me to help her to overcome it."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You understand, don't you, why the family have
sometimes been annoyed?  We all did what we could for her at first; but
she never seemed to understand.  And now this idea of going to see Mrs.
Beaufort, of going there in Granny's carriage!  I'm afraid she's quite
alienated the van der Luydens ...
subQuotationList:
["You understand, don't you,", "why the family have
sometimes been annoyed?  We all did what we could for her at first; but
she never seemed to understand.  And now this idea of going to see Mrs.
Beaufort, of going there in Granny's carriage!  I'm afraid she's quite
alienated the van der Luydens ..."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']], [['May Wellend', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland', 'Old Mrs. Mingott', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair'], ['May Wellend', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland', 'Old Mrs. Mingott', 'Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Letterblair'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Regina'], ['Mrs. Manson Mingott'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText: Ah,
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: It's time to dress; we're dining out, aren't we?
subQuotationList: ["It's time to dress; we're dining out, aren't we?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You haven't kissed me today,
subQuotationList: ["You haven't kissed me today,"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: At the court of the Tuileries, such things were pretty openly tolerated.
subQuotationList: ['At the court of the Tuileries,', 'such things were pretty openly tolerated.']
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland']

quoteText:
It will never do, my dear Louisa, to let people like Mrs. Lemuel
Struthers think they can step into Regina's shoes.  It is just at such
times that new people push in and get a footing.  It was owing to the
epidemic of chicken-pox in New York the winter Mrs. Struthers first
appeared that the married men slipped away to her house while their
wives were in the nursery.  You and dear Henry, Louisa, must stand in
the breach as you always have.
subQuotationList:
["It will never do, my dear Louisa, to let people like Mrs. Lemuel
Struthers think they can step into Regina's shoes.  It is just at such
times that new people push in and get a footing.  It was owing to the
epidemic of chicken-pox in New York the winter Mrs. Struthers first
appeared that the married men slipped away to her house while their
wives were in the nursery.  You and dear Henry, Louisa, must stand in
the breach as you always have."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Lemuel Struthers'], ['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden']]]

quoteText:
Is it possible, dear, that what I hear is true?  I was told your
grandmother Mingott's carriage was seen standing at Mrs. Beaufort's
door.
subQuotationList: ["Is it possible, dear, that what I hear is true?  I was told your\ngrandmother Mingott's carriage was seen standing at Mrs. Beaufort's\ndoor."]
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
If it was, I'm
convinced it was there without Mrs. Mingott's knowledge.
subQuotationList: ["If it was, I'm\nconvinced it was there without Mrs. Mingott's knowledge."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: Ah, you think--?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, you think--?']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
I'm afraid, that Madame Olenska's kind
heart may have led her into the imprudence of calling on Mrs. Beaufort.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid,", "that Madame Olenska's kind\nheart may have led her into the imprudence of calling on Mrs. Beaufort."]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: Or her taste for peculiar people,
subQuotationList: ['Or her taste for peculiar people,']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: I'm sorry to think it of Madame Olenska,
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry to think it of Madame Olenska,"]
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
Ah, my dear--and after you'd had her twice
at Skuytercliff!
subQuotationList: ["Ah, my dear--and after you'd had her twice\nat Skuytercliff!"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
At the Tuileries, the standard was excessively lax in some
respects; and if you'd asked where Morny's money came from--!  Or who
paid the debts of some of the Court beauties ...
subQuotationList: ['At the Tuileries,', "the standard was excessively lax in some\nrespects; and if you'd asked where Morny's money came from--!  Or who\npaid the debts of some of the Court beauties ..."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland']

quoteText:
I hope, dear Sillerton, you are not suggesting
that we should adopt such standards?
subQuotationList: ['I hope, dear Sillerton,', 'you are not suggesting\nthat we should adopt such standards?']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Jackson']], [['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Old Mrs. Mingott', 'Mrs. Augusta Welland', 'May Wellend']]]

quoteText:
I never suggest, But Madame
Olenska's foreign bringing-up may make her less particular--
subQuotationList: ['I never suggest,', "But Madame\nOlenska's foreign bringing-up may make her less particular--"]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland']

quoteText: Still, to have kept her grandmother's carriage at a defaulter's door!
subQuotationList: ["Still, to have kept her grandmother's carriage at a defaulter's door!"]
speaker: Mr. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
Of course I've always said that she looks at things quite
differently,
subQuotationList: ["Of course I've always said that she looks at things quite\ndifferently,"]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: I'm sure Ellen meant it kindly.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sure Ellen meant it kindly."]
speaker: Miss Welland
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']
referringExpression: She looked across the table at her husband and said

quoteText: Imprudent people are often kind,
subQuotationList: ['Imprudent people are often kind,']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
If
only she had consulted some one--
subQuotationList: ['If\nonly she had consulted some one--']
speaker: Mrs. Van Der Luyden
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText: Ah, that she never did!
subQuotationList: ['Ah, that she never did!']
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
addressees: ['Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Newland Archer', 'Miss Welland', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson']

quoteText:
I couldn't have my happiness made out of
a wrong--a wrong to some one else;
subQuotationList: ["I couldn't have my happiness made out of\na wrong--a wrong to some one else;"]
speaker: Miss Welland
referringExpression: he heard the voice in which she had said

quoteText:
I've got a beastly headache; don't tell any one, but come home, won't
you?
subQuotationList: ["I've got a beastly headache; don't tell any one, but come home, won't\nyou?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I'm so sorry you
don't feel well.  I'm afraid they've been overworking you again at the
office.
subQuotationList: ["I'm so sorry you\ndon't feel well.  I'm afraid they've been overworking you again at the\noffice."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: No--it's not that: do you mind if I open the window?
subQuotationList: ["No--it's not that: do you mind if I open the window?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Did you hurt yourself?
subQuotationList: ['Did you hurt yourself?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No; but my poor dress--see how I've torn it! Oh, no,
subQuotationList: ["No; but my poor dress--see how I've torn it!", 'Oh, no,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: But hadn't you better go to bed at once?
subQuotationList: ["But hadn't you better go to bed at once?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
No; my head is not as bad as that. And there's
something I want to say; something important--that I must tell you at
once.
subQuotationList: ['No; my head is not as bad as that.', "And there's\nsomething I want to say; something important--that I must tell you at\nonce."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes, dear?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, dear?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: May--
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
There is something I've got to tell you ...
about myself ...
subQuotationList: ["There is something I've got to tell you ...\nabout myself ..."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Madame Olenska--
subQuotationList: ['Madame Olenska--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Oh, why should we talk about Ellen tonight?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, why should we talk about Ellen tonight?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Because I ought to have spoken before.
subQuotationList: ['Because I ought to have spoken before.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Is it really worth while, dear?  I know I've
been unfair to her at times--perhaps we all have.  You've understood
her, no doubt, better than we did: you've always been kind to her.  But
what does it matter, now it's all over?
subQuotationList:
["Is it really worth while, dear?  I know I've
been unfair to her at times--perhaps we all have.  You've understood
her, no doubt, better than we did: you've always been kind to her.  But
what does it matter, now it's all over?"]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'May Wellend'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer', 'May Wellend'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: All over--what do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['All over--what do you mean?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Why--since she's going
back to Europe so soon; since Granny approves and understands, and has
arranged to make her independent of her husband--
subQuotationList: ["Why--since she's going\nback to Europe so soon; since Granny approves and understands, and has\narranged to make her independent of her husband--"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
I supposed, that you had been
kept at the office this evening about the business arrangements.  It
was settled this morning, I believe.
subQuotationList: ['I supposed,', 'that you had been\nkept at the office this evening about the business arrangements.  It\nwas settled this morning, I believe.']
speaker: Miss Welland
referringExpression: he heard his wifes even voice go on

quoteText: It's impossible,
subQuotationList: ["It's impossible,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Impossible--?
subQuotationList: ['Impossible--?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: How do you know--what you've just told me?
subQuotationList: ["How do you know--what you've just told me?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I saw Ellen yesterday--I told you I'd seen her at Granny's.
subQuotationList: ["I saw Ellen yesterday--I told you I'd seen her at Granny's."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: It wasn't then that she told you?
subQuotationList: ["It wasn't then that she told you?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No; I had a note from her this afternoon.--Do you want to see it?
subQuotationList: ['No; I had a note from her this afternoon.--Do you want to see it?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: I thought you knew,
subQuotationList: ['I thought you knew,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Why did she write this?
subQuotationList: ['Why did she write this?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I suppose because we
talked things over yesterday--
subQuotationList: ['I suppose because we\ntalked things over yesterday--']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: What things?
subQuotationList: ['What things?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I told her I was afraid I hadn't been fair to her--hadn't always
understood how hard it must have been for her here, alone among so many
people who were relations and yet strangers; who felt the right to
criticise, and yet didn't always know the circumstances. I knew you'd been the one friend she could always count on; and I
wanted her to know that you and I were the same--in all our feelings.
subQuotationList:
["I told her I was afraid I hadn't been fair to her--hadn't always
understood how hard it must have been for her here, alone among so many
people who were relations and yet strangers; who felt the right to
criticise, and yet didn't always know the circumstances.", "I knew you'd been the one friend she could always count on; and I
wanted her to know that you and I were the same--in all our feelings."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']], [['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'May Wellend']]]

quoteText:
She understood my wishing to tell her this.  I think she understands
everything.
subQuotationList: ['She understood my wishing to tell her this.  I think she understands\neverything.']
speaker: Miss Welland
referringExpression: She hesitated as if waiting for him to speak and then added

quoteText: My head aches too; good-night, dear,
subQuotationList: ['My head aches too; good-night, dear,']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Henry van der Luyden--Louisa--the Lovell Mingotts--the Reggie
Chiverses--Lawrence Lefferts and Gertrude--(yes, I suppose May was
right to have them)--the Selfridge Merrys, Sillerton Jackson, Van
Newland and his wife. (How time passes!  It seems only yesterday that
he was your best man, Newland)--and Countess Olenska--yes, I think
that's all....
subQuotationList:
["Henry van der Luyden--Louisa--the Lovell Mingotts--the Reggie
Chiverses--Lawrence Lefferts and Gertrude--(yes, I suppose May was
right to have them)--the Selfridge Merrys, Sillerton Jackson, Van
Newland and his wife. (How time passes!  It seems only yesterday that
he was your best man, Newland)--and Countess Olenska--yes, I think
that's all...."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer
referringExpression: Mrs Archer ran thoughtfully over the list
mentionTextsList: [['Henry van der Luyden', 'Louisa', 'the Lovell Mingotts', 'the Reggie\nChiverses', 'Lawrence Lefferts', 'Gertrude', 'May ', 'them', 'Merrys', 'Sillerton Jackson', 'wife', 'your', 'Newland', 'Countess Olenska']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Van Der Luyden'], ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott'], ['Reggie Chivers'], ['Lawrence Lefferts'], ['Gertrude Lefferts'], ['May Wellend'], ['Lawrence Lefferts'], ['Mrs. Merry', 'Mr. Merry'], ['Mr. Sillerton Jackson'], ['Young Mrs Newland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText:
No one can say,
Newland, that you and May are not giving Ellen a handsome send-off.
subQuotationList: ['No one can say,\nNewland, that you and May are not giving Ellen a handsome send-off.']
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland

quoteText:
Ah, well, I understand May's wanting her cousin to
tell people abroad that we're not quite barbarians.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well,', "I understand May's wanting her cousin to\ntell people abroad that we're not quite barbarians."]
speaker: Mrs. Adeline Archer

quoteText:
I'm sure Ellen will appreciate it.  She was to arrive this morning, I
believe.  It will make a most charming last impression.  The evening
before sailing is usually so dreary,
subQuotationList: ["I'm sure Ellen will appreciate it.  She was to arrive this morning, I\nbelieve.  It will make a most charming last impression.  The evening\nbefore sailing is usually so dreary,"]
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland

quoteText:
Do go in and have a peep at the table.  And don't let May tire herself
too much.
subQuotationList: ["Do go in and have a peep at the table.  And don't let May tire herself\ntoo much."]
speaker: Mrs. Augusta Welland

quoteText: Ah, well, it's not for long--
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well,', "it's not for long--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Well, the lady can't deny that it's a handsome arrangement, In fact I'm bound to say she's been treated pretty
handsomely all round.
subQuotationList: ["Well, the lady can't deny that it's a handsome arrangement,", "In fact I'm bound to say she's been treated pretty\nhandsomely all round."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText:
All round? Do you refer to
her husband's proposal to give her back her own money?
subQuotationList: ['All round?', "Do you refer to\nher husband's proposal to give her back her own money?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
My
dear sir, the law's the law; and your wife's cousin was married under
the French law.  It's to be presumed she knew what that meant.
subQuotationList: ["My\ndear sir, the law's the law; and your wife's cousin was married under\nthe French law.  It's to be presumed she knew what that meant."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: Even if she did, what happened subsequently--.
subQuotationList: ['Even if she did, what happened subsequently--.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
My dear sir, I've no wish to extenuate the Count's transgressions;
but--but on the other side ... I wouldn't put my hand in the fire ...
well, that there hadn't been tit for tat ... with the young
champion....
subQuotationList:
["My dear sir, I've no wish to extenuate the Count's transgressions;
but--but on the other side ... I wouldn't put my hand in the fire ...
well, that there hadn't been tit for tat ... with the young
champion...."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText:
This report, the result of discreet enquiries
...
subQuotationList: ['This report, the result of discreet enquiries\n...']
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText:
I
don't say it's conclusive, you observe; far from it.  But straws show
... and on the whole it's eminently satisfactory for all parties that
this dignified solution has been reached.
subQuotationList:
["I
don't say it's conclusive, you observe; far from it.  But straws show
... and on the whole it's eminently satisfactory for all parties that
this dignified solution has been reached."]
speaker: Mr. Letterblair

quoteText: Oh, eminently,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, eminently,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
You know she's deserted me? Oh, don't ask me why!  She gave so many reasons that
I've forgotten them all.  My private belief is that she couldn't face
the boredom.  At any rate that's what Augusta and my daughters-in-law
think.  And I don't know that I altogether blame her.  Olenski's a
finished scoundrel; but life with him must have been a good deal gayer
than it is in Fifth Avenue.  Not that the family would admit that: they
think Fifth Avenue is Heaven with the rue de la Paix thrown in.  And
poor Ellen, of course, has no idea of going back to her husband.  She
held out as firmly as ever against that.  So she's to settle down in
Paris with that fool Medora....  Well, Paris is Paris; and you can keep
a carriage there on next to nothing.  But she was as gay as a bird, and
I shall miss her.
subQuotationList:
["You know she's deserted me?", "Oh, don't ask me why!  She gave so many reasons that
I've forgotten them all.  My private belief is that she couldn't face
the boredom.  At any rate that's what Augusta and my daughters-in-law
think.  And I don't know that I altogether blame her.  Olenski's a
finished scoundrel; but life with him must have been a good deal gayer
than it is in Fifth Avenue.  Not that the family would admit that: they
think Fifth Avenue is Heaven with the rue de la Paix thrown in.  And
poor Ellen, of course, has no idea of going back to her husband.  She
held out as firmly as ever against that.  So she's to settle down in
Paris with that fool Medora....  Well, Paris is Paris; and you can keep
a carriage there on next to nothing.  But she was as gay as a bird, and
I shall miss her."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText:
All I ask is, that they shouldn't bother me any more.
I must really be allowed to digest my gruel....
subQuotationList: ['All I ask is,', "that they shouldn't bother me any more.\nI must really be allowed to digest my gruel...."]
speaker: Mrs. Manson Mingott

quoteText: A dinner--why?
subQuotationList: ['A dinner--why?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: But you like Ellen--I thought you'd be pleased.
subQuotationList: ["But you like Ellen--I thought you'd be pleased."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
It's awfully nice--your putting it in that way.  But I really don't
see--
subQuotationList: ["It's awfully nice--your putting it in that way.  But I really don't\nsee--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
I mean to do it, Newland, Here are the invitations all written.  Mother helped me--she
agrees that we ought to.
subQuotationList: ['I mean to do it, Newland,', 'Here are the invitations all written.  Mother helped me--she\nagrees that we ought to.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Oh, all right,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, all right,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: I don't think Ellen has ever seen this room lighted up,
subQuotationList: ["I don't think Ellen has ever seen this room lighted up,"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
Newland!  Dinner's been announced.
Won't you please take Ellen in?
subQuotationList: ["Newland!  Dinner's been announced.\nWon't you please take Ellen in?"]
speaker: Miss Welland
referringExpression: there was an unmeaning noise of opening doors and after an interval Mays voice

If it were only to see her hand
again I  should  have  to follow her--.
subQuotationList: ['If it were only to see her hand\nagain I  should  have  to follow her--.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It's to show me, what would happen to
ME--

I mean to
do a lot of travelling myself before long.

addressees: ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Young Mr. Newland', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Lawrence Lefferts', 'Miss Welland', 'Young Mrs. Newland', 'Mrs. Chivers', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson', 'Mrs. Merry', 'Ellen Olenska', 'Reggie Chivers', 'Mr. Merry']

quoteText:
I say, Reggie, what
do you say to a trip round the world: now, next month, I mean?  I'm
game if you are--
subQuotationList: ["I say, Reggie, what\ndo you say to a trip round the world: now, next month, I mean?  I'm\ngame if you are--"]
speaker: Newland Archer
addressees: ['Mrs. Lovell Mingott', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden', 'Young Mr. Newland', 'Mrs. Adeline Archer', 'Lawrence Lefferts', 'Miss Welland', 'Young Mrs. Newland', 'Mrs. Chivers', 'Mr. Sillerton Jackson', 'Mrs. Merry', 'Ellen Olenska', 'Reggie Chivers', 'Mr. Merry']

quoteText:
If things go on at this pace, we
shall see our children fighting for invitations to swindlers' houses,
and marrying Beaufort's bastards.
subQuotationList: ['If things go on at this pace,', "we\nshall see our children fighting for invitations to swindlers' houses,\nand marrying Beaufort's bastards."]

quoteText:
Queer, those fellows who are
always wanting to set things right.  The people who have the worst
cooks are always telling you they're poisoned when they dine out.  But
I hear there are pressing reasons for our friend Lawrence's
diatribe:--typewriter this time, I understand....
subQuotationList:
["Queer, those fellows who are
always wanting to set things right.  The people who have the worst
cooks are always telling you they're poisoned when they dine out.  But
I hear there are pressing reasons for our friend Lawrence's
diatribe:--typewriter this time, I understand...."]
speaker: Mr. Sillerton Jackson
referringExpression: the old gentleman twittered into Archers ear

quoteText: Certainly our hostess is much the handsomer of the two,
subQuotationList: ['Certainly our hostess is much the handsomer of the two,']
speaker: Reggie Chivers
referringExpression: Reggie Chivers say in an undertone to young Mrs Newland

quoteText: Is your carriage here?
subQuotationList: ['Is your carriage here?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: We are driving dear Ellen home.

subQuotationList: ['Good-bye--but I shall see you soon in Paris,']
speaker: Newland Archer
addressees: ['Ellen Olenska', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

subQuotationList: ['Oh,', 'if you and May could come--!']
speaker: Ellen Olenska
addressees: ['Newland Archer', 'Mr. Van Der Luyden', 'Mrs. Van Der Luyden']

quoteText:
I say, old chap: do you mind just letting it be understood that I'm
dining with you at the club tomorrow night?  Thanks so much, you old
brick!  Good-night.
subQuotationList: ["I say, old chap: do you mind just letting it be understood that I'm\ndining with you at the club tomorrow night?  Thanks so much, you old\nbrick!  Good-night."]
speaker: Lawrence Lefferts

quoteText: It DID go off beautifully, didn't it?
subQuotationList: ["It DID go off beautifully, didn't it?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: May I come and talk it over?
subQuotationList: ['May I come and talk it over?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Of course, if you like.  But you must be awfully sleepy--
subQuotationList: ['Of course, if you like.  But you must be awfully sleepy--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No, I'm not sleepy.  I should like to sit with you a little.
subQuotationList: ["No, I'm not sleepy.  I should like to sit with you a little."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Very well,
subQuotationList: ['Very well,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Since you're not tired, and
want to talk, there's something I must tell you.  I tried to the other
night--.
subQuotationList: ["Since you're not tired, and\nwant to talk, there's something I must tell you.  I tried to the other\nnight--."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Yes, dear.  Something about yourself?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, dear.  Something about yourself?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
About myself.  You say you're not tired: well, I am.  Horribly tired
...
subQuotationList: ["About myself.  You say you're not tired: well, I am.  Horribly tired\n..."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, I've seen it coming on,
Newland!  You've been so wickedly overworked--
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I've seen it coming on,\nNewland!  You've been so wickedly overworked--"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Perhaps it's that.  Anyhow, I want to make a break--
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps it's that.  Anyhow, I want to make a break--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: A break?  To give up the law?
subQuotationList: ['A break?  To give up the law?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
To go away, at any rate--at once.  On a long trip, ever so far
off--away from everything--
subQuotationList: ['To go away, at any rate--at once.  On a long trip, ever so far\noff--away from everything--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Away from everything--
subQuotationList: ['Away from everything--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Ever so far?  Where, for instance?
subQuotationList: ['Ever so far?  Where, for instance?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Oh, I don't know.  India--or Japan.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I don't know.  India--or Japan."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: As far as that?  But I'm afraid you can't, dear ... Not unless you'll take me with you.
subQuotationList: ["As far as that?  But I'm afraid you can't, dear ...", "Not unless you'll take me with you."]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
That is,
if the doctors will let me go ... but I'm afraid they won't.  For you
see, Newland, I've been sure since this morning of something I've been
so longing and hoping for--
subQuotationList:
["That is,
if the doctors will let me go ... but I'm afraid they won't.  For you
see, Newland, I've been sure since this morning of something I've been
so longing and hoping for--"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Oh, my dear,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my dear,']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: You didn't guess--?
subQuotationList: ["You didn't guess--?"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Yes--I; no.  That is, of course I hoped--
subQuotationList: ['Yes--I; no.  That is, of course I hoped--']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Have you told any one
else?
subQuotationList: ['Have you told any one\nelse?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Only Mamma and your mother.
subQuotationList: ['Only Mamma and your mother.']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText:
That is--and Ellen.  You know
I told you we'd had a long talk one afternoon--and how dear she was to
me.
subQuotationList: ["That is--and Ellen.  You know\nI told you we'd had a long talk one afternoon--and how dear she was to\nme."]
speaker: Miss Welland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland', 'Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: Ah--
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Did you MIND my
telling her first, Newland?
subQuotationList: ['Did you MIND my\ntelling her first, Newland?']
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Mind?  Why should I?
subQuotationList: ['Mind?  Why should I?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
But
that was a fortnight ago, wasn't it?  I thought you said you weren't
sure till today.
subQuotationList: ["But\nthat was a fortnight ago, wasn't it?  I thought you said you weren't\nsure till today."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No; I wasn't sure
then--but I told her I was.  And you see I was right!
subQuotationList: ["No; I wasn't sure\nthen--but I told her I was.  And you see I was right!"]
speaker: Miss Welland

quoteText: Dad,
speaker: Dallas
referringExpression: Dallas had first staggered across the floor shouting

quoteText:
Hallo, Dad--Yes: Dallas.  I say--how do you feel about sailing on
Wednesday?  Mauretania: Yes, next Wednesday as ever is.  Our client
wants me to look at some Italian gardens before we settle anything, and
has asked me to nip over on the next boat.  I've got to be back on the
first of June--
subQuotationList:
["Hallo, Dad--Yes: Dallas.  I say--how do you feel about sailing on
Wednesday?  Mauretania: Yes, next Wednesday as ever is.  Our client
wants me to look at some Italian gardens before we settle anything, and
has asked me to nip over on the next boat.  I've got to be back on the
first of June--"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText:
so we
must look alive.  I say, Dad, I want your help: do come.
subQuotationList: ['so we\nmust look alive.  I say, Dad, I want your help: do come.']
speaker: Dallas

quoteText:
Think it over?  No, sir: not a minute.  You've
got to say yes now.  Why not, I'd like to know?  If you can allege a
single reason--No; I knew it.  Then it's a go, eh?  Because I count on
you to ring up the Cunard office first thing tomorrow; and you'd better
book a return on a boat from Marseilles.  I say, Dad; it'll be our last
time together, in this kind of way--.  Oh, good!  I knew you would.
subQuotationList:
["Think it over?  No, sir: not a minute.  You've
got to say yes now.  Why not, I'd like to know?  If you can allege a
single reason--No; I knew it.  Then it's a go, eh?  Because I count on
you to ring up the Cunard office first thing tomorrow; and you'd better
book a return on a boat from Marseilles.  I say, Dad; it'll be our last
time together, in this kind of way--.  Oh, good!  I knew you would."]
speaker: Dallas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'Dallas'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText:
We'll stick
together,
subQuotationList: ["We'll stick\ntogether,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
It
functions as actively, no doubt, but the rhythm is different, The difference is that these young people take it for granted that
they're going to get whatever they want, and that we almost always took
it for granted that we shouldn't.  Only, I wonder--the thing one's so
certain of in advance: can it ever make one's heart beat as wildly?
subQuotationList:
['It
functions as actively, no doubt, but the rhythm is different,', "The difference is that these young people take it for granted that
they're going to get whatever they want, and that we almost always took
it for granted that we shouldn't.  Only, I wonder--the thing one's so
certain of in advance: can it ever make one's heart beat as wildly?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, all right--of course, I'll take
you to some jolly old-fashioned place--the Bristol say--
subQuotationList: ['Oh, all right--of course,', "I'll take\nyou to some jolly old-fashioned place--the Bristol say--"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText:
Hullo, father: this
is something like, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["Hullo, father: this\nis something like, isn't it?"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText:
By the way, I've got a
message for you: the Countess Olenska expects us both at half-past
five.
subQuotationList: ["By the way, I've got a\nmessage for you: the Countess Olenska expects us both at half-past\nfive."]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText:
Oh, didn't I tell you? Fanny made me swear to do
three things while I was in Paris: get her the score of the last
Debussy songs, go to the Grand-Guignol and see Madame Olenska.  You
know she was awfully good to Fanny when Mr. Beaufort sent her over from
Buenos Ayres to the Assomption.  Fanny hadn't any friends in Paris, and
Madame Olenska used to be kind to her and trot her about on holidays.
I believe she was a great friend of the first Mrs. Beaufort's.  And
she's our cousin, of course.  So I rang her up this morning, before I
went out, and told her you and I were here for two days and wanted to
see her.
subQuotationList:
["Oh, didn't I tell you?", "Fanny made me swear to do
three things while I was in Paris: get her the score of the last
Debussy songs, go to the Grand-Guignol and see Madame Olenska.  You
know she was awfully good to Fanny when Mr. Beaufort sent her over from
Buenos Ayres to the Assomption.  Fanny hadn't any friends in Paris, and
Madame Olenska used to be kind to her and trot her about on holidays.
I believe she was a great friend of the first Mrs. Beaufort's.  And
she's our cousin, of course.  So I rang her up this morning, before I
went out, and told her you and I were here for two days and wanted to
see her."]
speaker: Dallas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer']], [['Fanny'], ['Fanny'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Fanny'], ['Julius Beaufort'], ['Fanny'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Mrs. Beaufort'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Dallas'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Ellen Olenska'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Ellen Olenska']]]

quoteText: You told her I was here?
subQuotationList: ['You told her I was here?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Of course--why not?
subQuotationList: ['Of course--why not?']
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: I say, father: what was she like?
subQuotationList: ['I say, father: what was she like?']
speaker: Dallas

quoteText:
Come, own
up: you and she were great pals, weren't you?  Wasn't she most awfully
lovely?
subQuotationList: ["Come, own\nup: you and she were great pals, weren't you?  Wasn't she most awfully\nlovely?"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: Lovely?  I don't know.  She was different.
subQuotationList: ["Lovely?  I don't know.  She was different."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Ah--there you have it!  That's what it always comes to, doesn't it?
When she comes, SHE'S DIFFERENT--and one doesn't know why.  It's
exactly what I feel about Fanny.
subQuotationList: ["Ah--there you have it!  That's what it always comes to, doesn't it?\nWhen she comes, SHE'S DIFFERENT--and one doesn't know why.  It's\nexactly what I feel about Fanny."]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText:
About Fanny?  But, my
dear fellow--I should hope so!  Only I don't see--
subQuotationList: ["About Fanny?  But, my\ndear fellow--I should hope so!  Only I don't see--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Dash it, Dad, don't be prehistoric!  Wasn't she--once--your Fanny?
subQuotationList: ["Dash it, Dad, don't be prehistoric!  Wasn't she--once--your Fanny?"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText:
What's the use of
making mysteries?  It only makes people want to nose 'em out,
subQuotationList: ["What's the use of\nmaking mysteries?  It only makes people want to nose 'em out,"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: My Fanny?
subQuotationList: ['My Fanny?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Well, the woman you'd have chucked everything for: only you didn't,
subQuotationList: ["Well, the woman you'd have chucked everything for: only you didn't,"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: I didn't,
subQuotationList: ["I didn't,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: No: you date, you see, dear old boy.  But mother said--
subQuotationList: ['No: you date, you see, dear old boy.  But mother said--']
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: Your mother?
subQuotationList: ['Your mother?']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Yes: the day before she died.  It was when she sent for me alone--you
remember?  She said she knew we were safe with you, and always would
be, because once, when she asked you to, you'd given up the thing you
most wanted.
subQuotationList:
["Yes: the day before she died.  It was when she sent for me alone--you
remember?  She said she knew we were safe with you, and always would
be, because once, when she asked you to, you'd given up the thing you
most wanted."]
speaker: Dallas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Miss Welland', 'Dallas'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Miss Welland'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer']]]

quoteText: She never asked me.
subQuotationList: ['She never asked me.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
No.  I forgot.  You never did ask each other anything, did you?  And
you never told each other anything.  You just sat and watched each
other, and guessed at what was going on underneath.  A deaf-and-dumb
asylum, in fact!  Well, I back your generation for knowing more about
each other's private thoughts than we ever have time to find out about
our own.--I say, Dad, you're not angry with me?  If
you are, let's make it up and go and lunch at Henri's.  I've got to
rush out to Versailles afterward.
subQuotationList:
["No.  I forgot.  You never did ask each other anything, did you?  And
you never told each other anything.  You just sat and watched each
other, and guessed at what was going on underneath.  A deaf-and-dumb
asylum, in fact!  Well, I back your generation for knowing more about
each other's private thoughts than we ever have time to find out about
our own.--I say, Dad,", "you're not angry with me?  If
you are, let's make it up and go and lunch at Henri's.  I've got to
rush out to Versailles afterward."]
speaker: Dallas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'Dallas'], ['Newland Archer']], [['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer'], ['Newland Archer', 'Dallas']]]

quoteText:
But
I'm only fifty-seven--
subQuotationList: ["But\nI'm only fifty-seven--"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
That's it: they feel equal to things--they
know their way about,
subQuotationList: ["That's it: they feel equal to things--they\nknow their way about,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Oh, by
Jove,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, by\nJove,']
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: It must be here,
subQuotationList: ['It must be here,']
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: I wonder which floor--?
subQuotationList: ['I wonder which floor--?']
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: The fifth.  It must be the one with the awnings.
subQuotationList: ['The fifth.  It must be the one with the awnings.']
speaker: Dallas
referringExpression: he put his head into the porters lodge and came back to say

quoteText: I say, you know, it's nearly six,
subQuotationList: ["I say, you know, it's nearly six,"]
speaker: Dallas
referringExpression: his son at length reminded him

quoteText: I believe I'll sit there a moment,
subQuotationList: ["I believe I'll sit there a moment,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: Why--aren't you well?
subQuotationList: ["Why--aren't you well?"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: Oh, perfectly.  But I should like you, please, to go up without me.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, perfectly.  But I should like you, please, to go up without me.']

quoteText:
But, I say, Dad: do you
mean you won't come up at all?
subQuotationList: ["But, I say, Dad: do you\nmean you won't come up at all?"]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: I don't know,
subQuotationList: ["I don't know,"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: If you don't she won't understand.
subQuotationList: ["If you don't she won't understand."]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: Go, my boy; perhaps I shall follow you.
subQuotationList: ['Go, my boy; perhaps I shall follow you.']
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: But what on earth shall I say?
subQuotationList: ['But what on earth shall I say?']
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: My dear fellow, don't you always know what to say?
subQuotationList: ["My dear fellow, don't you always know what to say?"]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText:
Very well.  I shall say you're old-fashioned, and prefer walking up
the five flights because you don't like lifts.
subQuotationList: ["Very well.  I shall say you're old-fashioned, and prefer walking up\nthe five flights because you don't like lifts."]
speaker: Dallas

quoteText: Say I'm old-fashioned: that's enough.
subQuotationList: ["Say I'm old-fashioned: that's enough."]
speaker: Newland Archer

quoteText: It's more real to me here than if I went up,
subQuotationList: ["It's more real to me here than if I went up,"]
speaker: Newland Archer
